<Author>CautiousOptimist
<Content>The place grows on you We just returned from a week's stay at the Grand Paradise Bavaro. While away, I decided to keep a mental list of the good, the bad and the so-so to share when I got back, so here it goes.The good - The Beach! One of the nicest beaches we've been to (compared to Cancun, Aruba, Monico, Jamaica, Myrtle Beach, Florida). The depth of the beach can't rival florida, but the sand was free of any rocks or shells and the water is a perfect color with perfect waves. Some of the resorts in Punta Cana had more beach erosion that caused a dramatic slope in the grade of the beach. Grand Paradise Bavaro's beach did not have this problem. Also, the GP had beach huts which were useful to avoid direct sunlight. Not all resorts had these or as many of them on their beaches (Tip: Get to the beach before 9am to get your hut).The other bright spot of the resort was the quality of the shows that they put on at night. The same dance crew put on different shows each night. The quality of the dancing was quite entertaining, even if the lip-synching took a little time to get used to.Finally, our kids (we had 3 families with a total of 8 kids ranging in age from 5-10), enjoyed the kids club. I attribute this mostly to the woman who runs the club. She is wonderful with the kids (Tip: There is a mini disco each night at 8:30 at the amphitheater adjacent to the main building. The kids enjoyed this).The bad - The service. I would say 1/2 the people were very nice and 1/2 the people were either disinterested or tired of tourists. Apart from the personalities of the staff, the resort itself did not seem to have the whole service concept figured out. I booked connecting rooms through a travel agent. Apparently I would have been better served calling the hotel directly to confirm the connecting room. It took a somewhat heated discussion with the manager to get the connecting room upon check in. Not a great start (Tip: try and book directly if you can. We found out that the hotel next door to us was nicer and would have been cheaper if we booked it directly. It isn't always easy to book directly with some hotels and I think this may be one of them, but check prices before going with a travel agent. There are a few middlemen involved that are all taking a cut which seems to boost your cost). Another service issue relates to clean towels. The bath towels were not always available in the morning (the made would tell us that she'd be back in the afternoon). The beach towel hut was open at 9am and seemed to sell out by 10am. After that, the person at the hut would just shake his head and say later when asked when clean beach towels would arrive. The service at the restaurants was also lacking. The main eateries at the resort are buffets (more on that in a bit). It seemed that the bus boys from the buffet served as waiters in the traditional sit down restaurants. If you ordered a drink, it may or may not show up. After asking 3 times, you are likely to finally get your thirst quenched. Now, more about the eateries. Breakfast and lunch are served at a few different buffets. Also, during a week's stay, you receive two vouchers to eat at a traditional restaurant with waiter service and a menu. The process for making a reservation at these restaurants was somewhere between painful and torture. There is one person taking reservations in person as everyone stands in line for their turn with this important woman (Tip: Give the excursion guy next to the woman taking reservations a ten spot and ask them to hook you up for the week). The line may have gone quicker if the woman wasn't also responsible for showing each potential patron the menus for each eatery. If a person was especially curious or high maintenance, the important reservation person may spend 10 minutes with one patron. When there are 40 people on a line to make reservations, you can imagine the agony of standing in a long line that doesn't move very often. (Tip: Ask the front desk for food vouchers and get yourself additional nights out of the buffet. The food gets very tiresome).The rooms were ample size but we stayed in the old section. This is closer to the beach but the rooms are dated. The rooms lack clocks or dressers for your clothes. The closet doors didn't open properly, the bathrooms were dated and the TVs are small, without remote controls (Tip: if you have small children, I suggest staying in the old section and being near the beach and food. If you are going without kids, you may want to take advantage of the newer rooms that offer more).The final bad relates to the pools. The pools were a bit cold, but more importantly, they were all the same depth (too deep for 5-10 year olds to stand in). The only alternative was the baby pool, which was not interesting to even a five year old. A pool with varying depths from 1.5 - 5 feet would have been a big improvement. Also, the jacuzzis were cold. We did go to the hotel next door to check it out and found that theirs were cold as well.The so-so: They have tennis courts, but only 4 of them and they filled up rather quickly. They have some good photographers on staff, but the packages are a bit pricey (TIp: They walk around with animals - Parrots, Monkeys, Lizards - for you to pose with. I would suggest accumulating a variety of pictures with the different animals or a variety of people you are traveling with and putting together a package. If you do it individually, you will spend $40 a clip. I suggest finding 7-9 good poses of a variety of people and asking them for a package of pictures on CD for $40. The pictures they print are not the customary size in the U.S., so if you get the CD, you can crop and print 5x7s or 8x10s when you get home).Final Tips: If you use a travel agent, use a reputable one and inquire whether they have a booth at the Punta Cana airport. Our travel agent used the local Next Tours travel agent. These local agents did not have a booth at the airport and finding our hotel transfer was almost impossible. Check when the rainy season is before booking as well. The rain there comes down pretty hard and potentially often. Prices are almost always negotiable - when booking excursions, buying jewelery (they brought in local vendors - the first price was probably 5 times too high), T shirts, hair braiding, etc. etc.I probably wouldn't go back primarily because I may be tired of the all inclusives. I just want to go to breakfast, sit down with my family and order food and a coffee. Like I said in the subject, the place grows on you. We enjoyed ourselves even with the faults. It's a beautiful beach with beautiful water, which is the main reason you go to an island.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2009

<Author>Gavinator
<Content>Ocean View Worth the Price To wake up in the morning and hear the sound of the waves crashing against the shore and the palm trees blowing in the wind, was PRICELESS!! To not have an ocean view room may mean that you will get a room further into the complex, and further away from the beach. There is a tram that operates 24 hours a day to take you from the beach deeper into the complex. It isn't a big deal, but we sure enjoyed the convenience and the view. Some key points: All the water used for cleaning, cooking, ice cubes and for drinks is purified. Each day a 4L jug of purified (and sealed) water is put in your room. Myself, my wife, and my three-year old son were never ill. We always managed to find something to eat at the buffet, either where we were at, or we ventured further into the complex, to try their buffet. When you arrive at the hotel you are given a couple of room keys (plastic cards) and two towel cards that you present at a hut on the beach and exchange on a daily basis. Once you put your towels down on a seat (to keep it), people respect your space and don't take or move them. Treat your towels like gold, 'cause if you lose your towels or those cards, they're $20USD per towel to replace. Another recommendation would be to take a bunch of $1USD bills to tip the bartenders, waiters, and cleaners. It is not required as it is an 'All inclusive' resort, but it is appreciated by the staff and the service will reflect this. If we go back to the Dominican, we will certainly return to the Paradise Grand Bavaro!!!

<Author>benes
<Content>Few things you need to know Planning to take your vacations at Grand Paradise Bavaro? We would like to help with our advice, as we have usually found other people's advice very helpful: Grand Paradise Bavaro is a 3 - 4 star hotel. We would give it a plus 4 for the room standard, although we heard that in other parts of the hotel the rooms were not as good as ours. The beach and the pools are excellent. Facilities are generally good. For us, there were two major problems: 1.The hygene was horrible. In the small bars near the pools and the beach they served drinks with plastic cups. These plastic cups were re-used. When the bar ran out of cups, one of the people working there ran around quickly and collected used plastic cups - in the sand, on the ground, everywhere. They were taken somewhere behind the bar and, voila, they appeared in a minute, nice and clean. I don't think there was hot water or any kind of chemicals to help disinfect them. Later we came to understand why so many people in the resort had brought mugs from home. Three out of four of us got sick with poisoning. (For the record, we have been in several other resorts, and we have got relatively strong stomachs.)2. However, the poisoning might have been from food, and not from the cups. The food was the second horror of the resort. Poor variety, and not very well cooked. Over circulated - food from previous lunch and dinner appearing next day. Except from the first day, there was no yogurt in any of the restaurants. There was very little variety of fruit. Sometimes, you couldn't even find bananas. And the choices in the buffet were very limited. At times we found it hard to convince the waiters to bring us water. It was easier to get beer, though. 3. Doctor's service was good. Unfortunately, we saw a lot of it. We wish you never have a chance to need it.

<Author>TOnutcase
<Content>Average if you have low expectations We just came back from Punta Cana on 12/26/2008. Overall impressions are as followsSkyservice : cannot blame the delay on Skyservice on the outgoing trip due to very bad weather condition. Return trip was right on time. In flight service is good. However, they will try to sell you everything from snack to bottle water.Reception: Check in and out are probably the worst experience anyone will come across staying at this Grd Paradise Resort. Front desk staffs are generally incompetent, and arrogant. It is due either to the language barrier or just plain incompetent. Note that there are two reception areas. if you are in the select area, your reception for checkin/out, safe key etc is near the gate. If you are in the beach section, your reception is is in the main lobby. If you ask anyone, they will tell you to go to the main lobby which could be frustrating.Room condition, maid services: very clean in the select area or club area. Maids were friendly and really to do their jobs well. Bring a box of Kleenex with you, the resort do not provide it. You are provided with 1 gallon of water and 4 bottles of soft drink daily free of charge. Anything else in the fridge will cost you a lot.Buffet restaurant: La Guana near the beach has more varieties than the club area. Overall the staffs are friendly, and attentive. It has different kinds of food for all kind of taste. Stay away from fresh vegetable like lettuce, etc. stuffs that requires washing. We were sick for five days at the resort and we were very careful not to drink tab water. The only things we could attribute to were the fresh vegetable and the water we drank at the restaurant. A la carte restaurant: Tried Michaelangelo, Asia and Manglar. It was all nice. Asia will cost you extra $US 10/pp.Beach restaurant: mostly fast food stuffs. It is not as clean as the others, but it is expected due to the beach location. Rest room in this restaurant is very dirty. Pool area, beach area: very good, very clean. Serving staffs are very friendly. The undertow at the beach is brutal. If you are with small children, be extremely careful with the undertow and the surf. There is a steep drop off right in front of the resort beach area.Shopping: everything on the resort is quite expensive. There is a small plaza right outside the resort where you can get things at less than half of the price the resort gift shop is charging you. Even at the plaza, you have to haggle to get a good price. I would assume you can get thing cheaper if you are going to the local area, but you have to pay for transportation to get there, and it will end up paying more. Shopping for Rum, and coffee at the airport is even more expensive than at the resort.I also noticed the tour operator LOOKEA at the resort. It is geared toward the French tourist. They provided a lot of activities at the pool and at the beach for the French. it looks like a lot of fun. The french section where the Lookea is located is the most lively of all. Sunquest has no such presence in this resort.Cell phone and internet access: It is cheaper to use in room phone for international call than using your cell phone. Cell phone signal is poor and is working on and off. Internet access is pitifully slow and is only available in the main lobby area. It will cost you $US 8.00/hour. Once it starts, you will likely loose the remaining time eventhough you LOGOUT as instructed. What it normally take you 10 minutes to do using standard US and Canadian Internet, it will take you close to an hour or more to do here.Overall experience has been average. The reception and counter staffs spoiled the goodwork that everyone else were trying to make this place good and enjoyable. I have seen training sessions that management were providing to the serving staffs, and inspection sessions for the cleaning of the rooms. They were quite rigorous. I just cannot understand why the same standard were not applied to the reception and counter staffs. You will remember the bad experiences going in and out more than the good experiences in the middle. If you want to pay for an AIl inclusive package and just want to have a clean place to stay with plenty of food to eat, do not ask any question, with nothing to do except going to the pool and the beach then this is not a bad place. However, if you need better internet service, your questions answered correctly, more professional and efficient staffs like Holiday Inn in North America, then be prepared to pay a little more and stay at the higher star rating like the RIU or Majestic (next door). I would if I am doing it all over again.

<Author>Penelope1970
<Content>No worries!!! My 20 year old son and myself traveled with Sunwing to this hotel and are hard-pressed to find anything to complain about.My motto is, *travel cheap, *keep your expectations low *appreciate the basics (being in a tropical climate with all the drinks and food at your disposal)and you will never be disappointed.This is a solid 4 star. I have traveled to many places, some all inclusive, some not and I was completely satisfied with this resort and their services.I've been to Cuba several times and the D.R. twice before this and I may never go back to Cuba after seeing the beaches of Punta Cana and reliving how outgoing the people are.The most important thing to know about this resort is that there is a Club section and you probably don't want to be in it. It's not that it is inferior in services or anything, it's just too far set away from the main action...ie; the beach. Yes the train/trolley takes you around but it suck if you just want to make a quick trip to your room for that forgotten item.Rooms: We stayed in building 5 and got positioned close to the beach as we had asked. The rooms are fine, tiled, clean enough, the beds aren't very comfortable but I haven't been to a resort that had great mattresses anywhere. The air conditioning was very effective (so much so that I had to turn it off/down several times). No the maid does not change your sheets everyday but who the hell does change their sheets everyday?The only thing I would say negative about the rooms is that they are noisy. If you're a light sleeper you may want to ask for a room on an upper floor to avoid all the traffic of people.Service:If I hear about one more person on here complaining about the service they received at a BUFFET I'm going to scream. Man, it's a buffet with 100 people around you and if you don't get your beer or water brought to you until you are half done eating, track someone down and politely ask for it before you grab your food, problem solved. And if there's no silverware on the table you chose take it off another table. In estimation there is about 25 people for every buffet server there, I think they did a fabulous job keeping up.Service at the pool bar was different. The bartenders were ok but they had no cuing system in place so if you are the polite english/french speaking I'll wait my turn type (which I am), you may get very thirsty. Instead of subjecting myself to the frustration, I picked up my thermal mug (which not only saves extra trips to the bar,but also conserves the environment), and headed to the beach bar instead where people lined up politely for their turn and never had a problem after.Tours: If you book through your rep you can pay with a credit card.Dune Buggie: Loved it! This is so much fun if you like/don't mind getting dirty. $69 USD but you have to be 2 in the buggy otherwise the single price was around $89USD. Make sure to bring/wear your bathing suit for the stop at Macao beach and eat before you go cuz there's no food on this one.Marinararium: $89USD Lots of fun. the staff is super energetic and get everyone involved. Swimming with the sharks and stingrays is something that I will never forget. We got a real windy day which made visibility poor but there was not mistaking the sharks or stingrays.Jeep Safari: Great day, lots of drinking if you want, lots of great local info. Be prepared though it's a good 7 hours or so. $79USD. Go to the dollar store before you leave and bring a bag of school supplies for the stop at the elementary school. If you discretely give it to the teacher he'll ensure fair distribution to the kids that need it most.Shopping: If you intend to buy local things when you are there you can trade stuff from home. Things to bring that they will like:1-DUCT TAPE, I got 10 good vanilla cigars(value $20USD) for a good roll of duct tape,a $1 baby blanket that I bought at the dollarama and some new women's summer sandals shoes that I had never worn.2-mp3 players of the cheapest variety here (I had one that I payed 35 dollars for and was told that they cannot buy them for under 100USD locally. Just remember to load it up with music and bring the charger and accessories.3-children's clothing. If you watch for end of season sales at a walmart or something you could trade very well. I wouldn't attempt to trade used clothing, but you never know.4-I found a pair of children's shoes that light up on sale for 5 dollars and ended up with a bottle of rum and some more cigars for it.Bring USD. I calculated what it would have cost to take canadian and transfer it to pesos when there vs converting the Canadian to US at my bank and then converting the US to pesos while there and you came out ahead converting to US before leaving. That said, offer the vendor Canadian money first, many shops I went to named there price and then said Canadian, US, whatever so keep some canadian currency handy as well. You never have to use a peso the entire time you're there if you have USD.The Beach: Amazing. Very windy all the time.Bring a watch, there are no clocks anywhere on this resort.

We stayed in the Select section which is in the middle of the resort and is the newest part. I must admit the SELECT front lobby was a little disapointing compared to the other resorts we had dropped people off at, but we were never there so that was okay. Our room was clean, we had 2 double beds, flat screen t.v, nice washroom. It was more than adequate. We were in building 9 facing the pool. We had everything we needed. The room was clean , the pools were big and never crowded, the beach is AMAZING. BUT there is not a resort along that stretch of the beach who cannot brag about the Beach. Bavaro is a special place. There was lots of food though it was not always the best ( not bad just not great) It lacked a good salad bar, more fish and more fruit . I have been to resorts with better food. But I always found something to eat so that was no problem. The bread is amazing. The drinks were plentiful. The staff at the resort were really nice and were helpful. We are good tippers so I think that really helped. Remember these people make very little money so tipping them is a huge deal. It also helped our service. There is a trolly running throughout the resort. It is always going so that was easy to take. We walked a lot and never seemed to mind doing that. The walk was 5 mins at most. After all the food and booze it was welcomed. All in all for $616 taxes in. I cannot complain. Our group had a great time and enjoyed our week away from the snow. The cold sure hit us as we landed in Toronto late in the morning. It has not stopped snowing since we got home. I miss Punta Cana.So if you booked this resort. Enjoy.Katie

<Author>laneburyta
<Content>Amazing Resort, Friend staff and people We travel to the Grand Paradise Bavaro on November 22 for 2 weeks and returned on December 6. There were 8 people in our party and everyone had a great time with no complaints. There were 2 women and 7 guys, and our ages range from 25 to 35. And yes, we have been to other 3, 4, and 5 star resorts, so we do have something to compare it to. We stayed in the beach section of the resort. We arrived late and were greeted with a friendly and very helpful front desk. We were originally in build 5 on the 3rd floor, and the room was great, not a problem with it. We did ask to be changed to a ground floor room as we preferred not to have to walk up the stairs everyday. Our room was changed the following day without any problems and we were in building 3 now on the ground floor, Room 3105. It was a great room, AC was cold enough, the fridge worked great and hot showers all the time. Our maid was perfect and always did a great job on cleaning our room and restock our mini fridge when needed. The food was excellent. We ate dinner at the buffet every night as we seen no need to go to an ala carte. There was a good selection of food available at the buffet, including meats, veggies, potatos, a pasta station, pizza, soups, and others. Several of our group did go to ala cartes during the second week and they seem to really enjoy them also. For lunch we mainly ate at the beach Grille, which was great. Quick foods, like pasta, pizza, french fries, chicken, hot dogs, hamburgers, salads, and deli meats were all available. As for breakfast, I can't really comment as I never made it to breakfast enought times, but the 2 times I did go, I enjoyed the pancakes and french toast. As for late night snacks, the beach grille serves the same stuff they do during the day, at night after the ala carte closes there and remains open till about 2am. You can also get popcorn in the 24hr/sports bar and ham and cheese sandwiches if you ask the friendly bartenders.As for the bars and bartenders. They were all really friendly and trying there best to serve all the people there as quickly as possible. I am pretty sure we visited every bar there and always got are drink made with a friendly smile. The boat bar is a nice little touch and we always went there after dinner for a cold corona or MGD (only 3 bucks) and together with all our friends that we brought with us and met down there to get ready for the night.The disco and sports bar along with the beach bar/grille was were most of the fun would take place at night. The disco would play pretty much and song that you would request and was pretty busy most nights. The 24hr/sports bar had 3 fooseball tables, 2 pool tables and 2 plasma screen to enjoy to RR away from your vacation. The beach bar/grille was a great place to go and enjoy a late night drink and sit in a quiet enviroment.As for the walk between the beach section and the Club section. It honestly only would take like 5 minutes to walk it if you missed the train. And I am sure a little walking might be good for you on vacation anyways. The train runs constantly up to 2am and if you ride it from the one end of the resort (the french section) to the far end of the beach section (stops at the beach grille), it takes 15 minutes to do the round trip. So only 7 minutes one way, and like I said you can walk it in that time.The beach and ocean really doesn't need to be commented on, as they are absolutely beautiful. So I will leave it at that. The pools, yes there is 4 pools (2 at the beach, 1 at the club, 1 at the french section), and they are great. They are cleaned every night along with all the jacuzzi and kids pools. There are plenty of room around the pools to soak up the sun and the pools are large enough to play around in.We all do believe that a vacation is what you make it, and we go prepared to have fun and try to even put smiles on other vacationers faces. Yes if you were there during the time we were, we were the ones with the hockey helmet toques, mullets wigs, 60 inch beach ball, santa and elf suits, and a few other things. We sure did enjoy ourselves and hope that everybody else did too.If you have any questions or would like to see some pictures of the resort, feel free to contact me atlane_buryta@hotmail.comand I will do my best to answer any questions you have.

<Author>louella_8
<Content>Impeccable service and beautiful beach We just returned from a fabulous week at the Grand Paradise Bavaro. We stayed in rooms 9137 and 9139, which was an ideal central location. Even though we could have taken the little trolley back and forth to the buffet and beach (as the stop was directly outside the 9000 block of rooms), we almost always walked, as the walk was so pleasant and we enjoyed the inevitable encounters with a few friendly staff along the way. We found the service to be a wonderful combination of warmth, friendly, and professional. The employees certainly work very hard. The maid service was excellent; the rooms were very clean Within a few days, the waiters knew that we would likely order a Presidente beer at lunch, and that we liked our coffee with brandy at night. We barely had to ask, once we had been seated. It seems to me that this kind of special treatment and care is given to everyone. The beach is amazing. Fantastic for swimming. We had our own snorkels, but there is no snorkeling to be had at this beach. So we relaxed, read, and swam. Wonderful. The girls went para-sailing, and thoroughly enjoyed it ($85 for 2 people for 10 minutes). They thought it was definitely worth the money. We all went on the Outback Safari day trip ($90 a person; it is better to pay cash, but we couldn't, so the VISA gets charged in euros, ouch). We had an extraordinary guide, who gave us a lot of valuable history, and insight into the culture and economy. It was very sad to see the throngs of mostly illegal Haitian hopefuls waiting for work, at one point along the way. As my husband and I are teachers, we were a little disappointed that we couldn't actually visit the school, but it totally makes sense that that would be quite disruptive to their learning. We were able to just leave the clothes and pencils with the Outback guide, which is best for the distribution process amongst their 8 schools. I bought a few things along the way, like coconut oil and vanilla and coffee...I thought I was supporting the local grower, but I realized later that it was way over-priced compared to what the beach and resort vendors will sell it to you for. Be wary of that. The last stop of the day was at Macaa Beach for boogie-boarding; that was so much fun because it is a completely undeveloped beach with big waves. A blast!  The food was fantastic. Buffets were great. We had 3 a la cartes, and enjoyed them all. The chicken, the pasta, and the fruit was consistently excellent, but we tried to sample as much variety of food as we could.  We saw one very good show in the evening, but found that there wasn't a lot going on otherwise that interested us at night. That was fine though, as we lingered long over our meals, and liked to get up early for a full day in the sun, so the night life wasn't the big attraction for us anyways.Tips: a) My bank teller told me to take 50 one-dollar bills, to tip. I am so glad we had those, as we used them all, and it was important to do. Although quite honestly, whether we tipped or not made no difference to the excellent service that we received.b) Women should have a two-piece bathing suit; no one wears a one-peice no matter how their body is shaped or how old they are. A two piece in that kind of heat just makes way more sense. c) Take duct-tape to seal any bottles that you buy (i.e. coconut oil, vanilla, etc). The seals are not good (typical, I believe, for developing countries)d) The girls wished they had a watch, as they never knew how long they were sleeping in. They only made it up for 2 breakfasts!e) Best to carry $US cash including for the excursions.f) The market just outside of the resort is full of very aggressive vendors, so if your stomach doesn't like that, stay away. That was the only unpleasant part of our holiday, which I wouldn't do again (even a half hour was too much)g) For the maid, I had taken zip-lock bags, with a prepared note saying Este regalo es para la camarera that I put in the bag each day, along with a tip, a Canadian souvenir, and some perfumed products. That was a lot of fun for me to do, and I especially appreciated meeting and talking with Brigid, our maid, (with my handy Spanish-English dictionary always with me). None of us in our party could speak Spanish, but it was important for us to try to communicate in Spanish with her and the other employees.h) They tell us that the pure coconut oil provides the best tan and is best for the skin. Easily accessible there.i) We had brought a few Canadian hats, deck of cards, etc. that we gave to some special servers near the end of our stay. We were really glad to have those to give away. One server (Juan) pulled out a Canadian watch, key chain, pen, lanyard, and lapel pins, and proudly showed them to us. It appears they love the Canadians, and that the Canadians love them. j) We had brought four big bags of cheezies, chips, etc, with us, because we heard that the mini-bar was really expensive. We were glad to have those for that little bed-time snack. We would have been fine without them too. We didn't touch the mini-bar though. I would not hesitate to stay at this resort again, though I think there is much to experience in the world, and am not inclined to return to any holiday destination twice. I learned not to ask other holidayers what they thought of the resort, as they tend to just compare this and that and this and that with their other resort experiences. To me, those kind of comparisons serve no valuable purpose. I think being in any resort is a privileged experience, and worth enjoying fully just for what it is in the moment that you are in it. My travel agent said before we left Go with a sense of humor...you are in a developing country. Its good advice. We loved our holiday at the Grand Paradise Bavaro.

<Rating>1	1	2	1	1	1	1	1	

<Author>TorontoStefan
<Content>Self Serve resort Grand Paradise Bavaro DR versus Breezes Jibacoa in CubaThe roads are in very bad shape, lots of large pot holes. Very large coach bus with AC drove slowly over the holes so we were in comfort. Lots of people driving motorcycles or even motor cross bikes, which in Canada would not even be allowed on the roads. Very few motor cycles have license plates, and no one drives with a helmet. Interesting to see.Service: Jibacoa has great service in the buffet, but Grand Paradise has a problem with service. In the buffet restaurants there are servers for the entire restaurant that remove dirty dishes and bring you drinks. The food you get yourself. One time at breakfast the 6 of us went for the buffet three times, each time getting a new plate. This is all normal. What is not normal is to find no one taking away the dirty plates from our table even though dozens of servers walk past our table while we were eating. A pile of dirty dishes only attracts more flies, which most people consider a problem in any resort. What is even more shocking is that no one even offers us coffee, tea or juice. Time and time again I see servers setting up the cutlery for a 4 person table, only to find three coffee spoons, or only 3 wine glasses. Generally all the knives and forks for all 4 people are set. On another occasion some of us wanted hot water for a tea instead of coffee. We already had cups and saucers, and the tea bag was in the cup waiting for the hot water. After several minutes we hailed down another server to ask for hot water. Minutes later still no hot water so a third server was flagged and a request was made. Each time the servers were very friendly saying sure, right away, no problem but each time still no hot water. On another occasion in an a-la-Carte restaurant we were asked if we wanted anything more, after finishing off dinner and wine. We all requested more wine. 5 minutes went by, and still no wine, but we did get offered desert. In the end we never did get more wine and left. Generally speaking its a place that really is self serve. At Jibacoa servers are responsible only for a few tables, not the entire restaurant. They observe the guests and when you leave the table to get more food, they clear off your old plate. They would ask you if you want more to drink when they see your glass empty. Food: At Grand Paradise I would say is so so. Most of the a-la-Carte restaurants were closed with only 2 opened (low time of the season and they can do repairs to them now). The buffet in the section we stayed was closed so we had to walk 15 minutes, or take the train, to the other half of the resort farther from the beach to eat, or eat at the beach buffet with a much reduced selection. The beach buffet had no eggs, and oat meal only one day. The main buffet that was opened does have a good selection of eggs, tailored made, or you can get pre made scrambled eggs. The juice selection I did not like. Grand Paradise has lots of refrigerated drink dispensers, and it all seemed like cool-aid or some other man made drink, and not freshly squeezed, real fruit juice. Jibacoa has fresh juice, or at least it tasted that way. Grand Paradise fruit selection was limited compared to Jibacoa. The water melon, cantaloupe didn't taste any different then what we buy local. The pine apple and mango however were very sweet and juicy, but don't try to find mango or pineapple juice. I can't even believe they didn't have coconuts to eat. At Jibacoa they had a Cuban day where they cut a small opening in a fresh coconut, filled it with rum, and gave it to us. Then when we finished drinking, they would open up the coconut and dig out the coconut pulp for you. Nothing like that at Grand Paradise. In fact when we took a day trip to Saona Island for $85 they offered us coconuts, but also asked us$2.Night show: Jibacoa had simpler shows with less frills and glitter. Grand Paradise had one hour long shows with many elaborate costume changes. The stage was also much more elaborate. At Jibacoa the announcer spoke primarily English, while at Grand Paradise they spoke Spanish, French German and English which also added to the length of the show.Water: Both places have nice clean pools. Jibacoa is an adult only resort so there are no kiddy pools like at Grand Paradise. As for the ocean, Jibacoa is amazing for snorkeling since the rock, coral and fish are only a few meters from shore. Grand Paradise shares a small section of miles of white sandy beach with the 50 or so other resorts. No rock, no coral, no grass or vegetation therefore no fish or other wildlife. You have to pay someone to take you out in a boat for snorkeling or scuba diving. Jibacoa will give certified divers (bring your card) one free dive during their one week stay. No free diving at Grand Paradise.Room: Both places had nice functional rooms. Won't comment on decoration since its not important, as long as its clean and everything is in good working order. Jibacoa did have a TV that wasn't very good. Had to hit it to receive channels. Grand Paradise had a flat screen TV, but I think only on the 2nd and 3rd floor. The first floor rooms seemed to have the older style TV's. Both places had working AC units although at Grand Paradise the room has no power when you are not there as your room key is also used to turn on the power, lights and AC. Jibacoa has one industrial sized AC unit at one end of the building complex and only a quiet fan in the room, while Grand Paradise seemed to have AC units in each room above the washroom ceiling. The one in my room happened to leak so the washroom floor was wet, and when you sat down on the toilet you also got dripped on. Out of three rooms used by our group mine was the only one with a drippy AC unit. The clock radio at Grand Paradise was hard wired into the wall so you could not connected to a working outlet. Remember the power is off when you leave the room, so it loses its time setting every day. Battery chargers for your camera or cell phone also do not function with no power during the day.Tips: Breezes Jibacoa does not expect or accepts tips. Some people did give tips, but as secretly as possible. All of Dominican Republic loves tips. We did not tip anyone there since no one really deserved it. At Jibacoa I tipped a few people for their outstanding service, including the tennis coach who gave me a band aid after I fell on the court.Activities: September is the low season so getting a tennis court or catamaran shouldn't be a problem and at Breezes Jibacoa it wasn't. At Grand Paradise you had to reserve everything. At 10 am I wanted to take out a catamaran, but they said first reservation available is at 12 noon. I can see in their books that no one has reserved, and the catamaran is sitting on the beach waiting for someone to sail it. Grand Paradise had Tennis with a pro at 4pm, but unless you actually reserved that time slot, there won't be a pro at the tennis court when you show up at 4pm.Checking out: In Cuba's Breezes Jibacoa we got a phone call in our room the day we were to check out asking if we need a porter to transport our luggage to the front desk. We never got such a phone call at Grand Paradise.If you go to Grand Paradise expecting to be served hand and foot, then you will be very disappointed. If you go there knowing that you really need to get things yourself, and not count on them to get it, even if they ask you, or you ask them, then the resort is great. Really one goes for the sun, beach, ocean, pools, and decent food and drinks, and that is what we got. We know of and heard of many people that are repeat customers of Jibacoa. They even have a special repeat customer party during the week. I have not heard of anyone that is a repeat guest at Grand Paradise, but did hear a few that said they were there in the past, but also won't go back Right next door to Grand Paradise is the Majestic Colonial. Every one I talked to say its really great, they serve you hand and foot to your every need and desire. The bus from the airport to the resort actually stopped at Majestic to drop off some guests. We saw how the porters were carrying peoples luggage, and someone else walked around with a tray of hot towels to freshen your self up. No one did that at Grand Paradise. We paid around $600 for Grand Paradise while Majestic is around $1000. But price isn't everything. The problem with Grand Paradise is management and the way people work. It doesn't cost any more to get people to actually do what they should be doing in the first place. When you ask for hot water you expect to get it in a reasonable time. There are other places for the same price that actually do provide service.

<Author>WirralAnna
<Content>Not a 4* but a good 3*... still a great holiday We were worried about staying at the Grand Paradise after reading some of the reviews but I have to say that generally we were pleasantly surprised. Both my boyfriend and I aren't complaining types so I'd like to think that you could take this review as you read it. 1. Check in : Absolutely fine. The flight was fine, the transfer to the hotel was fine. We waited about 10 minutes to check in and we had a drink provided for us. The check in staff were very friendly, professional and helpful. Alex, who checked us in, spoke very good English. We were given a remote for the TV and we paid $20 for the safe for 2 weeks. We were only given one room key but we didn't ask for 2 so no complaints there.The bellboy took our luggage and we were given a ride on one of the golf buggies to our room straight away. We tipped the bellboy $1 but he didn't seem to be waiting for a tip and he was grateful. 2. The room : Very nice. We were staying in block 9 which seemed pretty new. The room had 2 king size beds, both of which had decent mattresses (although one was slightly better than the other). There was a flat screen TV which worked perfectly, could receive all the channels. The bathroom was spotless, shower bath and wc. We had complimentary soaps and shampoos left although we didn't use them. 3. The maid service : Good. We agreed we would tip the maid $1 a day. The first day we left the dollar we came back to a towel folded into a heart shape with flowers on the top, an extra room key (so the air con would stay on all the time), as well as all new towels plus 2 extra ones. We felt slightly guilty that we'd only left a dollar but we were on a tight budget and only tipped $1 again the next day. When we came back to our room it was cleaned well but the extra room key had gone and there were no towels folded into pretty shapes. The air con was efficient enough to cool the room down within about 10 minutes when it was on anyway so we didn't require an extra room key. I guess if we'd tipped $5 the next day we would've kept the key but it wasn't really important to us. 4. The mini bar: EXPENSIVE. Within the all inclusive package you get a gallon of water (replenished whenever you finish it - every day if you drink it all) and 4 bottles of pop, which I think is plenty. We did eat quite a few snacks from the mini bar on a couple of days when I was unwell and we couldn't face walking to the buffet for breakfast or lunch. The price list is provided and it is expensive but we thought we knew what we were letting ourselves in for. I put aside money each time we ate something from the mini bar (and I was rounding up as well e.g. we had 2 chocolate bars totalling $7, so I put away $10. The following day a bill for what you've consumed is put in your room with the service charge added on and the total in dollars. Be prepared though when you check out they give you the bill for anything charged to the room and from the mini bar in pesos. They can only provide a breakdown in pesos. But when you pay for anything in cash at the resort they prefer dollars. If you want to settle in dollars (as we did) they then convert the pesos to dollars at their exchange rate and you end up getting fleeced. It is also impossible to tell if you've been correctly billed unless you want to ask for a breakdown, go and sit down and convert pesos to dollars for each day and then attribute it to what you ate. Also - one day we were charged for some peanuts ($11) but I am seriously allergic to peanuts and there is no way I had eaten them. We spoke to the rep about it and when we checked out they did take it off the bill. My advice - just stay within your all inclusive allowance. The mini bar is my major gripe by the way :)5. The beach: Gorgeous. The beach is beautiful. White sand, crystal clear waters. The beach is always very clean too. There is a lovely old guy who goes around collecting the glasses and he always smiles at you. I did feel a bit sorry for him but he was always smiling. The water can be a bit choppy, probably too much for young children but fine for adults. The sea is clean and there's no debris. The beach isn't stoney either which is nice. While we were there it was low season so there was no problem getting a sun lounger, even in the shade (as long as you don't mind sitting under a tree if all the umbrella things are taken - which we didn't). I can imagine it's hard to find somewhere in high season though.6. The pools: Very good. Both pools are very clean and nice. No problems with either. The swim up bar at one of the pools is great and Luis the barman was lovely. 7. The service: Okay. The service could be a little hit and miss but I cannot fault the staff. They were tirelessly, you never see anyone standing around. They always seem cheery and smile at you and remember you although sometimes you can be waiting a while for a drink. I think it's because the place is so big and could probably do with some more staff. At the buffet if both of you get up to get food at the same time and take a while you will probably find your table gone by the time you get back. We just took it in turns though so it wasn't a problem. Again I wouldn't like to go during high season as I imagine it's baaaaad. 8. The staff: Wonderful. They are brilliant. Some of the waiters really are funny and / or very attentive. Nestor who works in the La Palma buffet was an excellent waiter and he was gorgeous too haha. Kelvin who we saw working in the Italian was very funny - a real character. The animation team work very hard and are genuinely lovely. I went with my boyfriend but I still got a lot of attention from the male workers and I'm not anything special but they do like blonde women. I imagine single ladies would get aboslutely hounded, it was just a laugh cos I was there with my other half. 9. The food: Okay. I'm not a fussy eater but I did get bored of the food. Even though they have themed nights the stuff always seemed to be the same. Most of the food is okay although some of the stuff tasted funny. I didn't eat any seafood cos I was worried about getting food poisoning. We did have dodgy stomachs on 2 occasions but I do have a weak stomach. There are a lot of flies in the buffet but they can't do anything about that. We only tried the Italian è„Œ la carte but it was very nice. Sadly one of the dodgy stomach incidents came after eating a not very hot lasagne there but I would still thoroughly recommend it. I expected at least one dodgy stomach whilst going to the DR though!10. The drinks: Good. The cocktails are nice if a bit of on the sweet side. You do only get a small plastic cup so take a travel mug if that bothers you. The beer is really nice and I don't like beer (I only like bud anyway). The measures are big and I can't say I thought anything was watered down. Mama Juana is very nice - you must try it!11. The disco: Awful - but bearable if you get drunk. You can request music but we didn't bother. There were a group of young Canadians staying there and when they were at the disco the music was good. The toilets were awful but no worse than a bar in Liverpool city centre so who cares?12. The other guests: Not overly friendly. I'm English and we only met one other English couple there. There were a lot of Canadians and lot of Europeans. I'd like to go to a resort where more people from the UK go to next time.13. The Entertainment: Good. The shows are good, the dance troupe are really good. It sometimes gets a bit tedious when the compere of the evening announced everything in 3 different languages but it is an international place and they make everything accesible to everyone. A few other things: I didn't experience anywhere near as many problems as some people seem to have. I've been totally honest and moaned about anything worth moaning about. The DR is a 3rd world country, the hotels are paradise compared to how the Domincans live so don't expect everything to be perfect. The staff are lovely and I had no problem with their English. They really appreciate any attempt at you speaking Spanish but they can all speak most languages. We didn't pay a lot for our holiday so we didn't go expecting the world. I wouldn't say the hotel is a 4* but it is a good 3*. If you want excellent service then you have to pay higher prices. I would love to go back to the DR but I'd probably stay at a different resort. I chose the Grand Paradise because we were on a budget. If you've booked here don't be frightened off by bad reviews, go with an open mind and an open heart and you'll have a wonderful time.

<Content>Amazing Hotel - Stop complaining! After reading all the negative reviews on this hotel last year, I regretted booking here. But it was too late as I had already booked. I donéˆ¥æª› remember in detail what I ate, all I know is that I had amazing food every night. Bear in mind that I am from Montreal where the food is really good. Don't forget that the entertainers are up early in the morning and organize several activities through out the day. You can snorkel at the far left of the beach near the water sport rope, but there isn't much to see. If you walk further right and pass a couple of hotels, there's some better snorkeling, but nothing amazing, don't expect to see Great Barrier Reef quality fish.People:The guests were a mix of Europeans (french, german, spanish, italian) and North Americans. Note to single men: The Spanish women are incredibly hot. Learn a few words in Spanish and go talk to them. If you get lucky, you owe me a drink. Note to women: The entertainers will most likely hit on you. They are harmless, just don't give them any attention and they will move on to their next prey. Room:I don't remember what my room looked like. I was only there to sleep, shower and use the toilet. Once I had the runs and... never mind, I won't go into details. All you have to know is that the plumbing works great!Some people are frustrated with their personal and professional lives. They actually like going on vacation and complaining about everything. So they tell of the staff so they can feel superior and perhaps for once in their life they feel in control. Just go and enjoy your stay. Eat, drink, swim, tan, dance and leave your worries behind.

<Author>Suzi-Q_08
<Content>Ladies Beware! Some of the Dominican men at this resort are real players. What do I mean by that? They sweet talk the ladies and pile on the flattery. Sound harmless enough you may say? Not really. It's a game to seduce unassuming tourists in an attempt to extort money. First of all, the resort employees are not allowed to fraternize with the resort guests. The ones who do run the risk of getting fired, but they don't care because they're after the big easy. Watch out for the guys on the animation team....easy to spot....they are the workers with the orange shirts on who are in charge of beach activities and nightly shows. The waiters are not much better...particularly at the La Laguna buffet restaurant. If you want to know names....email me personally and I'll tell you. But to put it simply...if an employee asks you if you are married/single/have a boyfriend..they are on the play . The hard working, honest employees never get personal! The players however will ask you for your room number....a big no no!!!! They will also ask for email and cell phone numbers....don't give that info out! You can spot these guys walking around with their cell phones checking to see which poor girls have called them. They make about $6 US per day and have cell phones...laughable!!! Once you spot one, you see them all! You may want to google the word Sanky. It will better explain how these guys operate...because that's what they are called....sankies! In short ladies...keep your guard up. If a man knows you only a day or two and tells you that he loves you ..that's a big red flag. You wouldn't fall for that foolishness at home so why fall for it on vacation. If you want to hook up with anyone, go with another tourist. Stay clear of all Dominican men...locals and resort employees because most of them see you as their next meal ticket. One more thing....do not leave the resort at night and don't go to the beach at night...either alone or with others, it's not safe!Now about the rest of the resort....This resort was fairly decent and clean, but no frills. The entertainment was good sometimes and tacky other times. The buffet restaurants were good...lots of variety. I didn't eat at the a la carte places but the only one I heard was decent was the Italian one. The beach is beautiful and the pools are lovely. The service was a bit all over the place....good sometimes, but lacking from time to time. A word of advice...go to the buffet restaurants early for breakfast, lunch and dinner. As the hours go on, it gets crowded and the service goes down hill from there. Go to this place only if you get a really, really good deal. If you're looking for a posh resort, pick another one. Like I said, it's no frills. I don't think it really is a 4 star place...more of a 3 or 3.5 star at best.Hope this helps...email me for more details if you like.:-)

<Author>rdajabo
<Content>Great Vacations, Great People It's a shame that most of the people who take the time to write a review about this resort are those who were not happy with their stay. The average cost for this all-inclusive hotel is less than any overnight stay at a Motel 8 in the USA, so I truly don't know what they expected. Everything far exceeded our expectations, even if we had paid $100 per person per day, which neither us nor anyone else certainly did not. The facilities are beautiful and enormous and well kept, the ac could be a little cooler but we slept well at night. Our fridge was always stocked with water and sodas. There was a stocked coffee maker in the room and a working iron with its board. TV was a 32 inches plasma. The room was serviced every day.We were a party of 8 people (16 to 47 years old) and had a wonderful 5-day stay at Grand Paradise. The beach and the settings are gorgeous like everybody else agree, and the food was great. I was the only one who got sick but it was out of my own gluttony. Many people eat too much, get sick and, understanbly, speak lousy of their stay here, but I think it's not fair to blame the hotel or the staff.The staff is very professional and friendly. Christian Cuevas at the lobby, our maid Marcela Alvarado, Yoralaisa, don Alberto, Juan, they all were very nice to us. Fun is non-stop for those who look for it. The quality of the Las Vegas-sort-of show at the amphitheater is sound for the size. Food was great. The two buffets (we preferred La Laguna and you might as well stick eating there rather than trying reservation restaurants) offered plenty of options to eat. The meat might not be done to the American taste. All restaurants look great and their staff is always willing to help. Most of them are multi-linguals, so communication should not be an issue. Tip these folks as you would at any restaurant. They deserve it. There are shows at the beach and dance classes. We also sailed on sail boats and kayaks. One note for management: Set up an emergency crew at the beach. My daughter, who can't swim, and a friend got on a kayak and sailed away into the sea and did not know how to come back. Fortunately a gentleman from Australia saw them in distress and rescued them. This resort is well worth your money and then some. We also stayed 5 days at Barcelo Golf but overall our time here was much better. I would recommend it.

<Author>joaoYreina
<Content>Not bad for the price... My wife and I stayed at Grand Paradise Bavaro Jun. 26 to July 3. Overall it was a very good trip. First room was a bit funky, in Building 3. It had a moldy smell and and the bathroom was falling apart and there was no view to speak of. The toilet didn't flush but I fixed it. We complained at Reception and were given a new room in Building 6 with a king bed and a clean bathroom and a view of the pool and the ocean. The rooms are functional but not fancy. They all seem to need a bit of work. But it was fine, AC worked, shower was fine. The TV got a ton of channels in Spanish, English, French, Portuguese, Italian and German(ask for remate at reception). I noticed some people mentioned in the reviews that there were no face clothes, but our room had them. The maid worked very hard, you really should tip these ladies. All the staff at the resort are very hard workers. You can hear everything going on outside, drunk people yelling, people next door gettin' some. The resaturants were all good. But I can see why typical Americans would not like the food. The Buffet didn't have hamburgers, pizza or fried chicken fingers. They did, however, have the best red beans and rice, tropical veggies like yuca, tayote and green plantains, and tropical fruits like chinola. Lots of meats and seafood as well. Great coffee. Ate at two A la cartes, Taino (dominican) and Michaelangelo's (Italian). The Italian was ok, nothing special at all. The Domican place was one of the best restaurants I've eaten at in a long time. Amazing cream of Yuca soup, delicious Chicken stuffed with ripe plantain. At the buffet I often had to get up and get my own drink at the bar, or find my own clean silverware, but that didn't really bother me considering that we paid $550 each (including air) for 7 nights. Everyone works so hard, many live at the resort and work for 10 days straight then get three days off so they can travel back to their towns and be with their families.The beach was really nice. Impossible to get a palapa unless you get up before dawn. There are many palm trees you can sit under though. The sand is white and the water warn and clear. It gets rough toward the end of the afternoon. Overall, we were very satisfied with the resort considering what we paid. We are both Spanish-speakers too, so we didn't have any communication problems. I think that it's true that many of the staff had limited proficiency in English. The other guests were a mix of Spaniards, French, Canadians, other Europeans and a few other Americans. Everyone was nice except for the Gift shop ladies.

Nice variety from day to day (different theme every night).A la carte restaurants: Asian and grill were closed during our stay. We went to Italian (very good), International (good) and Dominican (average).BEACH: The highlight of the resort. VERY nice beach, white sand, turquoise water, palm trees on the beach, very large, lots of loungers. It was always possible to find shadow but palapas were impossible to get. If you want to do snorkeling, there is a small section with coral at the left of the swim section, where we saw many different kinds of fish.SERVICE: We had a very good service. Employees were always smiling and singing, whether you gave tip or not.There are, however, a couple of things that could be changed:- It is impossible to get change to tip employees at the reception. There is no bank on the site and the lobby and the gift shop never have small cuts for pesos or American money. We had to get change in the a la carte restaurants...- There was no ice cream on the main site, which was disappointing considering the very hot temperature!- The music was not so good: sometimes, in the afternoon, they played Eric Clapton, Dido, Bon Jovi...- Once again, the toilets issue could be taken care of... New pipes please!!!We had a very nice trip at Grand Paradise Bavaro and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it. Go with an open mind and enjoy, don't forget: you're on vacation! Have a good trip!

<Author>WhensMyNextVacation
<Content>Nice resort, beautiful beach......but nothing's perfect! We (husband and I) vacationed in Punta Cana from May 27 to June 3. Airport Check from Pearson Inernational (Toronto):Got a last minute deal with Sunwing (for an unbelieveable price). I have to say this was the easiest travel experience I've ever had. At the airport check-in there were 2 people ahead of us in line....went extremely quickly....then left and had some breakfast......boarding, we were provided with plastic bags for any liquid items in the carry-on. Flight was delayed 30 mins leaving waiting for a crew member but we still landed on time. The seats are small, and the food just OK but a lot better than many others I've had. Free headsets and in-flight movie made the flight seem short.Punta Cana Airport:A breeze. Immigration and luggage claim was fast, then off to a full size, air conditioned Sunwing Tour bus which took us to our resort (and stopped at two others on the way). I really felt catered to by Sunwing. Only problem with them was finding the Sunwing Rep towards the end of the stay, however the information binder (tours, return flight etc.) was left at the Sunwing desk, just where they said it would be.Hotel Check-in:Again, really quick, took about 3 minutes total. We paid $20 for the room safe and were off to our room....luggage was brought up for us.Room: Wonderful. Main section, right next to main lobby and closest to the beach, pool and La Cana buffet restaurant. Room was quite large, ground floor, wicker table and chairs for lounging, patio chairs outside the sliding doors, ironing board and iron (small problem with the door on the closet being off it's rails, and a loose shower head, but nothing to even complain about really. I don't think I EVER saw not even an ant in our room (oh yeah, a mosquite once, which no doubt followed us in one evening). Room was cleaned very well every day and had fresh towels (no face towel though, as others have said).Grounds: Spotless, always being cleaned, well maintained, very, very pretty actually, both the main section and the Club Section to which we frequented because of the buffet there (we alternated between this buffet and La Cana for variety). The trolley ride there was perfectly fine. I found the whole place quite lovely, and very large.Beach:You'll hardly find a more beautiful beach. We were there for a wedding at nearby Bahia Principe and walked the distance, along the beach to the other hotel a few times. Absolutely beautiful. The Bahia is a 5-star, but any standards, but the beach at Grand Paradise is actually nicer. Grand Paradise is, I would say, a 4-star at best, and certainly does live up to it.Food and drink:Buffets were very, very nice. I usually stick to the buffets at resorts but the a la carte restaurants here were fantastic. We tried the Sea Food (very good, although no lobster or crab on the night we went), the International (great) and the Steak House (the Best). The Dominican restaurant, I found was just OK. But I never ran out of variety at the buffets. The food tasted fine. Both of us did have The runs. That's the risk you take when vacationing. I asked others at the resort and most didn't have any kind of stomach problem. And of course, NEVER drink the water. Stick to the Banana Mama (Hi Robert) , the Miami Vice and the Blue Hawaii. The wine is nothing to sing about but you'll always find most of what you want wait, except for a Caesar which is apparently not well know there - husband had to practically make it himself.Activities:Shows ranged from cheezy to quite good. I hear the 'disco' was OK. There's a club in the area called Rangoo which I hear is great....again, never made it there because we were too busy with the wedding. (I'll resist the urge to rave about the Bahia Principe). We didn't do any excursions primarily again because of the wedding, but I heard Soana Island as well as the jeep safaris are great. There aren't many motorized water sports however, just kayaking, para sailing, banana boat.Service: I found most people courteous enough but certainly did not go out of there way to speak english to us. Surely, the hotel staff make a minimal amount of money, so a little tipping goes a long way. And the one guy at the front desk seemed to take great pride in ignoring guests. I though he was a real jerk, especially at check-out when he intentionally would not even make eye contact with the long line forming, until someone complained to the guy from the Guest Services desk a way over and he came over and hauled out another 'clerk' to assist. Then check-out took only about 2 minutes. That guy needs to fix his attitude or else find a new line of work.Problem: Money - be advised - bring lots of U.S. cash and/or Royal Bank ATM card and credit cards. We both bank with TD Canada Trust and could not get ANY cash out of any of the bank machines at our resort or ther other resorts. Everyone had the same problem. Even the mall La Palma, a 15 minute cab ride away, which has two banks, neither one of them were of any use, yes, Cirrus, etc. We eventually had to go off the resort and thank God found a Scotia Bank to get cash. You're in the Caribbean - visiting a small, Third World country with obvious signs of poverty, everywhere.....be somewhat generous......the very fact that you can afford to travel there should tell you that you're way better off than 99% of these people....be prepared and don't forget you're not at home!Flight home:Again, an easy trip back to PC airport. Airport check-in and immigration, OK, long line-up but by far not the worst I've experienced. I would definitely travel with Sunwing again.Punta Cana:There's really not much to see or do off the resort in Punta Cana so go if you like the beach and pick a resort that has lots of amenities to keep you entertained with water sports, a good club and shows. But you'll have a relaxing week.Over-all:A nice vacation for all age groups. Was an easy trip. I would recommend this resort to friends and family. Just remember you're not paying for a 5-star so don't compare it otherwise you will find disappointments. But I do think it definitely merits it's 4-star rating. I read all sorts of reviews before going (good and bad), plus spoke to two people who've vacationed at this resort. My better judgement told me to go because I've travelled enough to recognize the difference between valid complaints and just people who are unpleasable and unrealistic in their expectation. Ola!

<Author>youngdeanna1
<Content>Amazing Resort Just returned a few days ago and this place was amazing. Just my sister and I went and had an awesome time. ROOMS: We stayed in the Club section of the resort which the rooms are older. Really clean but bathroom fixtures and stuff were older. NO BUGS!! Except when they would put fresh flowers on our bathroom sink, there were little insects in them. We would throw them out right away. We were to get two double beds but ended up getting one king size because the resort was over booked for the Dominican Labour Day Weekend. That was fine for us. Flat screen tv, which we never used was in our room. Hairdryer, coffee maker, AC, iron  board were all in the room. Be careful using the phone, you have to pay each time you use the phone. They charge you when you check out. The Grand Paradise section (not the club) is newly renovated and the rooms are much nicer but you have to take a 10 minute trolly to get to the beach and restaurants. Trolly is fun but waiting around for it is a nuissance. If I go back I'd stay in the older section just to be that close to the beach.RESTAURANTS: Two buffets to choose from one in the Club section and the other in the Grand Paradise section. Both were excellent. Breads, assorted deli meats, deserts, pasta, meats, etc. Very good. Breakfast was the best at the buffet - bacon, bread, yogert, cereal, crossants, muffins, etc. There's also La Cana Grill which is open during the day they have hamburgers, hotdogs, deli meats, fruit, pizza, fries, chichen, etc. Also there's a la carte restaurants to choose from which you have to book in advance. We only tried the Itilian, which was really good.BEACH: Awesome!! Clean, lots of beach loungers. Water is warm. If you have kids be warned lots of topless women. Also around the pools even though there's a sign that says No nudity. Beach was my favorite part of the trip, truly amazing.POOLS: 4 or 5 pools to choose from. Swim up bar on the Grand Paradise section. We mainly stayed around the pools in the Club section. Clean.EXCURSIONS: Definitely recommend the Soana Island Catamaran Tour. It's a full day trip from 7am to 7pm. Try and get a seat up front in the bus so you can see the view. Beautiful place. Took about 2 hours to get to the fishing village where we take the catamaran to the island. It's on the Caribbean Sea which the water is even nicer. Really calm, no waves. Catamaran ride was about 2 hours to get to the island. We stayed on the island for about 3 hours, then took a speed boat back which was so much fun. I recommend packing a light snack for the morning ride. Around 12-1pm they have a big lunch set up on the island, which was good.SHOPPING: Just outside the resort there's a place called Punta Blanca it's a marketplace only 5 minute walk outside the resort gates. You have to barter for items. I suck but my sister got us some really good deals. Always start at 10% of what they are asking, they tell you crazy prices. We walked outside by ourselves it was completely safe. No bad experiences at this resort. Also towards the end of our stay some locals came inside the resort and set up tables to sell items. There's also people going up and down the beach.ACTIVITIES: We weren't much for the nightlife, we got every morning between 5-6am to hit the beach and pool so by 10-11pm we were done. We tried to get as much daylight that we could. Most of the activities were either done in spanish or french and we only understood english.PHOTOSHOP: There's a photoshop on resort and they have photographers going around asking if they can take your picture. You don't have to buy it if you don't like it. We loved the pictures and ended up booking a session. Very professional looking photos and we had a blast doing it. We booked with photographer - Pablo, and he is very talented. Definitely recommend this.LANGUAGE: We only speak english. Most at the resort are french canadians. We found it a little frustrating at times getting directions and asking for things but we got use to it. Most of the staff only speak a small bit of english. We had a mini fridge in our room which had water coke and sprite in it and that was all included - no problems at all and she kept filling it back up every day for us.We went to the entertainement every night - it was great, funny. <Author>tigs
<Content>Just returned from a FANTASTIC stay !!!! We just returned from an absolutely fantastic vacation at the Grand Paradise Bavaro - Club Section.We travelled April 24 - May 1st, staying in the Sunquest Select section of rooms, Builiding 8; 3rd floor. We knew prior to traveling that we were not in the main section of the resort, but it did not bother us in the least. We have stayed at much larger resorts that required much more walking, so we didn't mind. On the days we didn't feel like making the 5-8 minute walk to the main section and beach - we waited for the trolley (never more that 10 minutes, if you just missed it) or at any given time, there was always an employee in a golf cart that would be more than happy to pick you up!!So lets try to sum it all up here...FLIGHT: Flew Skyservice out of Toronto - same typical service we are used to...cramped seats and lousy food, but who cares, this bird is taking you to paradise!!PUNTA CANA AIRPORT: Check in was the quickest!!! At the most 30 seconds at Immigration, and a 5 minute wait for our bags - loved it!!THE RESORT: The resort is comprised of 2 section The Grand Paradise Bavaro and The Club at Grand Paradise Bavaro. The main section is beach front and boasts most of the day and evening activities as well as most of the restaurants. The Club, is a short 5 minute walk from the main section and has 2 pools; both with swim up bars and jacuzzis; along with one buffet and an a la carte restaurant...it is almost a resort in itself, just not beach front. We found the ground of both sections to be very well taken care of and extremely clean.ROOMS: Great!!! We were in building 8 in teh Club section, on the third floor overlooking the pool - althought we were not fortunatel enough to get a room with a jacuzzi, ours was wonderful just the same. The Sunquest Select section of rooms, apparently just opened in December we were told, so everything is brand new. The room we had was with 2 queen sized beds; a small sitting area; walk in closet; bathroom with seperate tub/shower and toilet; balcony overlooking the pool; bar fridge (some items you do pay for) and about a 32 LCD flat panel TV.We did not have any issues with anything being broken; leaking; not working at all - the room was in perfect condition.RESTAURANTS: Oh my goodness, you had such a great selection of places to eat throughout the resort! We had no issues with the food whatsoever, found everything to be plentiful and tasty.- Breakfast: Buffet at the main section or Club. Great selection of food - made to order omletes; waffles; crepes; pancakes - better selection at the main resort, but both of equal quality- Lunch: Buffet at the main section or Club; Buffet at the beach as well, as a daily BBQ there; apparently there was also lunch available in the restaurant in the club section (the Magalar) We found all to be very good, with a different selection each day- Dinner: Buffet at the main section or Club; plus 6 a la carte restaurants to chose from. The buffet had a different theme each night, so the food changed with it - we found it to be very good.We were allowed 3 a la cartes - we chose only 2, due to limited availability. First we dined at the Dominican restaurant which we found to be quite good, a nice selection of fish and meat. Our second was the International a la carte in the Club section - this one was excellent!! Again a great menu selection, lots of choices!!BARS: There are several bars located throughout the resort. I'll start with the main section. There are 2 beach bars; one open unti 11 pm the other until 2am; there is a 24 hr. Sports Bar as well as a Disco. In the Club section there are 2 swim up bars at each pool along with a bar at the Magalar restaurant that had a bistro type feel to it, with tables and chairs set up in a courtyard like setting.NIGHTLIFE: Most watched the evening shows in the main section and then seemed to congregate to the bars at the beach waiting for the disco to open. Disco was great and always busy as was the beach bar that stayed open late. There is a very tiny casino adjacent to the Sports Bar. The Sports Bar is another area that was typiccally busy at night.POOL: There are 3 pools within the entire complex. One in the main section; 2 in the Club. The time we did spend by the pool, we stayed up in the Club section. All pools were very nice, and seemed to be well taken care of and clean. We found that most loungers were taken by about 9am - most reserved by people who never did show up!!!BEACH: I will be echoing most reviews, the beach here was fantastic!! The water was wavy, but not too rough, just enough to have some fun. We did find, that you had to get up at the crack of dawn to reserve a palapa on the beach - this kind of became a routine for us, and maybe I am crazy but we didn't mind. We had a routine of getting to the beach by 6am; watching the sunrise (nothing beats a caribbean sunrise) and then making our way to the buffet for breakfast and then a long walk on the beach before it got too hot. EXCURSIONS: We did not book an off-resort excursions as they seemed to be all very similar to ones we have doen throughout or travels; but we did hear great things about the Monster Truck and Dune Buggie tours. We did however go Parasailing, which we organized at the resort and it was a blast! Cost was $80US for both of us. You are up in the sky about 10-15 minutes and the view is fantastic!!! The captain takes pictures of you that are availabe the next day on CD for $14US - you get about 18-20 pictures; most of you and then some shots fromt eh air of the surrounding resorts etc. Togetehr combined, they are a great memory for us!!!BREIF SUMMARY: After reading many mixed reviews we went with an open mind and I can honestly say, I am not sure where some of you stayed!!!?? This was our second trip to Punta Cana, we were there in 2004 for a breif 4 day stay at Secrets Excellence, which we thoroughly enjoyed. Aside from that we have been to several resorts in Cuba ranging from 4-5 stars and we found this resort to be comperable and in some ways even better. We would return in a heartbeat and would not hesitate to recommend this resort to any of our friends or family. We completely loved this resort and do not have a single complaint..with the exception that it would have been nice to have had a coffee maker and iron inthe room - but we did survive without!!!!

Would have gone on more but ran out of money. We went on the green truck safari, awesome trip, worth it. Went to see several plantations, seen rice being cultavated, all kinds of fruit. We also went to a cave WOW what beautiful cave, absoulately beautiful, a must to see. Don't regret going on this after you get home and see pictures. One thing I thought would be a safety point was to have safety rings on the truck as when you get to the beach as our last of the excuration, the beach was beautiful, but it has a very dangerous under tow that Will carry you out, so please be very careful when you go into the water. Try and stay this side of the first wave. This is something to take very serious, accidents happen. We also went on the tropical Storm on the cattamaran, another beautiful trip. Another all day trip, but worth it. Snorkling was great, the natural pool, and the largest inflated slide which was a blast. Take lots of pictures of your trip to this resort. My husband go somewhere different every year, but I hope to take him to this resort in Nov. Hope this helps people to make up there mind and enjoy your vacation.We do have lots of photos, just not on the computer yet.
