<Content>Excellent resort! We just returned from our Go Travel Direct vacation to Punta Cana, from March 11th -18th. After booking, and reading some of the reviews, we were a little concerned - but on the advise of another review - we went with it................This is a fabulous resort for singles, families and couples. The accomodations are spacious and clean. Very well air-conditioned. We were with our 2 kids, 6 and 9, and were given an extra double bed - and with 3 double beds in the room, there was still plenty of room. A large balcony, great bathroom - no need to bring any toiletaries or hair dryer - they worked fabulously!!We were originally booked at The Club. This is a new part of the hotel. It is extremely nice, gorgeous pool, a couple of restaurants....but you do need to take a 2 minute train ride to the main resort and beach. It was only an issue with us, having kids with us, we didn't want to have to go back and forth to the room, if we forgot something etc.......so we met with the agent Diana, who immediately, without hesitation, moved us to the main resort. She and the guest service manager, couldn't have been nicer and more accomodating. The pool is huge. Yes, you do need to get up and reserve yourself a lounger, if you want an umbrella to shade yourself - but with our kids awake early, my husband just put a couple of towels over the chairs, walked to the beach and did the same there. We would spend the mornings at the beach and then afternoons at the pool. The breakfast buffet at Laguna, was excellent. Every single item of food you could ever imagine - pancakes, crepes, waffles, omelettes, toast (the bread selection was incredible!) sausages, bacon, cereal, fruit, yogourts. Great coffee, tea, fruit juice. The waiters were buzzing around you continually serving you. It really was excellent. At lunch, you could either go back to Laguna or the Cana Grill on the beach. Both, once again, were excellent. Hot meals, salads, deli meats and cheeses, desserts. For the evening meals, you had a choice of a la carte restaurants - we booked the Asian and the Italian. They were great. The Italian was really good. An abundance of food, beautifully prepared...............kids loved it all. For the nights we were at the Laguna buffet, plenty of choice - steaks, potatoes, rice, salad, pasta made to your choice, desserts and fruit. You really had a full choice and we made total pigs of ourselves, eating 2 or 3 plates per meal - ridiculous, but couldn't resist!!There are plenty of poolside activities going on for everyone. The beach was wonderful. White sand that went on forever. There were a couple of topless woman, but they pretty much stayed on their loungers, and definately were not making spectacles of themselves. They were very discreet and no body noticed. You could do several water activities. The beach grill and bar, provided great cool drinks, snacks etc throughout the day.There is a very good kids club. Available from 9-5pm. The women running it, are up-beat, enthusiastic, they LOVE your children. Plenty to do. They take them out swimming, they even take them out for breakfast or lunch, so you can get a bit of time alone. Excellent, safe and worry free babysitting.In the evening, their are market stalls selling various stuff. There is a good sports bar, nightclub, pool music at the bar, shows playing at the amphitheatre. And to top it all, the weather was fantastic................This is a great resort. It has everything you could want or need. And if you treat the employee's with respect and kindness, they will bend over backwards for you. I would deifinately return here again. Try it. It was excellent.

<Author>calgarycrazy4cuba
<Content>Wasn't what we expected We usually travel to Cuba but decided to try the Dominican for some sunshine, rest and relaxation. We stayed at the Grande Paradise from Jan. 23 to Feb 6, 2007. We got the sun, rest and relaxation as expected. We also got diarrhea on day 2, poor service and experienced the annoyance of the VIP employees as did the guy from Waterloo. As I have been to Cuba many times (and my husband is Cuban) we expected that things would be quite similar to Cuba. Not! We are not picky eaters but did have trouble on many occassions trying to find something really tasty at the Buffet. (I can say though that the fried chicken at the La Cana restaurant everyday at lunch is excellent!) We both love fish and expected that there would be more fish available. Warning - If you see the glazed ham - stay away from it - the time we tried it I am sure that it had gone bad.We met some nice people while we were there and did enjoy meeting SOME friendly staff but for the most part I can say that there were not a lot of smiles from staff and this was very disappointing. As I say, we are used to going to Cuba and I always bring lots of things to give away. We had trouble finding deserving people to give it to though. Cudos to Jose and Nelson (both bartenders) and to Samuel at the beach massage booth.One of the highlights (besides the sunshine) was the Monster Truck Tour ($85 US each). Terrific. Picked up at 7 a.m. and dropped off at 5 p.m.. Stopped at a farm, school house, popular river (swimming) and several stops where we could give stuff to villagers who are much in need. We had taken 2 carry ons with stuff to give away (paper, pencils, crayons, kitchen stuff, baseball glove, balls, shampoo, deodorant, clothes, etc.) and wished that we had brough 2 suitcases full instead. There are so many people (including Haitians) that need help. The tour also included lunch and a drink on the truck every 15 minutes. If you drink enough rum I understand that it takes away the pain of seeing so many in need (I had 5 but needed more!)The VIP guys are really annoying and it took my husband 4 days to finally get them to stop bothering us. One even asked to borrow money which he would pay back. The answer was No.You have to be very careful when shopping. We were told to barter with people but you have no idea. In Cuba we don't because they don't ask for much and don't try to get your every peso. We bought one necklace for $20 US from a vendor outside the Buffet, the next day in the hotel we found the same thing for $10 at the jewellery store and later found the exact same for $5 at the Punta Cana market. We were also told that you can take Cdn or US money but Cdn doesn't really work as most places take US or pesos only. The hotel itself - whenever we left our room (6134) which was right on the beach we had to slam our door to get it shut. The tables in the La Cana restaurant are in need of fixing as some are only attached at one end. When paying our phone bill we were short changed and had to ask for the remainder of our money. Hold on to your tables at the main buffet - if you leave them for a moment they will take all the food away and you will have to start again or go away hungry and frustrated. We complained to Guest Services about several things and were told that a report would be made up and compensation sent to our room. Never arrived (not that we were really expecting it). Remote for your t.v. - not that you are there to watch tv - but we found out on the last day that you have to ask reception for the remote.The beach - beautiful! You need to get up at 7 to put your towel on a lounger if you want a good spot though. The waves are very high and the undertow very strong.Annimation - whatever. Some shows are quite good but others not so much. (They are really lucky as their costumes are a lot nicer than Cuba's - due to being able to trade I guess). A lot of drinking done by people who are paid to entertain (especially at the disco) and I could go on but I won't.There really isn't much to do outside the resort unless you are going to pay to go on a tour. You can take a bus to the next City but otherwise you are really stranded at the resort. I am not used to that but had been pre-warned.Got charged $75 overweight coming back (in the end only paid $60) and can't understand as we gave so much stuff away and really didn't buy anything except necklaces. Wasn't charged for being overweigh leaving Canada.Overall, very satisfied with the sunshine (only rained one evening) but disappointed with most everything else. Maybe other hotels are different but we weren't at another hotel and that doesn't change the response we got from the people there. We will be going back to Cuba next time. Sorry Punta Cana. Oh yes, on my return I spent the next day in Emergency and for only $71 Cdn you can get 6 very good antibiotics to cure your stomache!

<Content>Beautiful Beach......however...... We went to this resort from Feb 3 - Feb 10 and just arrived home, home sweet home.I checked this website faithfully and tried to be prepared for the worse but hoped for the best. A little advice... Keep your towels overnight. In the morning send a friend alone or spouse alone with the towels to pick up cards from this lady. Then when your spouse returns wait 10 min and bring the cards back to this lady for fresh towels. They will not exchange towels for towels. Be sure to be alone throughout this process cause they will recognize you.- If your first room has a toilet that does not flush properly, complain and they will move you to a better room with a good functioning toilet and shower.- Be sure to hang the Please make up the room sign on the door and throw the dirty towels in the tub or else they will not give you fresh ones.- Don't expect fresh sheets daily unless you are stripping the bed yourself and throwing them on the floor. Gladys de Jesus seems to use the excuse of not being able to open your room door to make up the room, alot.- Bring chewable immodium and be sure to drink a minimum of 2L a day of water if you have loose stools. If you give him a couple bucks he will take good care of your liquid needs! lol- Most of the staff is very good with customer service. They really try and make you happy.- The gift shop ladies are mean, beware. We walked past some magnets and they happen to fall off the door and fell on the floor. These lady's are not afraid to yell at you and make you feel like an ass. They run on a understandable You break you buy policy- The ocean is amazing. The water is beautiful and nice and warm. Spend some time in the waves.- Bring some OFF sprizer spray with at least 20-30% DEET. Spray the floor drain in the bathroom and the bottom of the door to keep visitors away. (Not so many bugs in on the 2nd + floors.All in all it was very nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of our lifestyle. If you have had the luxury of travelling to 4 + resorts expect a little less from this resort. The beach, rest and relaxation really saved the day for us. I wish you a great trip! And remember to speak up for what you want, for the most part they try to accomodate your needs. Have fun!

<Author>sensfan12
<Content>Very Nice Vacation My wife and I just came back from the Grand Paradise Bavaro last night. We had a very good vacation.First, the beach and the weather were incredible! We had 30+ deg C weather without a drop of rain for 7 days. The beach is absolutely amazing - just miles and miles of soft white sand and clear blue water lined with palm trees. The best beaches we've seen compared to Cancun, Puerto Plata, and Barbados. On some days, there were some pretty good waves which was alot of fun to play in. On these days, there was a bit of weeds that washed into certain areas of the beach but nothing major. Note: you have to get out to reserve your beach chairs very early - before 8 am!!!Before reviewing the hotel, the one thing that is important for travellers to understand is that the hotel ratings in the Carribean are different than in North America, i.e. you cannot expect the luxuries of a Canadian 4-star hotel at 4-star in the DR. You need to come to terms with this otherwise you will be disappointed no matter which resort you go to in the DR.The Grand Paradise is a nice, mid-sized resort. The layout is very good with the pool in the middle and the resort buildings arranged in a U around it. The pool is really nice, big and clean. The a-la-carte restaurants were very good - we tried the seafood place, the steak house, and the Dominican restaurant. The buffet place was pretty good - lots of variety. I wouldn't want to eat there for several weeks but it was certainly ok for our stay. There was also a beach side grill where they served pizza, hot dogs, burgers throughout the day. Not exactly gourmet food but good enough for those days where we didn't want to go to the big buffet place.We got very good service at the bars and there was lots of activities throughout the day (aerobics, volleyball, games, etc.). We brought thermos mugs and the bartenders had no problems in making our drinks in them - kept them colder longer and helped reduce number of trips to the bar.For the negatives, there weren't very many: First, the room we had was nothing to write home about - old and worn. But it was clean and adequate for us since we spent little time there except to sleep (see comments about expectations above). On the third day we were there, the whole region had a water shortage for the entire day until 7 pm. This wasn't a big deal until you wanted to shower or go to the bathroom....Note: this was not the resort's fault since the whole region was affected. I wrote about it because it's something that can happen in countries like the DR... Lastly, my wife and I both got a mild case of the tourista despite being careful with what we ate and drank. Make sure to bring immodium no matter what resort you stay at - it's almost par for the course when you're down there no matter where you stay.In summary, we would definitely go back to Punta Cana because of the amazing beaches and weather. The Grand Paradise is a very adequate AI resort that we would recommend with the warning that the rooms are old and that you can't expect the luxuries of a North American 4-star hotel.

<Author>KDZTUF
<Content>Well worth it We returned on 1/28 from a week at Grand Paradise and had a very nice week all in all. If you lower your standards a bit and remember this is the Caribbean, and have some good weather, you'll have a good vacation. Here are some comments pro and con.ROOM: Spacious,clean,bare floors,clean,poorly lit for night time reading, good TV selection, fridge stocked with Cokes,Sprite and water at no charge, adequate closet space, inadequate drawer space, enough toweling. TIP: ask for 2 keys. The power is kept on in the room with a key in a slot. Take the key when you leave the room and the room is hot when you return.BEACH: Beautiful,clean,water is rough on occassion since this is the Atlantic, few pesty vendors now located in an area just off the grounds,good water sports, plenty of chairs,lots of shade. Music always playing but we've heard worse. Plent y of towels and chaises. The pool area is pretty with some shade. There is a bar close to the pool and beach. TIP: before breakfast go to the beach or pool,pick out your spot, put books,towels, etc on the chairs then go to breakfast. Do it every morning, so you won't have to hunt around. every day.FOOD: Not gourmet but better than passable. Breakfast is just fine with a very fast egg station. The buffet has some good food at every meal. The pastries were very good. I'm picky and I was more than satisfied. There are five specialty restaurants. Chinese was the best. Italian,disappointing...fair food poor service. The La Cana Grill was good. We didn't go to the Seascape or the Dominican. TIP: The sign up for specialty restaurant reservations is a pain. 10:30 to 3. Do it right away if you check in before three to insure your choices. You are entitled to 3 specialties for each week.Entertainment: Every night but awful depending on your level of experience. We are admittedly spoiled. Some talent but repeticious. There is the usual audience participation stuff before every show. The 9:45PM start in too late for our taste.They have a small room with slot machines,pool tables.hockey and snacks. There is a small casino in the hotel next door with slots,black jack,roulette, and poker. A 6 dollar cab fare which the will reimburse for coming but not returning to your hotel. The day time activities are the usual...volley ball etcStaff: very friendly and helpful. The ladies in the gift shop are a little sour. Too busy talking to one another. TIP: bring some room snacks if you enjoy them. I will not pay $2.00 for a Milky Way.Shopping: There is a small shopping area within walking distance for local arts and crafts. <Content>Paradise @ The Grand Paradise Bavaro Just got back yesterday from Punta Cana. We stayed at the Grand Paradise Bavaro. We usually had lunch at the La Cana Grill. Pizza  fries were good, but hamburgers weren't cooked. The buffet restaurant was great. Lots of variety. The nightly shows were good. Daily activities were okay. The beach was beautiful. Pools were kept clean. The bathrooms are another story. A couple of days there was no water at the beachbar restroom and other locations. Water always worked in our room though. The rooms were not dimly lit as stated in some reviews. Maid service was more than adequate. We requested additional towels and received no problem. Also received extra water and sodas without asking. We went banana boating on the beach. This was alot of fun. We also went to the Marinarium. This was a 1/2 day excursion and I would recommend it. Alot of laughs and it was cool to swim with sharks and stingrays (very safe). We also did the sunset horseback ride which we would also recommend. We found the staff at the hotel very friendly. On-site photographers are great. They bring around different animals each day to have a photo taken with. My daughter loved this. My son loved the daily volleyball. All in all we loved the resort and would definitely return. We liked that this was a small resort compared to some of the super large ones. The only thing we would do different is bring our own pillows. The resort pillows are very lumpy. email me if you have any questions (sharalynb@sympatico.ca)

<Content>GRAND PARADISE is what it is!!!! I stayed at this resort from Dec. 16th to the 23rd and let me tell you it was one of best experiences of my life. All the resorts in Punta Cana aren't near any shopping plazas, except the markets are close by. Either you walk down the beach for over an hour or you go outside the club resort, around the cornor and there ya go. The market is called Plaza Punta Blanca. Only offer 40-45% of what the vendors offer. Most of them do not know the value of US money, except local #5....his name is Eddy and he is very honest and respectful to all visitors. His gift shop is called La Caribena. The rest of them consistently bug you and call you lady or sir Some of them say to you that they will give you anything for cheapy, cheapy. This experience is very rewarding because you really can get some better prices than what you will pay in the gift shops at the resort. Make sure you do go to the market because the memories will last forever. The ground keeping of this resort is maintained amazing. They do a great job! Cleaning the pools, removing drink cups, plates, etc., and the general overall appearance is awesome! I would speak very highly of this resort and tell anyone to go there. The younger crowd would love all the activites throughout the day, the children have their own little pool, the beach is beautiful and relaxing for those lazy and quiet days, and the entertainment at night is superb! There's a night club that's open from 11-2am and you can't hear the music at all from outside. It's GREAT! The only complaint I have is that they're really behind with the music and they play the same stuff all the time, ex: ace of base, no doubt etc. The restaurants also played christmas music 24/7 which sucked cuz when you came home you didn't want to hear anymore of it. Other than that I would go back to this resort in a heart beat!!!!

<Author>chuly
<Content>Greatest beach but... Okay, so I read all the reviews I could find before I actually left. I was nervous about everything. I was at the Grand Paradise from december 24th to january 7th.First, the actual check-in was a breeze, a nice cocktail was awaiting us. The process actually took less than 10 minutes.The room. I had writen an e-mail requesting building 6 or 3, the ones facing the pools, and I got exactly what I had asked for. I was in room 6210, second floor, huge balcony overlooking the pools and I even had an ocean view. The room is quite big, tv, fridge, chairs, 2 double beds, a dresser, a good size bathroom with bath and shower. The toilet/bath is separated from the vanity area (sink and mirror). The room was ALWAYS cleaned and we never had problems getting towels. You do have a problem with the water pressure during peak hours (5pm-8pm). The fridge got restocked everyday with what we liked (do talk to your maid and tip her and she'll give you the moon). The floor was washed often and not once did I see a bug of any sort in my room. So be reassured about that part.The pools are beautiful. Plenty of chairs but they do get taken very fast. The pool bar is often crowded and you'll get pushed over sometimes. Don't bother tipping unless you visit the bar very often... The jacuzzi is quite icky... don't go in there, the water is always murky...The BEACH, what can I say, it's the best thing going for this resort. The sand is like powder, the ocean is gorgeous not or almost no debris ( compared to the beach in front of the Bahia Principe, disgusting!!!). You do have to get up very early if you want to get a palapa. But for me, a chair in the sun did just fine. No problem getting that! Be very careful, they give you a card that you exchange for a beach towel. If you loose the card or the actual towel, it will cost you 20$! Has I did, I suggest that you bring your own old towel that you don't mind loosing...The animation is ok but I got bored of hearing awa-yim (aquagym) and dee-yay (d-j) very soon!!!! The nightime shows are a bore, a mix of karaoke and lipsync...The staff is ok , they are very accommodating. Beware you single ladies of the locals who are VERY touchy-feely...Now for the bad!!!! THE FOOD IS REALLY BAD. I'm not a fussy eater. I like to eat good, wholesome food. A simple grilled chicken, a little veggie on the side and some fruits. I had trouble finding that!!!! The buffet is always stocked with fish or pork in SAUCE! The veggies are either too cooked or in a SAUCE. The food is not good at all. Even the a la cartes are disappointing. The only good one is the Manglar and it's Chateaubriand. If you like fried foods, pizza, fish and pork , you'll be in heaven! There's always fresh fruit available and the breads are really good (not if you're on Atkins though!!!) If you do go there, bring your own snacks 'cause a bag of chips will cost you 5 $ US in the gift shop!!!Be careful of the agents who tell you they'll arrange for you to go somewhere to buy stuff. They will charge you more than if you bought your souvenirs at the airport!!!! The vendors come in every friday night and you can make excellent deals but be firm and stand your ground. Be aware that some of the vendors will try to sell you fake larimar and amber. If they're legit, they'll scratch a mirror with the actual stone or light a lighter to it to prove to you that it's real (plastic melts and does'nt scratch...).So, overall, if you are lookin for a clean hotel, a superb beach and you like fish, pork, sauces and fried foods, you will be pleased. 2 weeks for me was WAY too LONG!!!!

<Author>CHARBY'S
<Content>Great time - from Knowlton, Qc Canada We stayed at the CLUB at Grand Paradise in Punta Cana from December 9th to December 16th. Admittedly, I was very nervous after reading some of the reveiws but I am very happy to say that we had a great time. We travelled with Go Travel Direct from Montreal - Zoom Airlines and we taken very good care of. From check in at the airport, to arriving at the hotel - all when very smoothly. Everyone we had contact with was polite and more than helpful. I had seen several warning about NOT staying at the CLUB --- mostly from those who stayed at the sister resort -- not to worry - the CLUB was great. It is more quiet - swim up bar - plenty of service -- not a problem at all. There is a 2 minute trolly ride to get to the beach - or you can also walk. It is a beautiful relaxing walk through a jungle looking area lined with gorgeous hibicus shrubs. We chose to walk most times. We had several guests at our resort who had switched from Grand Paradise to the CLUB as it is on the quiet, relaxed side. Great for families with little children - no crowd here as everyone is at the beach during the day. The food -- well somedays it is wonderful and others --- well less so. But there is plently to chose from --- you will never starve ! Bad drinks ? --- not for our foursome who were all quite happy - a treat of mamajuana each night too. The beach is, of course, absoultely gorgeous. It is clean, soft, and long. I think it is probably the nicest right in front of our resort - but maybe I am a litte partial. Lots of activities, if you so wish. Some sales people who are not a bother at all. Polite and helpful. BARGAIN to your heart's content. Larimar and Amber are great deals - at about 1/4 the starting price. Our rooms were average rooms, nice bacony and very clean - always made very pretty with freshly picked hibicus flowers on swan and hearts made from the rooms towels. Leave the maid a litte note for anything you need, and she will do her best to help you out. It was fun to come back to the room to see each day's surprise. Everyone is very relaxed, so you may have to ask more than once for your coffee but hey, chill out a little. Slow down and enjoy your meal. The grounds, pools and restaurants are very clean - lots of gardens and ponds with ducks - look for Matilda - cranes and fish to feed. There will be Vendors on the Friday night - with great deals to be had. You have access to both resorts - take advantage of that - tour around and you will enjoy it. We took the Mountain View Jeep Safari - had a wonderful day. Well, worth the cost. We had a great week - don't be afraid of this resort - you will be pleased if you keep in mind where you are. Don't go in with unreasonable expectations and you wil be very pleasantly surprised. Paradise is the key word ! Enjoy ! A thank you to Anne Michelle - our Go Travel Rep - and to Hugo the bartender who made each evening fun.

<Author>CrazyForCaribbean
<Content>Beautiful Beach, but Resort Was a Disappointment We stayed at the Grand Paradise Bavaro in late February 2006. We had not done an AI since we were young, and had decided to give the Dominican Republic a try. This report will be long.I read all the reviews after I had booked (booked somewhat last minute on travel agent recommendation), and I became very nervous. We went with an open mind and wanted to enjoy our trip. We are not picky and just wanted to relax. I thought maybe some of the other postings were from people who expected a lot or who were very hard to please. I have to agree with a lot of negative things.On arrival, the resort did not look quite as nice as some of the others we had seen during the ride on the airport transfer. No problem, because I've found that sometimes the inside is beautiful and you don't spend your vacation outside staring at the entrance to the resort. We were pleased with the furnishings and the landscaping of the resort. This is one of the smaller resorts and we didn't expect alot of glitz. We were booked in The Club section but were taken to the main section (beach side) for check-in. Needless to say, we had to be taken back to the Club side to check-in. We had to ask many questions to find out about things - the staff was personable but not forthcoming with information. I only knew to ask about the tram that goes from one section to the other because of this site. Reservations have to be made for the ala-carte restaurants.We stayed on the Club side because the rooms were all Jr. Suites with a jacuzzi tub in the room and this side was much quieter (which is what we wanted). The jacuzzi did not work at all. Our room could not be changed because they were sold out and we were repeatedly told that someone was coming up to fix it. They even told us at one point that it was fixed. It was not. This went on for 3 days. We finally gave up. Now, we had no perk for being in the nicer room because we were further from the beach. Very disappointing.We left a nice tip for the maid each day and we got soda  water stocked in the fridge. We left a note asking for Diet Coke  water only and she provided them the next day. After that we just left the tip, and there was no restocking of the fridge. We had to call the front desk to get soda.We called for an iron one night and it took 3 hours. No apologies, no excuses. Actually, my husband had to wind up going to the front desk for it and then had to sign 3 different forms to borrow it for 15 minutes.Our best dinner was at the Manglar on the Club side. Patrons can dine at restaurants on either side of the resort. The wait staff here was incredible! Very attentive and personable! It was difficult, and sometimes impossible to get coffee in the morning at the buffet. We were both bartenders for over a dozen years and will be more patient than the next person because we can empathize, but service was ridiculously slow, and it was no better no matter how much you tipped. Even at some of the nicer restaurants for dinner. We often waited and waited for coffee to be served to eat with the desserts that had been served 20-30 minutes prior. These restaurants were not packed to the gills and there were plenty of servers available. We are frequent travelers to the Caribbean and recognize that there is such a thing as Island Time - service will definitely be slower. This was unacceptable. A free half-hour of horseback riding comes in the AI price. Each day we went to sign up, we were told that it was booked, even if we said How about 3 days from now. The answer was always no, but for X amount of dollars we could ride for an hour or two. I felt like we were being scammed every time we asked for the perks that were part of the package price ( I believe kayaks were part of that too - same story). we gave up on that as well.Vendors set-up tables on the beach side of the resort early on Friday nights. I got a beautiful set of Larimer jewelry at a bargain price. I was just thinking about my purchase and he just kept lowering the price! I guess he thought I was going to walk away from the deal because I was quiet, but it worked to my advantage. He even let us pay him 3 hours later because our money was in the safe. Very nice vendors!I did suffer some GI upset for several days. I was able to still enjoy the beach each day, but for 2 days I was petrified to eat breakfast or lunch. I had chills the one night and my husband had to dine alone. One of the waiters we met the first night noticed my husband and alone and asked for me. He let him know that I was sick and just wanted some bread to nibble on ,so he gave my husband several clean napkins so he could bring me back rolls from the buffet :)The best part of the vacation was the BEAUTIFUL BEACH! The sand was perfect! The water was incredible and the most lovely shade of blue (and we have been to many islands)! We walked along the beaches in front of some of the other resorts and Grand Paradise definitely had the nicest beach. We met couples staying at other resorts and they too commented that the beach and surf seemed to be the best. All in all, I was in the Caribbean with my husband on a much needed vacation, and we enjoyed our time together. There were only a handful of staff members that were courteous and the only highlights of the trip were the beach, water and dinner at Manglar. <Author>lost-cape-bretoner
<Content>Christmas in the Sun!!!! Just returned back from the resort this week. And after reading the reviews here, I think some people ask for way too much! My family and I went to the Grand Paradise for our first family vacation at Christmas, and can't wait to go back! (My teenage daughter would still be there) We are well travelled people and this trip by far sets the bar for the rest.The room- We checked in and were greeted with a smile and drinks. It was a smooth process, and the staff fell over themselves trying to help us. We were escorted to our room, and it was in Bldg 2 top floor (2307), the door was opened when we got there, and it was not the Hilton, but was very clean, and no bugs. I did a complete inspection and it was certainly clean enough for the family. Pehaps the lights were a bit dim, but we looked at it as if it created a tranquil ambience. Afterall, you don't want to feel as though your in a hospital room with glaring lights on a holiday! To say the least with the amount of time spent in the room there, it was suffice. We only went there to sleep and shower, not much time spent in the room. We left gifts for the maid (nylons, beauty products, etc) and had clean towels and clean room all the time. The maids were happy and I greeted them everytime I saw them, what a great bunch of people. Our luggage arrived promply and the busboy was singing and smiling, we tipped him, and he was gracious. The food- I have no idea the big fuss of the food that is here? Sure don't eat the cheese, but hello people-you are in a country without pasturization! The food was plentiful, the crepes were extraordinary, the omlettes-awesome. I loved the pineapple every meal also....Christmas Eve...WOW! Did they do it up nice. Extraordinary displays of culinary art for Christmas. We had turkey, stuffing, potatoes, gravy...it was superb. I don't think for one minute that I could have done better here in Canada. Nor do I kid myself that dispays of bread donkeys are in my capability.....The food at the restraunts were good, the soup at the Italian was awesome. The steak at the grill was tasty, and the chinese was outstanding! We purchased our own wine there and it topped off a great meal each night.The pool- Awesome. What more can one say? They were clean, well maintained, and enough chairs for all. If you wanted sun or shade the choice was yours, as there were umbreallas all around the pool. We had brought travel mugs with us, and what a great idea. It saves you from 50 trips to the bar for a refill, and the ice stayed much longer in the hot sun. Pack your travel mugs, you won't be sorry. I loved the pool area and our room was not far from anything. My husband and daughter loved the beach, so we alternated each day between the pool and beach. We brought our own towels also, but this was not necessary, as the resort had a huge supply for all. The Beach- Clean, clean, clean. Yes there were some cigarette butts in the sand. I think this is due to inconsiderate people who think they are entitled to be swine when they are on holidays. All inclusive does not mean- All manners out the window! At the beach, there was always something to see. If your a people watcher-go to the beach. Children in the sand, people playing in the waves, or watch parasailing in the sky. Something for everyone. It was superb.The Entertainment- well I must say, what an energetic staff. They were coaxing people to join into water areboics, stretching, pool games, beach volleyball, or shuffleboard. The highlight was the tropical Christmas show. WOW! It was elobrate, and awesome. a great show, and the children from the resort participted actively. It was great. They danced with people in the audience, and you really felt like a part of the show. I couldn't take my eyes off the stage, as the costumes were elobrate, and the talent was awesome! My teenage daughter found the internet, and enjoyed e-mailing her friends pictures and telling tales of her vacation in the tropics. They charged $8 for an hour, which is resonable, as in any city you would be lucky to find it at that price. On Christmas Eve for breakfast they had 3 local men with guitars and morraccos sing at your table for you. This was beautiful, and I wished them a Merry Christmas in thier native tongue. It was great. Some people ignored them like they weren't there, but some people are like that I suppose. My husband and I lapped it up, and felt honoured that we were serenaded at breakfast for Chritmas Eve. Can't get that in Canada. I believe that there is always something there for you to do, whether you choose to participate or not, you are the designer of your own holiday. I didn't sit back and wait for someone to involve me, I made it my own. On Dec 24th we had an itenary slipped under our door with the days events. This was great and allowed us to plan for what we wanted to do and participate in. On Christmas day, Santa arrived on horse back, and all the children followed him to the beach. He gave gifts to all the children, and it was a splendid thing to see. The Staff- From the maid to the busboy, from the gardner to the waitress Bravo! They were outstanding. One of the waitresess was so kind, I told her I liked her earrings, and she gave them to me on xmas day. How nice. They were all glorious with the exception of the gift shop. Rude, ignorant, and not so motivated to say the least. I refuse to be pushy and have a few woman ruin my holiday, so I never went back in there. Problem solved. The photgrapher was great and produced some awesome pictures for souviners. Pictures with the parrott were great. The staff at the check in were very accomdating to us, and allowed for a late check out the day we were flying. It cost $20 but what a convienience to us. The room safe was the same price, and gave us the piece of mind for our money and cameras. Although the staff was honest as I left money on the table, and it was not touched when I got back. That stands for something in my books. Greet them with a smile and manners, and you will get back the same from everyone there. Parasailing- My husband and I went up on xmas eve, and what an awesome experience. We loved it. Went out to the ocean by boat to experience it, and saw a school of 8 dolphins below us. The island was magnificant to see from the sky. We asked to be dipped into the water, and it was allot of fun. They took pictures of us, and we had to have them. It was awesome and I would have paid double for that experience again. Le Torpedo- was a great insight off the resort. We were told of this by our Air Canada rep- we participated and were not sorry. It costs you nothing to go, and we had the opportunity to see hand made cigars. They had rum, jewellery and cigars there...something for all. Try it out- what do you have to lose? The prices were reasonable- much cheaper than the resort and no haggling.My advice- bring travel mugs, immodium, snacks (in case you can't find anything at the buffett) granola bars, chips and gum were a god send. When our snack cravings hit, we had them in our room. And the gum was great for the salty water at the beach. I did learn that thier bananas are equal to 3 here in Canada. So if you get ill and need to stop running to the bathroom- eat bananas. 3=9 CDN. It WILL stop you. And if you are at the other end of the spectrum and can't go to the washroom, coconut is a natural laxitive. IT WORKS! All in all- we would go back tomorrow. You would be hard pressed to find anything better than this resort!!!!!!!

<Author>Blithespirit3
<Content>Heavenly Getaway We just got back yesterday from an incredible week in the hot Dominican sunshine at the Grand Paradise. The resort was amazing (granted this is our first all-inclusive getaway so our comparators are few, but we do travel alot) - we had a superior room with a garden view (highly recommend this for better cable and quiet sleeps - pool view is a bit noisier it seems) and we loved it.The staff was incredibly happy, helpful and plentiful. The rooms were clean (granted, a few minor decorative repairs were needed but they were minimal eg. a piece of broken quarter round on the dresser, a little tear in the patio door blind), spacious, tastefully decorated and a/c'd! The food was delicious, plentiful and there was incredible choice. Our favourite of the specialty restaurants was the Dominica grill Taino. We heard some complaints from people we met there who had trouble with wait service at the Italian restaurant but we didn't have a bad experience. We found that a $1 or $2 US tip was remembered by the staff and they were even MORE helpful to us after that small token of thanks. The vegetables were a big hit at the La Laguna Buffet as was the breakfast there, others reviews are right, the omelette station is the best!We were in building six so only a few steps from the beach, pool and restaurants. Honestly, we couldn't have been more pleased. We never had trouble finding chairs, no matter the time of day we went out. The ocean and beach were wonderful, and they had staff cleaning up any garbage the guests were leaving about throughout the day. We took the snorkelling trip and had a blast. Our captain even took us on a side trip to see sharks and stingrays (they were in a pen but we swam around it) or a few extra US $ - was a great day.Lots of Europeans so many foreign languages to hear and the resort is small enough that you can meet new friends and get a sense of who is on holiday 'with you'.The activation team work SO hard it blew my mind away. There was something to do, if you wanted, all the time, but if you just wanted to chill out and tan, that was possible too. The shows at night were great fun - not much in the way of sets, but the main stage appeared to be under renovations, so the shows were up at the Paradise Club (I think it's called) about a 4 minute shuttle ride away.The only small spot of complaint would be that I agree with other reviewers that the staff at the gift shop is a bit hard to engage or get help from...but really, there's not much need to be in there for more than five minutes, so in a week, that's not much to complain about.We visited the market beside the front gates to the resort - the shopkeepers are aggressive and you'll definitely want to bargain/haggle the price down to at least half of what they start at.We spent our nights having an end-of-evening drink by the beach bar - hearing the surf and the laughter and singing of the staff was great - we knew we were on holiday and were well cared for. We highly recommend this resort (for all ages!).

<Author>misspolly
<Content>Amazing Beach My fince and I spent 7 days on this glorious beach. We are both well travelled and thoroughly enjoyed our stay at this property. Room:Our room was simple. No frills or such but it was clean and located in the centre of the property. There was never a lack of hot water, fresh towels or clean linens. Food: The food was quite tasty. There was a large selection of food. If you can find something you like... stay home and cook your own food. There are three stations in addition to the large buffet for lunch and dinner. One for fresh fish, another is a carvery station for roasted pork, chicken, turkey, beef etc. and the other a fresh pasta station. In the morning there is an omelet station... your choice of ingredients. The buffet is always stocked with fresh fruit as well. Food is served on this resort from 7:00am to 2:00am as there are several restaurants.... if you can't find something to eat......please!!!!A La Carte Restaurants: We chose, Chines, French (International), and Italian. Surprisingly... we found the Chinese restaurant to have the best ambience, service and food. But all were tasty. The Chinese and Italian restaurant have a romantic feel... the French restaurant does not... the lights are very bright. Drinks: The wine served with lunch and dinner is lacking. If you're a wine lover.... order a bottle at the A La Carte restaurants, they have a large selection and the prices are comparable to home. We enjoyed the large variety of frozen drinks offered.. as well as the simple rum and coke, vodka and orange juice etc. The resort also has a large supply of non-alcoholic drinks during meals and at the bar. For breakfast there is fresh fruit juice, coffee and a variety of tea (Twinings), green, lemon, peppermint, english breakfast, etc. There is soda (major brands coke, sprite, etc) available during lunch, dinner and snacks. Activities: To the people who found nothing to do.... stay home on your sofa and continue to be a couch potato. Vacation is what you make of it. There is always a volleyball game happening, beach games organized by the animation team, kayaking, catamaran, pool games, tennis, ping pong, badminton, daily areobic and stretching classes - all our located outside so you don't have to be indoors. There is also a games room, and a sports bar... what more do you want. Parasailing and tubing is also available but you have to pay for those particular activities. Animation Shows: We only went to one show... and weren't very impressed. We were bored to tears with the lack of imagination and talent... so we left at the end of the show and we didn't return.Disco: Was filled with staff and visitors. The focus is mainly on Latin music but is was fun. We let loose and got into the groove. Staff: The majority of the staff were very helpful, friendly and professional. I did have one negative experience with the ladies in the gift shop but I refused to let two miserable girls who obviously hate their jobs ruin my vacation. I just didn't go back into their shop... their loss!! Airline: We booked our vacation with Sunwing. This was a first time experience for us. We would definitley book with them in the future. The food on the plane was actually edible and the service was great. Our on-site Sunwing Rep Jennifer was so helpful. She even brought me sun tan lotion from home when I was running low... what service. LIke I said, vacation is what you make it. If you want to have a good time you will find a way to enjoy yourself. If not... why spend the money? Stay home and be miserable.

I am not a picky eater, I generally find something I like to eat in every place that I travel to. This place was the exception. Most of the food was overcooked, oily, and salty. The meats were often very fatty or tough. The sausages and cold cuts tasted like they came out of a can. The food I did eat made me sick four of the five days that I was there. There wasn't much available to drink outside of the frozen mixed drinks. They didn't have normal mixers for the alcohol. They didn't have any cranberry juice or grapefruit juice available. It rained two days during our stay and there was not much to do at the property during inclimate weather. The activities staff was inexperienced and unimaginative. Most of the entertainment consisted of karoke performances. Most of the excursions outside the hotel were $75 and up and the majority of those involved water sports. I had a much better time in Jamaica and Mexico.

<Author>aiacono
<Content>Great Holiday We had an enjoyable stay at the Gran Paradise Bavaro from August 5 -12. This was my first experience at any resort. After having read negative reviews on this site, I was terrified to go and packed all sorts of medications with me expecting the worst. Why do people write such negative reviews? Itéˆ¥æªš great to experience other parts of the world. Airport: Once you got through customs and got your suitcase, we looked for our tour facilitator, Nolitours. They were ready for us and had a bus waiting. Some people didnéˆ¥æª› know about the bus, so they probably took a cab, not necessary. The bus ride was about 40 min from the Punta Cana Airport. Airport is really interesting with hut roofs.Check-In: This took about 5 minutes and went very quickly and smoothly. Rafael checked us in. He speaks very well English, Italian, French, Spanish. The lobby was also quite impressive. There were no problems with luggage or going to our room. The bell boy takes your luggage to your room.Room: Very large, beautiful, and spacious. On your left is the bathroom with a closet and full length mirrors. Your safe is in the closet as well. Good idea to lock up your valuables and passports. The toilet and bathtub with shower are separate from the sink which makes it easier to use while the other is using mirror and hair dryer. Our room had two double beds with a sliding door to the balcony. The balcony had 2 chairs and a table, but we hardly used it except to hang up our towels. Our room was backing onto the Majestic Resort. Our TV had satellite with several English stations and we were actually kept informed with CNN so we didnéˆ¥æª› feel so remote from news. The maid made our rooms and replaced our towels and tidied up. It felt great to come back to a clean room every day. They always left flowers in the bathrooms. When we got there we had to ask for face towels, but then the maid knew to bring them. We tipped every day. They work very hard. A few dollars for us is a lot for them. If you donéˆ¥æª› speak Spanish, good idea to look up the basics you need to know to get the service you want. Theyéˆ¥æª™e was always bottled water and soft drinks in the fridge. Resort: The resort is beautiful and very well kept. At first I thought that bigger is better, but then I was glad that we only had to take the shuttle to the show at night. The resort does have an extension on this side, but one had to take the shuttle every day to the beach. I was glad I was on the beach side. I met a few people who were not pleased with their rooms at the Club. The men and women are constantly working and cleaning around the clock. Everything is done with a machete which is interesting to watch when in Canada we see all yard work done with actual tools. . Pool/ Beach: We loved both. There is entertainment everyday at the beach, i.e. aerobics, volleyball, aqua-gym, table tennis and of course the various water sports some were included and some were extra. We would get a lounge chair at either the beach or pool leave our stuff and switch back and forth between swimming at both. Theyéˆ¥æª™e were plenty of chairs, but we would reserve the umbrellas by the pool or huts on the beach. We were always there before 9:00 a.m. Weather: Very warm and party cloudy everyday. <Author>beach2bmine
<Content>Fabulous Trip We recently traveled to the Grande Paradise. I was skeptical after reading so many negative reviews. I really hated to think of what I might be getting myself into. But I decided to go with an open mind as I believe that anywhere I travel is going to be a beautiful experience if I give it a chance and any place away from home and work can't be all that bad. We were not disappointed. Negatives reviews must be written by people who expect way more than what they are paying for. How could this beach be described as anything but magical. The review that said there were rocks everywhere must not have been in the water at Grand Paradise. There are so few rocks, you actually have to look for them and absolutely no shells. Plenty of chairs and cabanas for shade. The water is so clear it is unbelievable. The breeze blows all the time so it was very comfortable. Alot of topless women, but hey, try it because you can, and enjoy how liberating it feels!The staff are all pretty friendly. I agree that if you speak Spanish they are more friendly and usually serve them first at the bars. Lots of Europeans, but they all speak English, can you speak French or Italian or Spanish? Very friendly and alot of fun to talk with. Not much selection on drinks or alcohol. Rum is good if you like sweet fruity drinks, beer is good but only one selection.No much in the way of activities in the evening. Never went to a show as they all started at 9:30 and after a day of fun in the sun and drinking, was pretty worn out and didn't really want to sit in an uncomfortable chair to watch a show. Lights are very, very dim. What can you do. After a day of very bright light and heat, dim is not so bad on the eyes when relaxing in the room. Can't read in there but do that on the beach. At least the light over the sink was the brightest. Food at the buffet was good. I loved the European flair of meats, cheeses, pates and breads! Fruit at every meal. There was always something to eat that I liked. Only complaint is that there was NO A/C in the buffet dining room for the first 2 or 3 days. At least that is what it felt like. It was so hot that you either didn't feel like eating or ate very fast to get out of there. Went to 3 of the al a carte resturants, Sea Scape, La Cana and Italian. Don't waste your money on the Lobster night. The lobster is grilled, very little of it and it was dried out and burnt. The only one that I would recommend is the Italian. The most amazing Italian food ever. I agree that there is not food 24 hours a day and wanting anything to eat besides popcorn and nachos outside of dining hours is not going to happen. But you can always take food from the buffet back to your room and put it in the frig. Walking on the beach in either direction is so amazing. I just couldn't get enough of the views. So take your trip, if you like to relax, look at the most amazing beach, water and surroundings, remembing what it cost and know that if you are expecting more than what is offered at this resort that you will have to pay for it. If you are an uptight high maintenance person maybe another resort would better suit you.

We had trouble with air conditioning, room would never cool down. <Author>abacaxi
<Content>not-so-Grand-but-still-Paradise-Bavaro.....had a great time. Okay.....just returned from the Grand Paradise Bavaro. First things first...I am relaxed, tan and completely diarrhea free (and was for the entire trip). I had a great time. I think some of these negative reviews are by unreasonable tourists that either don't know how to have a good time, or were not realistic in what a three star hotel should look like. Please note that I am also American (important if you've been scared off by some of the THIS PLACE IS NOT FOR AMERICANS/AMERICANS DON'T GO posts). This place IS heavily populated by Europeans, so if you have a problem with that or are expecting American norms to apply, you should go ahead and book your trip to Kansas, lounge at the pool at the Howard Johnson and let that be the extent of your exotic travels.Prior to going on this trip (July 13-18th) I had gotten really freaked by some of the reviews, and was busily shopping for water purification tablets, mosquito netting, prophylactic antibiotics and wondering how I was going to pack my own sheets, towels and light bulbs as well as food and water for five days. In fact, for a few days prior to the trip, I was actually dreading my vacation (so many horror stories and reviews). Finally, I realized all my worrying was just dumb; my friend and I made up our minds that we were going to have a great time. I ended up just loading up on pepto (go to the CDC website for info on using pepto just-in-case to prevent travellers diarrhea)...it gave me great peace of mind. So...on to the good news. This place is a nice place to have a great trip, provided you are not expecting a 4 or 5 star experience.The rooms are clean; we had hot water, towels and fantabulous airconditioning. Our fridge was stocked with Coke, Sprite and a big jug of bottled water. The rooms are basic, and if tiny holes in the curtains or dust ruffles are going to --- you off.....try another hotel. Otherwise, bring your own lightbulbs or flashlights....the rooms ARE really dark....once the sun sets, the room is pretty dim, even with every lamp on. We did leave two dollars for the maid each day....why not? The hotel is clean....so I think you could go either way with tipping housekeeping. No theft, but we did pay for the room safe and had small locks on our suitcases....better safe than sorry...and that doesn't just apply in the Dominican Republic, right? The beach.....wonderful. Plenty of huts for shade, lots of chairs (although you will want to browse around....some of the chairs look like there is a 300 lb person in them even while empty). We did put our towels down before breakfast...but I am pretty manaical about my spot on the beach; people around us were coming and going, and there didn't seem to be a shortage of huts or chairs. Waves are gentle, water clear and unlike some of the other hotels on the strip, you don't have a hike to get to the water. From the hotel's beach, you can pass other hotel beaches, and I noticed that our water had less sea debris in it.....which was nice. Note....if you turn your towel in in the afternoon, you might not be able to get another, they run out sometimes. The staff.....okay. Honestly, if you speak spanish, you will fare better (but please note...you are a guest in a spanish speaking country). People are friendly enough, but if you are expecting someone to fawn over you and smile non stop, you might not be happy. Otherwise, no problems....people do try to accomodate you, and the front desk people do speak english.....less likely in the restaurants.The food. I don't want to say disgusting/horrible....because I didn't ever go hungry, but, there is a fair amount of bizarre and revolting looking dishes served. The food, in my opinion, is the least appealing aspect of this hotel. Breakfast is your best bet...fill up then, and you'll be okay with hunting around for the rest of the meals. Again, I didn't starve, but there were a few meals (dinner mostly) that were mostly fruit and bread based. My friend had better luck than I did....but neither one of us are really picky eaters (so if you are....all inclusive might not really be your best bet, because honestly, most really don' t ever have fabulous food). We didn't go to the specialty restaurants....the idea of eating asian influenced food when the basics looked sorta gross didn't seem like a smart move. The service in the restaurants ranges from fast hey...where'd my plate go to slow why are all the waiters sitting down taking a break. Getting a drink is probably the hardest thing. No, sorry. Getting a drink refill is the hardest thing. What usually happens is that your empty glass is whisked away by one of the singing waiters and never replaced.....so, don't guzzle, thinking that you will get instant refill. We didn't really tip at dinner, mostly because at the buffet at least, your service is not personalized, but consists of various people sweeping your empty plates off the table. Note....leave something small on the table so other guests can see that it is occupied. Too often people would get up for a fresh plate/second round and find that their table had been reseated with new guests. In final....would I go back? I'd rather try one of the other hotels....just because there are so many other experiences to be had. Nothing about the hotel made me want to make it my only destination in Punta Cana. Maybe after trying other hotels I'd grow to love this place enough to return season after season, but I like variety. This place is truly nothing special, but if you aren't picky, born to complain and know that a good time isn't always predicated on one thing....you'll do fine. I love being by the water, and didn't require much in terms of the hotel. The beach is wonderful, what I was hoping for, so I had a great time. I wouldn't steer anyone away from this hotel, but would recommend that you be sure of what you can and can't tolerate in terms of your accomodations. Do not go here if you are expecting to be treated like royalty, or have hopes of paying low budget prices for a surprise five star gem. The Grand Paradise Bavaro is a standard three star hotel with basic amenities, average staff and a lovely beach. Go...and don't be afraid.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Double check your room reservations before leaving! Let me first say that I didn't expect a 4 or 5 star resort and am very easygoing when on vacation. I'm not a chronic complainer and don't need much to keep me happy. We stayed at the Grand Paradise Bavaro from June 15-22, there were 17 in our group, ranging in ages from 7-60. After reading all the reviews about this resort I made sure our travel agent requested our group be placed in Building 6--on the beach at the main resort. Our tour operator was GoGo. The one thing we were adamant about is that we didn't want to be placed in The Club--we didn't want to have to take the tram to the main area everyday with 9 kids.When we arrived after the hotel (after a very long wait for our transfer) we were told to take the tram to the other side of the hotel. We tried to argue with the desk operators telling them we requested the main hotel area. We were informed that our reservations were at the Club. However, for $50 per person, per night, we could move to the main hotel. When we didn't take them up on their offer then we were told they could reduce it to $25 per person per night. $25 x 17 people. The men at the front desk are con artists. I heard this same story over and over again from other guests. We decided we would check out the Club. Basically, there is nothing at this end of the hotel. If you are there without children and don't care about not having the beach a few steps away--you might enjoy this quieter part of the resort. One pool, one a la carte restaurant and 2 bars, as far as I could tell.After 2 days of arguing with the staff at the front desk, my mother contacted guest services. They moved us all to the main resort immediately. I am a very easy going traveler and I don't sweat the small stuff but I have to say that the first two days of this vacation were complete and utter hell.Rooms: We were in Building 3. Not as good a location as Building 6 but it was close to the pool and the main lobby. The rooms were dark, which we antipated. The bathroom flooded a couple of times and we were without hot water or towels one day--not a very big deal. Rooms were a little run down, fridge not very cold. The AC seemed to work fine. The biggest problem we encountered with the room was the late night noise. The concrete hallway acted like an echo chamber and the other guests were really inconsiderate. Earplugs are a necessity--even for the heavy sleeper. The maids were very kind and accomodating--I left ours a tip and a little gift each day and never had to ask for something twice.Pools: The pools were nice, slightly scummy some days. The biggest problem I had with the pools were that although there were notices prohibiting topless bathing at the pool, dozens of women ignored this. I expected it at the beach but not around and IN the pool. I'm sure my 15 and 17 yo sons didn't care but to me it was just another example of foreign guests ignoring the rules and generally being rude. They smoked in no smoking areas, barged in front of people in line at the restaurants and bars. I found the French very obnoxious (and I hate stereotyping). I also thought the staff could have done more to entertain the kids. The activities revolved around the adults, meringue lessons, water aerobics etc. Our kids were mostly too old for the kids club but I think that when they should make an effort to include the teenagers in some activities.Food: I didn't have a problem with the food. No one in our group got sick. The breakfast got a little boring by the end of the week but there was always fresh fruit and cereal. Lunches were fine. We ate at both the Cana Grill and the buffet. We went to make dinner reservations at the ala carte restaurants and were told they couldn't accomodate a group of 17. We pointed out that they took the $ for a group of 17--then we were given reservations. I wasn't impressed with the ala carte restaurants at all. Italian was mediocre and Cana Grill horrible, orders were incorrect and the wait was awful. The Manglar (French) was very good.I thought the drinks were very watered down and they could use more staff at the bars.Hotel: The hotel buidings and grounds are very attractive. The Sports Bar could use a little updating and better AC, as could the gym. The lobby was beautiful, but on the last day we had torrential rains and the main lobby flooded very badly (imagine 6 men with giant sqeegees). I also agree with the person who said it was everyone out for themselves. There was no orientation (unless you want to sit through a timeshare spiel). You basically had to find out everything for yourself. A good brochure/map would have been a very handy thing.Punta Cana: The beaches are beautiful, as is the turquoise water. We took advantage of the water sports there, kayaking, tubing, banana boats etc. We also took the 2hr. horseback ride and bought gifts and clothing for the local children. That in itself made the trip worthwhile. If you go, don't forget the Dominican children. We went on an ATV trip as well (also lots of fun). The market outside the hotel gates is great but the vendors can be very pushy. If you are looking for braids, walk down the beach to the right. There is a really sweet woman on the beach and she is much cheaper than the hotel salon. Natasha (henna artist) is great at her craft and very interesting to chat with.We had a great family vacation in spite of our problems with the hotel. But I would not recommend this hotel to anyone.

<Content>The only review youll need  Most positive reviews you may read about this resort are most likely by those who are very easy to please. This is a very poor country, and ALL of the surrounding areas are very run down, and a great eye sore. Not the type of scenery that sweeps you away on the way to your resort. Infact, all the resorts are basically forts in a sea of poverty. You'll travel one minute on a gravel ridden road, and turn into your resort the next.It took us about an hour to check in when we arrived. They didn't seem organized. Our rooms were not entirely comfortable. We had a flooding problem in our bathroom. Anytime you took a shower, you'd have a pool of water on the floor, despite having adequite curtains to prevent the water escaping. There was some sort of leak, and all the floors were especially slippery when wet, so we almost fell a few times in the bathroom.One of thee worst factors in this was the food. It was absolutely atrocious. And the service was very poor as well. You would ask for a drink when dining, and never see your server again. There was also the issue of their 'VIP' people walking about. They were constanting in your face trying to sell you time-shares someplace. They didn't take no for an answer, so thank heavens for the language barrier. Their 'Sports Bar' was so second rate, that most watering holes at home would put it to complete shame. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Vacation Ever I travelled to Punta Cana with two of my friends aged 21 and 20 in May 2006. After reading the reviews we were a little worried about what the resort would be like...turns out any of the negative reviews were wrong.First of all the beach was amazing...we walked down the beach for an hour and we all agreed that Grand Paradise has the nicest beach. The sand is soft and white and the water is clear blue. Also, very clean and there was nothing in the water to step on.Food- I am a picky eater and there was always something that I could eat at each meal. If I didnt like the theme of the night there was always pasta which was really good. Also, we took Pepto Bismo twice a day (just in case) and we did not get sick the entire week and I have a sensitive stomach. We went to the Italian whihc was really good and went to the Dominican which was good, but not really to our usual taste.Drinks---We drank beer mostly the entire week which is Presidente and awesome. We also tried the special each day and had some pina colada's. Be aware drinks are measured by eye and we got some that were 3/4 alcohol and 1/4 mix. But no complaints on that at all!Rooms- Our room was on the bottom floor which we were a little sketchy about, but we were really happy with it. It was always clean and we felt safe the entire time. It was a little noisy because they do not have insulation like us, but nothing to keep you from sleeping. We were also close to the pools and didnt get woken up in the morning wiht people at the pool. Trips- We went on the snorkeling trip which was fun. It cost 30$ and was really neat to see...Mostly the same couloured fish but we enjoyed the trip regardless. If you have never done it I would recommend it. We also went to Maniti park and swam with the dolphins which was amazing. I would reccomend this, just be aware that some of the animals walk around the park looose!!!!!Finally, I will save the service for last as I can't understand how anyone could complain abou this. Dominican is a third world country and we recieved 1st class service the entire week. All of the workers were incredibly friendly and polite and tried to make our trip even better than it was. We always thanked them very much and we noticed some people being very rude to the workers and they did not receive the same service as us.All in all, I have NO complaints about this resort. Instead of worrying about the little things, enjoy yourself while on vacation. We went down there with certain expectation and they were met and surpassed during our stay.....WE WILL BE RETURNING TO THIS RESORT!!

Most resorts have designated areas for this-away from the rooms.I'll stop here but I could go on. In short, I'll say the beach is great, staff are friendly. <Content>Nice Vacation (could have been better) My family and I recently stayed at the Grand Paradise Resort in Punta Cana. The pool bar was awesome and the bartenders are very nice. An on-site grill or restaurant by the pool would have been great. There is always a tendency to snack at night. Oh, and here's a tip, make sure you have plenty of singles for tipping as singles seem to be scare on the island. Tipping is not required, but, it will sure make your experience a more pleasant one. Overall, it was a good vacation, but, it had the potential to be great. We are going again next year and trying a different resort.

Buy all accounts this is one of the smaller resorts in the area, which makes it even better, everything is very close, and the resort is very well laid out. My only knock against the resort is that making change for large $US bills is a pain in the butt, but thats my fault for taking them. All in all, I would say this resort is a great bang for your buck, you will meet people from all over the world, drink tons of rum and have way way too much fun.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Just what I needed My husband and I were at the resort from March 28-April 3. We went for fun and relaxation and were very pleased with our choice. The beach was great and there were always chairs available. The pool was great too. The pool at the club (travel their by trolley) has a swim-up bar. However, the main pool is likely to be more lively. Although there are rules prohibiting nudity at the pool, not everyone abides. My husband did not care, but some parents with children might have an issue with this. We especially enjoyed the pool bartenders: Nelson, Hector and Juan. TIP: bring a big cup for your drinks. We brought coke mugs (bought at Walmart). Many people in the resort recognized us by our jugs. And at the end of the stay, we sold them for $10 each! The bartenders filed them without hesitation. We tipped $5 the first day. They treated us like their best freinds the rest of the week. TIP: I recommend you buy the mama juana (Dominican Republic Viagra in a bottle) but make sure you have the rum in it (not just the roots) or you may have problems in customs.Food: we read the reviews and were cautiously optomistic. The buffet was fine. The omlettes in the morning are great. Try the chocolate milk, it has extra spices. Michaleangelos was excellent! Others said the steaks at Cana Grill were good. The seafod at seascape was decent and we sat at a table oceanside with a great view and a nice breeze. We heard that Asian restaurant was not so great. The french restaurant at the club had good food too. Note: we were seated outside. There were several French visitors and their host set up a gameshow right next to the restaurant. It was distracting and we felt like the waiters forgot about us. I would eat there again but I would eat inside!$$$: bring enough US dolars as the resort will not change pesos to $$$. Everyone seems to prefer US $$$. However, be prepared to pay $3 a day for the safe in your room. We each paid $10 to get into the country. We were told we would each have to pay $20 US to get out, but that did not happen. There is an ATM in the resort but it only gives pesos.Rooms: The DR has serious electricity shortages. All the lights in the room are the energy saver lights and therefore, it is quite dim. Our bathroom light was out, but they fixed it. The resort has enough towles for each room but not enought to restock: they take the towels and deliver them around 4PM. TIP: shower early and expect to be without towels during the day. You can get new beach towels everyday. We tipped the maid $5 the first day and she took good care of us.Front desk: it only took minutes to get checked in and the staff was very friendly. They sell internet cards: $5 for 30 minutes and $10 for an hour. TIP: Ask for a TV remote: it does not automatically come with the room. Booking agent: each person is assigned a greeter. There is a meeting up on the second floor of the main buildingthe day after you arrive. Fernando was our assistant. He gave excellent advice and booked our excursion. We went on the Jeep Outback Safari. It was great. We got to see how the DR people live, a cocoa plantation, went to a ranch, and used a boogie board in the ocean. $80pp. Fernando got us extra dinner reservation tickets.CAUTION: after your first meal at the buffet there will be others who approach you with VIP or Vacation shirts on. Thery are soliciting for time shares.Social Activites: the shows at the resort are hit and miss. There are usually dance lessons or games by the pool bar. The disco is fun but the men we met indicated there was not much chance of meeting anyone. Some of the firends we met went to Mangos: the disco in town. Be prepared to pay $12 each way for cab, $507 cover and $5 per drink. They danced there until 6AM. Several people went more than once so it must be fun! Have fun!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sunrise Punta Cana, D.R. I had read many of the reviews of the Grand Paradise before leaving with my wife, two daughters and son-in-law and frankly was concerned. We arrived in Punta Cana with no luggage. None for the five of us. They had overbooked the rooms and sent us to their second hotel/time-share area called The Club. It seemed things were going downhill fast. Our ground transportation was provided by Turinter and their representative, Noel, did everything possible to locate the luggage. With his assistance, the luggage arrived the following day on the next flight. The Club was a blessing in disguise. The rooms were very large with a jacuzzi. Our balcony faced east, so the items set out were dry by 9 AM. The pool at The Club had a swim up bar and the best bar was at the Mangler restaraunt area where they actually made mixed drinks. The other great bar was at the main hotel, upstairs. I believe I attended six bars in all. A train ran frequently to shuttle between the two resort locations. Not a big deal.Our standard breakfast was at the International where they served a continental style breakfast and you could also order off the menu. Excellent omelets. At the main resort a full buffet was available, we just did not feel like eating that much. We had supper twice at the International, once the Italian and once Chinese. Each exceeded my expectations, not gourmet, but very tasty. Service was great, not always fast, but always with a willing spirit. Fresh fruit at every meal. Take a pair or two of long pants for the evening sit down restaurants, no shorts allowed.The staff genuinely liked to be helpful. Most of the waiting and service people spoke English and French. They work long hours each day and 26 days a month. Tips of any size were appreciated though not expected. We took two dollar bills which got attention, they said it was good luck. Maybe it was good luck to get two dollars rather than one.The resort has a real european flair. Many French. We also met people from Canada, Lichtenstein, Germmany, Spain and Russia. Toplessness was practiced on the beach area, only seldom around the pools. Even at that, you had to look to find a topless bather. Frankly the beach and sea was so spectacular you did not notice.We drank the water provided with the meals and a fresh gallon of water was provided to our room each day. We re-filled our small bottles a few times. Dad used the imodium the last day, the others were fine.It is a great place to come if you are a couple or large family. They can accommodate either easily. Seating was never a problem.For those people who expect world class accommodations, with world class service and immediate attention to their every concern, don't come here. For that matter don't go anywhere I might be vacationing with my family. We went with the idea that this was going to be a great experience and relaxing vacation and it was. Thanks, Grand Paradise!
