<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great week overall! My boyfriend and I (28  27 years old) just returned from a week long stay at the Club Grand Paradise Bavaro, the adjoining hotel of the larger Grand Paradise Bavaro. We booked pretty last minute and got an AMAZING DEAL. Considering what we paid we had a great time. The hotel is rated a 4 star, but I felt it was more like a 3 and a half star, but definitely a good value! Here are some tips if you're looking to book:ROOMS 4/5-try and get a room on a higher floor FACING the pool, the pool view rooms are fantastic; jacuzzi, large bathroom, sitting area, balcony, mini fridge stocked daily w/ pop and water-always use the jug of water they leave you in the fridge; ensure it's replenished dailyFOOD 3.5/5-the restaurant Manglar International (a la carte), just steps away from the pool, is by far the best restaurant on the entire complex (compared to the Buffet at the Grand Paradise etc); we ate most of our meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) here because of it's convenience and the service at Manglar is EXCELLENT-for dinner you book reservations at the Terrace beside the restaurant; make sure to get there no later than 9:00am to book Manglar and the other a la cartes (Seafood, Italian etc) on the other side at Grand Paradise; get up early they book fast-the fruit juices at the bars are great too! -pool bar is great; note there's no pool bar at the Grand!-be aware that there are no snacks available on the Club side late at night so make sure you fill up at dinner or bring your own snacks from home (chips, chocolate) I had a craving for chocolate and had to pay $2.00 US for a chocolate bar at the gift shop-be aware that there are quite a few flies within the restaurants; it didn't bother me that much as i'm aware i'm in a tropical country, there's bound to be flies! don't worry too much about them. POOL  BEACH 4.5/5-although the beach is a trolley ride away it's worth it; the beach is probably one of the best i've seen GORGEOUS! BEAUTIFUL! -because the Club Grand Paradise is away from the beach it's quiet and there's room at the Pool! It can get quite busy but I found it to be nice and calm compared to the other side (Grand); it's nice to have the option to go to the beach one day and then stay at the Club pool the next SERVICE 4/5-the staff was fantastic and friendly! remember your basic spanish: hola (hello), gracias (thank you), por favor (please), cerveza (beer)-remember to bring lots of $1.00 US bills as tipping is allowed and you should do so if you feel that the service was good; we left a total of about $12.00 US for our maid throughout the week, well deserved! ENTERTAINMENT/NIGHTLIFE 3.5/5-the entertainment and activities staff are great; lots of options to do different things; no pressure if you just want to chill out-we went to the disco a few times and it was pretty dead; however our intentions on this trip were not to party! -piano bar at the Grand was a great place to sit and drink; sports bar had pool tables and a big screen, if you're significant other has to watch basketball playoffs, like mine! -Internet access available on the Grand side; need to buy access time at the Grand Paradise reception deskSICKNESS -my boyfriend did get sick throughout the trip, having to make several trips to the bathroom during the week; he did have stomach pains but I think that this is common amongst many Carribean third world countries-don't be startled if you get sick, it's part of travelling to these types of countries; remember to bring lots of Imodium Advanced AND Pepto Bismal with you from home - you don't want to have to buy them there as they are pretty pricey; better to be prepared; if you do get sick drink lots of fluids, not so much the water but reccommend the soda pop-oh yes, and bring bug spray if you're susceptible to being bit alot; you just need a little at night OVERALL 4/5-it's a great little resort where you can enjoy the amenities of the larger complex too (Grand); great place to stay if you want a quiet, chill out atmosphere-if you're paying well under the book prices $1200 + this resort is WELL WORTH THE MONEY!!!-if I get a chance to get the deal that we got, I would definitely go again! Hope this helps! Have a great trip, you'll have a blast!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>relaxing fun... I just returned last night from a one week stay at the Grand Paradise Bavaro. My boyfriend and I (24 and 25) planned this trip at the last minute and booked it a week before we were to leave because it was such a good deal. This is only my second trip to the caribbean and my first to the dominican. Here goes my review..... I went on this trip with abolutely no expectations..I was a little worried about some of the reviews that I had read, but decided to just see what happens and go with the flow. We arrived in Punta Cana at around 4:00pm and were taken to the resort. The bus ride is only about 20 minutes long and they are nice and air conditioned. Our check-in was smooth and we received a room in building 6 on the ground floor, which is right by the pool and the beach. The room was a standard hotel room with two double beds, a sitting area, night table, dresser with a television set. There was a small patio that had two chairs and a table. The bathroom had a sepearte area with a sink and large mirror, full closet (the safe and iron were located in here) and then a doorway led to the shower, bathtub, and toilet. There were no major problems with the room, but soon discovered a leak above the shower, our sliding door did not lock properly and the closet door was broken. I was a little worried about the lock problem, but everything else did not bother us one bit..we were on vacation. The grounds of the resort were beautiful..there is a pond with ducks, turtles, fish, and frogs. There are a ton of mature palm trees and the beach is two steps away. The beach is AMAZING!!! the water was the perfect temperature and there were a ton of palapas and beach chairs. We were late risers and had no problem finding a spot with shade. There were plenty of activities to do throughout the day. I played ping pong, volley ball, badminton, and we rented the boogie boards for the ocean. The entertainment staff had something going on all time and if you weren't interested in participating there was no pressure. At night the staff put on a different show every night at 9:30pm and then the disco would open at 11:00pm. I didn't go to every show, but I would have to say the bravissimo show was the best. I had a lot of fun at the disco and it was pretty busy. The drinks were pretty strong at this resort, so there was no need to drink a ton. I found that the most relaxing spot was the piano bar that was located above the lobby. There was always live music and plenty of places to sit. Now for my complaint.....the food!! There was an adequate choice, but I did notice that there was a lot of repeats. I found it hard at dinner time to try to find something that i really enjoyed. I am definitley not a PICKY eater and I love food, but near the end of my vacation all I could do was think about what the first thing is I am going to eat when I get home. We met quite a few people and the majority was sick with some sort of stomach problem including myself and my boyfriend. I was out of commission for one night, due to stomach problems. The A La Carte restaurants were however spectacular...my fave was the Italian. The only problem is you have to wake up at 8:30am to make reservations. All in all I did enjoy my vacation. It was what I was looking for because I just wanted to spend time on the beach. Also, I received a very good deal for this trip..if i had paid more i may be a bit more disappouinted. I think that if this resort improved it's food...I would go back in an instant..no questions asked.

<Author>the_person
<Content>Absolutly great, a truthful review... This was my first ever time in the Dominican Republic or even the Caribbean for that matter and I must admit this was one of the best holidays I have ever had, our group of 5 only stayed for a week (23rd May to the 30th May) though but 2 would have been ideal to experience everything the resort had to offer. Before travelling to the DR, you must acknowlege that this is a 3rd world country and much of the area is developing as you will find during the transfers from Punta Cana airport; do not expect it to be anything like you would find in America, Canada, UK etc. Also opinions can only be based upon your own personal experience and my overall thoughts about this resort will differ from yours, I can only give you a rough example of what to expect. Also keep in mind that I went in low season where there is low occupancy, if your travelling in high season then keep in mind that service will be a lot different.After reading other reviews of this resort, I found them to be quite in-accurate, otherwise the people that wrote them must be extremlely fussy indeed; making a mountain out of a molehole. As I stated before, do not expect 1st class as this is a developing country. Try not to take everything onboard that people say about this place, I did and I was very apprehensive about going but thoroughly enjoyed it in the end :-D. There is one thing I would definetly recommend, carry most of your money in dollar notes and 10 dollar notes; great for tipping people, also if you try to pay taxis, shops etc they always say they have no change so you have to pay extra (they always do have change but want money for themselves, especially the woman in the gift shop who is also VERY grumpy, don't tip her)AIRPORT - 5 out of 5 - Punta Cana airport is absolutly beautiful; all made out of stone with thatched palm roofs. After stepping off the plane we entered arrivals and had our photo taken with Dominican women in traditional outfits, they also play live Merengue music in the background. I would advise you to have a pen ready by this point to fill in your $10 entrance visa. Everything ran smoothy and was very well motivated, we collected our bags of the carousel without even having to wait, then its through customs and your out. If you are going to travel to your resort by taxi, $22 is a reasonable price but be warned, the ride is very nerve racking!ROOMS - 4 out of 5 - Rooms were always clean, bright and colourful and had luxury amenities such as the minibar, cable TV, hairdryer, air conditioning. There was nothing to be complained about the rooms but it is money well spent to tip the maid about $2 per day as she will always leave swans made out of towels, flowers and make sure your minibar is always full and give you new and clean bedding, towels etc. There are construction works going on next door but I can honestly tell you this will NOT affect your holiday in any way, the building can hardly be seen from the your resort. Buildings one and two do face the construction but noise and pollution does not seem to be a factor affecting them in anyway. If you do feel you need to move to a seperate building, staff would be happy to help If you stay polite, happy and do not raise your voice. A small tip would also be very much appreciated. Also take into credit that you will not be spending all of your time in your room.FOOD  DRINK 4 out of 5 - Food was fantastic all round, uspet stomachs and food poisoning is none existent here as we met nobody with any problems. We all did experience 'jiffy' stomachs but we put it down to climate change, alcohol consumption, not drinking enough water and change of diet but definetly not bad food. All food in the buffet was great, they do try to cater for everybody and make gourmet food; always piping hot with steam billouing off. You can design your own pastas for dinner and have them freshly cooked by the chefs, design your own omelettes for breakfast, make toasties, toast, everything you can think of, they have. Do try to get there earlier than later (we went around 7.30pm) and food was fantastic, but once we went a bit later and there was not as much variety (but still great!) Decor in the buffet if gorgeous, everywhere is decorated in some way, even the cakes that looked to good to even cut! We never really tried the restaurants as we were never up early enough to get reservations, we only went in low season so it was a lot easier to get reservations, try to be there at around 8.50 and one is guaranteed. We did try the Italien, I had the Lasagne Napolitana which was amazing, definetly top class restaurant style and I can more than recommend it. I have heard that all other restaurant are fab and they all offer special nights such as barbeque night ( La Cana grill) and Lobster night (Seafood Restaurant). Drinks were great too, the beer was a local called Presidente, usually draft but still tasted nice. If you tip the barmen and be polite to them they may give you a bottled one if you ask. Also the cocktails are nice, especially the Tequila Sunrise but beware, all the cocktails are strong! Beware that the La Cana grill is open air so flies can be a problem, do not let them bother you and keep your food covered when your not looking; nothing can really be done to stop this. Also if you are the curious type, it is safe to have ice in your drinks because they ALWAYS use bagged ice, they do also water the wine down sometimes but not always; they always use bottled water.SERVICE  STAFF - 5 out of 5 - Some people are nice, some people are really grumpy; try to tip the people that offer you the best service as they do remember you and gives them an incentive to pay even more attention to you. Practically everybody in the resort was more than friendly and a simple 'Hola' can make a big difference although they always seem happy and in a good mood. The barmen in the Sports Bar were really funny and sociable, especially Pablo and Raulyn who deserve a big juicy tip now and then. I do hear the resort is under new management and has vastly changed, making a lot of the other reviews obselete because of the massive improvements, I never encountered any problems with service although the Receptionists can get stuck in Manyana sometimes; just stay patient :p The waiters also seem to help with the entertainment and do an absolutely fantastic job, they do karaoke, dance routines, magic shows and 'Who is the best Maria?' which was side splittingly funny. There is also a waiter there that is also a stand up comedien; very funny (MUAHAHAHAHA! You will know what I mean when you get there :P lol)POOL  GROUNDS - 5 out of 5 - Grounds are very well kept with towering palm trees and tropical plants, everything is colourful with lush green grass. Everthing is always clean with no litter. The pools are definetly a highlight of this resort, there are four to choose from, always clean clean and well kept. There were ALWAYS sun loungers and umbrellas as the pools were always empty, there were always activities there such as Salsa lessons, Volleyball, absolutely loads (theres also a kiddy club for the kiddies). There are also hair brading, massage and henna tatoo stands around the pool area. Absolutelty no complaints here, nothing can be improved it's the best of the best.BEACH - 10 out of 5!!! - This is the ultimate Caribbean beach, it's almost like the front page of a brochure! There were always hundreds of spare sunbeds and Papulas, no need to get up early as there was always a big choice! There is one thing that you must know is that the waves are extremely powerful, great for watersports but I would not advise young children or elderly to venture in; a short walk past the ship wreck where there are no waves at all is ideal. Kayaking can also be quite dangerous, only be prepared to take on this 'challenge' if your a very strong swimmer. I would definetly recommend the speedboat down the island, there are some truely Carribean sights down there, I saw secluded white sand beaches and blue lagoons (better than the Maldives :O). I would not recommend the Parasailing as I heard it was very dear and not worth the money. Snorkeling is definetly a must, walk up towards the right hand side of the beach and walk up to the small pininsula next to the beach bar, there are some shallow rocks that are absolutely teaming with tropical fish! Remember to take some popcorn, banana or bread for the fish as they come and take it right out of your hand! Be careful of the sea urchins that are on the floor and do NOT put your feet down as a sting could be extremely painful, there are also fish there that can be quite intimidating but I am pretty sure their harmless; there was one that I saw that had an extremely sharp nose almost like a Samurai sword and swim extremely fast, do not get in their way!WEATHER 5 out of 5 - The weather all depends on what time of year you go, although the DR has more or less constant temperatures all year round; rain and hurricanes are more or a variable factor. Low season runs from May to October which I think it is probably the best time to go, June being the best because there is no risk of hurricanes, monsoons, relatively low rainfall and low hotel occupancy. August to September is hurricane season and is not advisable to go because of sweltering temperatures and the risk of a hurricane. I did hear that there were days of endless rain before we traveled to the Punta Cana but ended the very day we got there, we had hardly any rain at all, clear skies, 32 degrees celcius days everyday but extremely high humidity making that temperature feel like the mid 40's. Air conditioning in your room is more than sufficient to keep the room cool all day and night and experienced no problems at all with the heat at night. The Sun is extremely strong all year with a UV factor of around 11 (which is classed as extreme in UV rating terms), I would recommend a minimum of 30SPF which is recommended by skin specialists for this type of climate for the first few days and work down to a minimum of 15SPF once a tan has started to develop. I used a low factor and burned extremely bad so be VERY careful. High season is from October to April, there is very low rainfall between these months and more comfortable temperatures ranging from 27-30 degrees celcius in Punta Cana. Remember to try and seek shade between the hours of 11.00am and 4.00pm where the sun is at its strongest and drink plenty of water. Also try not to take any notice of the forecasts as they are always inaccurate.Each and every single aspect of this hotel is great, keep in mind that a tip goes a very long way with staff and be polite and friendly, treat them the way you would like to be treated and I can guarantee you will get along great with them. Also acknowlege that this is a third world country and is in early stages of development; do not expect it to be too luxurious and this resort is what you make of it, try to keep a happy face :P. The resort also seems to be very popular with weddings as I saw 2 in one day, so if your travelling for a wedding or a honeymoon your definetly well catered for and seem to have a lot of experience at these occasions by the looks of the amazing decor they had there. Also as a precaution, it is advised to have Hepatitis A and B, Polio  Typhoid, Dengue Fever, Teburculosis and Malaria immunizations; although not compulsory it's probably is better to have them and be sure although you will probabaly never come across them, there has been a recent health warning for Malaria around the Punta Cana region, try to use an insect repellent with DEET and if you are going to use Malaria tablets; use Chloroquin because they have less side effects such as stomach upsets. None of our group felt we needed to have these immunizations and just used the insect repellent, I never even got bitten once with that stuff on! If you need any information at all please contact me on the attached email address and I will be in touch as soon as possible otherwise have a fantastic time at this great resort! Best Regards.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Grand Paradise is typical for Punta Cana A group of 10 stayed at the Grand Paradise for 1 week. Overall I enjoyed my stay at the resort but saw very little difference from the other two Punta Cana resorts I've stayed at. First was the Barcelo Bavaro and the second was Breezes. If you dropped me in any of these resorts I wouldn't be able to tell which one I was at when it came to food, service, rooms, and beach.The Grand had a great easily accessible layout and the resort itself wasn't that large. We only had one person get sick, really sick but she could have brought that with her according to her doctor at home. My last two trips to the Dominican saw more than one from our group get ill and we didn't stay at the Grand. I believe it's each persons reaction to the different food, spices, oils, and general preperation that makes them ill. That's not to say some food my be under cooked, spoiled from sitting out too long or whatever. Every one of the 3 resorts I've stayed at in the Dominican had open air buffets so nobody can tell me this resort is unique in that way.The buffets couldn't keep up with the demand for their roast chicken so it never sat for more than a few minutes at most. Fries were always hot and fresh. If you get sick here then you have an equal chance of getting sick at any Punta Cana resort.The beach was beautiful, the staff were really friendly to us, the speciality restaurants were great especially the Italian, and Chinese. The room was clean and everything worked. The maid service was prompt, and very friendly. Our group consisted of a 23 y/o, 26, 28 y/o, 33x2, 35, 39x2, 45, 50. You can't get a much broader range of ages than that and we all had a great time even the one person that was sick for 3 days. We never really checked out the evening entertainment but heard it was your typical resort style. The disco was busy and the music was great, lots of variety.Not one this about this resort surprised me. Everything I researched was as I anticipated. When you do your homework you won't be disappointed. We drank out of 52oz mugs all week and never had one problem.Hope you enjoy your stay.

<Content>An Incredible week we'll never forget My wife and I and another couple stayed at the GPB from Apr/04 - Apr/11 and the week was one of extreme enjoyment. We also read all the negative reviews and honestly, I was a bit worried since I learned of this site AFTER we had booked. Thank God I did because I might have changed my mind. I truly can't understand how anyone could possibly knock this hotel and the staff that work there. I will break down my review into sections. Here goes....SERVICE: As soon as we arrived (around 1:00 pm) our bags were put aside for us and assured us they were safe in the lobby. While we waited in line at the desk to register (about 5 mins tops) we were given our bracelets and served a drink (What a terrible resort! LOL). When we got to the desk to register the man was joking with us, had a huge smile, told us our room wouldn't be ready till around 3:00pm, but we could go get something to eat and check back later. He shook my hand, thanked me for choosing his resort, and sent us on our way. ROOMS: There is constuction going on next to the resort, but only beside one of the six buildings, so you may want to ask for a certain building when you book. We stayed in building 4 which we thought was just fine. The rooms were very clean, floors mopped every day, and the fridge well stocked with coke, sprite and water. The maid was extremely nice. A tip I should give is to leave money daily and not all at once, as the maids usually change mid week. We left $2 a day along with some little things my wife picked up (hair clips, razors, crayons, stuff like that). If you smile and ask how they are instead of just walking by, you will be amazed at the level of hospitality these people have. We didn't see any ants in our room, even though we did do some snacking in there. I really can't complain at all about the rooms.BEACH: One word INCREDIBLE!!!!!!!Tip: If you want a cabana, you better be at the beach by 8:00am. (not by 6:00am as it says in other reviews)POOLS: The pools were very clean, very refreshing when laying in the sun for a period. I found there was enough chairs, although not always the spot you really want but who cares? The pool bars moved very fast. I tipped the waiter a few bucks the first day, but really there was no wait even if you didn't tip. Tip anyway though! The only negative thing I can say is that you couldn't swim after 7:00pm. It would've been nice to take a late night dip a couple of nights. Really no big deal though.NIGHTLIFE: The animation team was amazing!! They organized beach games in the day and then put on an incredible show at night. My wife was amazed at all the beautiful costumes they had. It was really first class!!! There was comedy in between acts with karaoke every second night before the show started. After the show ended the Disco would open. We went 2 nights and had a really good time.ATMOSPHERE: We totally loved the atmosphere at the GPB. We met some really nice people and the staff were so friendly. We really bought in to the Dominican time thing. The whole week was both fun and relaxing all in one.FOOD: The food at this resort was actually pretty good. They do cook with a different oil though, which does have a different affect on different people. My wife and I had no problem, but as for the other couple we went with, she was o.k. but he wasn't LOL. Let's just say he used up some immodium LOL. Like i said, it affects different people in different ways. You will probably know how it will be after the 1st day. The Al-A-Carte restaurants will take bookings from 9am till 11am (get in line by 8am)and you can only book for that day(new rule). The Italian restaurant was by far the best, with the steakhouse coming second, then the chinese. When staying at the GPB you can take the trolley over to the GP Club and enjoy everything they have as well. DO THIS!!! While the buffet at the GPB is good, lunch at the club is excellent! You are seated and a waiter takes your order. It's like an al-a-carte without a reservation. People, don't be fooled by those who say the food is terrible, because we all had no problem finding something we liked every day.Overall I can easily say that the Grand Paradise Bavaro was an excellent choice for us and everyone we spoke to at this resort felt the same way. I guess if your looking to be treated as upper royalty and you want your feet kissed this may not be the place for you (LOL) because this is the only reason I can figure someone would write a abd review of this place. <Content>Great time in Punta Cana The Grand Paradise was a great place to stay for a first time visit to Punta Cana. The resort was very nice and clean. The Beach is just a small walk away. The workers are very friendly and not overbearing. We found the variety of food to be a little different than the average American buffet but there was plenty of food to keep you full. Myself and three friends went and we are definitely going back to stay longer (we only stayed 4 days). The beach is beautiful (even with little fish swimming by your feet in the ocean). Market place shopping was in walking distance. I would definitely recommend this hotel to anyone going to Punta Cana. Make sure to visit Mongu Club. Great place to dance and socialize. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Time at the Grand Paradise Bavaro!!! Well, I read many reviews here and after careful review of all of them, I decided to see it all for myself. While I respect everyone's opinions, my philosophy is that you cannot always go by what other people say. There is no better substitute than experience! I was at the Grand Paradise Bavaro from 3/11-3/16, 2005 which makes this approximately 2 weeks ago. I must say that when I arrived there the staff at the reception area was very friendly and hospitable. We got our keys and towel cards right away. We also requested a lock for the safety deposit box which was rented to us immediately for $20.00 US. The price covered rental for 7 days. The bell boy took our luggage upstairs right away and as it is in our custom, we tipped him 3 dollars. Let it be known that while tipping is not necessary, it is often very appreciated as the wages for most hotel staff are not that great and most of them rely heavily on tips.The restaurants were generally good, however I would really recommend the Italian restaurant as the ambiance and general atmosphere was quite pleasant. The food was really good (try the spaghetti as well as the lasagna, you'll be glad you did!). The Asian restaurant was good, but not something to be crazy about although as mentioned for the Italian restaurant, the decor and atmosphere was really nice. La Laguna restaurant (buffet) was good and service was excellent given that the waiters were really attentive to your needs. They were also very flirtatious (all you women out there, beware of these predators! lol), but nice. I liked the fact that there were many choices and selections. For breakfast they had the typical American Breakfast and then there was the typical Dominican breakfast (for example Mangu, which consists of mashed plantains as well as fried cheese which reminds one of mozarella cheese.) The pasta bar was appetizing and also an option when you didn't feel like eating anything else. The Pana Grill served lunch and is right by the beach. I must say that out of all the four restaurants, I found this one quite disappointing as SOME STAFF not all (let's be fair) were indifferent and ignored me. I requested some napkins and a coke and was ignored. It wasn't until I signaled one of the waiters with my arm that I was taken care of. He was really nice and apologized for the inconvience. The food was well, ok for the most part. The beach was gorgeous, but the waves were rough. I've been to many beaches including Mexico and other parts of the Caribbean, and I must say these waves are wicked! lol. Don't let go of your guard no matter how much of a good swimmer you are!The pools were fabulous and pretty. What I liked was that the water wasn't cold. It was nice and warm and the area was perfect for a nice nap under the palm trees. The breeze here is great in the afternoon. I liked the drinks and I suggest that you try the Banana Mama and Coco Loco.If you want nightlife, it is worth the $12.00 US to take a cab to other clubs in other resorts. Two I recommend is Areito and Mangu. Just ask the cab driver. He'll know where to go. Just ask the reception area staff and they'll call a cab for you. I didn't go to the hotel disco because I wasn't too crazy about the music. Overall, I found the hotel and hotel grounds to be very pretty and the staff very hospitable. I did get a little sick to my stomach but it wasn't something that Pepto Bismol and Immodium AD could not relieve. You have to be careful with what you eat and use common sense and judgement. This isn't a five star hotel, you get what you paid for and that's what counts. You have to be optimistic and not let yourself get discouraged by other reviews. Everyone has different experiences. I for my part am dying to go back again!!

<Content>A Very Relaxing Vacation Spot My fiance and I visited this resort in early March and found this was a wonderful vacation spot.Resort - This is a beautiful resort that is kept very clean. We had no complaints with the room service - there was always clean towels, bottled water and pop in our rooms. The staff are very accommodating and try to make your stay as enjoyable as possible. The rooms are comfortable and air conditioned. There are also many activities to join in so you can do as much as you want or as little as you want. Food - We ate mostly at the buffet because we preferred the convenience of being able to eat whenever you wanted. We never had a problem finding something that appealed to us. The best time to go to the buffet for dinner is when it first opens. The staff are lined up greeting their patrons with applause. They are also right there to serve you wine with your dinner. We chose not to go to any of the a la carte restaurants, mainly because we didn't want to be tied into a reservation. Many people we met did go to these restaurants and really enjoyed their meals. Beach - This is definitely a 5-star which is where we wanted to spend the majority of our time. You can walk for hours up and down this beach. The cabanas are very popular and it's best to go to the beach early if you want to get one.Shopping - We just did a little shopping at the end of our Catalina Island tour. We had heard that this wasn't a good place to go if you wanted to do any shopping. Tours - We chose to only go on one tour because we wanted to spend as much time as possible at the resort. We went on the Catalina Island tour which we would highly recommend for anyone that is interested in doing any snorkelling. The day was a little long but it was definitely worth it.This was one of the most relaxing vacations we ever had and we would definitely go back.

<Author>LindaC
<Content>Are Your Expectations Too High? I was at the Grand Paradise at the beginning of March and found the hotel to be just what we expected. A 4*. If you are going to Cuba or Dominican you should know that a 4 star here is not a 4 star in Canada. We were at Sandals in Cuba in November and other than the room (Sandals was a suite) there was not a lot of difference. We found the food basically the same at the resorts. I was happy eating omelettes and pasta and typically don't eat anything different even if I was on vacation in the US. My husband tried everything and we were never sick at all. We have visited many resorts and found the staff at this one, the best. The guy making omelettes actually was making 4 or 5 at one time, unlike some who only cook one at a time at other places. The bartender at the beach bar was quick, friendly and called out to people in the line so they could be served quicker. There is pop and lots of water provided in your room fridge and never had any trouble with towels or the room getting clean. The rooms need updating and we noticed that there was painting in one of the areas being started. We initially did not like the location of our room so they moved us the next day to a room around the pool. The front desk went out of their way to accomodate. The shows here are some of the best. I paid $860.00 plus tax so was very satisfied. If you want a low key resort, with a beautiful walking beach, a place to lay your head at night, go here.

<Author>Constantine-TA
<Content>Good value for the money We spent a week at Grand Paradise, between March 12 and 19. Generally, we had a great time. We decided to breakdown our comments by area:Check-in: Very quick, very professional. We could check into our room right away, and our luggage was delivered within 5 minutes.Room:Very attractive, though the king size beds didn't have bottom sheets that tucked in - it's amazing where sheets end up! Mini-fridge always stocked with water and soft drinks. Room was usually cleaned promptly and well.Grounds: Very well maintained, lush and clean swept. Unfortunately there's a construction site next door - new resort going up - and sometimes the noise, dust and diesel fumes were noticeable, especially at the far end of the beach.Beach:Excellent quality. Always enough available loungers and shelter umbrellas. Lots of fish to see, and warm, clear waves. Beach was clean - seaweed raked up, glasses/garbage cleared regularly. Water was sometimes a little rough though. Food:Sometimes a little bland but otherwise delicious, especially the Dominican selections. A varied selection at the buffet restaurant, and the theme evenings were interesting. A la carte restaurants are a bit of a waste of time, though the atmosphere at the Cana Grill was just wonderful. As we spent the week at the beach, lunch was usually at the snack bar - a bit of a disappointment for some food items (eg hot dogs weren't!) but quick and casual.Drinks:Bars never had too much of a lineup, and there were lots of kinds of drinks available. More drink menus would have been helpful.Excursions:We only went on one excursion - a shopping tour to Higuey. It was excellent - a tour guide is Manfred (Moppel) from Germany, who has spent over 30 years in DR. He is very knowlegable and his all-day tour was interesting and insightful. We'd recommend it, but make sure you bring shopping money. Our tour operator didn't tell us that this is a real shopping excursion - lots of stops, different goods - we should have brought more money. The tour really provided a fascinating look at life in Higuey.Swimming pool:Although we hung out for the most part at the beach, the pools were very attractive, with available chairs around. Our room overlooked the pool, and I was impressed with the constant care, clarity of the water and welcoming atmosphere around the pool.Staff:Generally very friendly, helpful and accomodating. We tend to stick just to ourselves on holiday - we're on vacation to quietly relax - and apart from the annoyingly insistant people flogging the VIP club memberships outside the buffet restaurant, staff really picked up on our 'vibe'. Communicating was easy - most staff spoke English or French (or both and more!) to an extent that we could make our requests very clear.

<Author>catamaranmountie
<Content>I will not return Tour op (Sears Canada - Air Canada Vacations) rates this a 4 star; I'd give it a 2.5, my wife says a 3 at best.It was a reasonably priced vacation so we bought it as rated; after calls to the tour operator, and the hotel itself, to confirm that it had Hobie Cats to sail. This is a neccessity when I go on vacation. We accepted the idea of a 4 star instead of 5, because we were taking our kids (grown) and thought we'd try a little lower rated hotel and try to have less expectations and just accept a relaxing spot; this is a smaller site.OUR FINDINGS:Most of the negative reviews in this site, are accurate, or contain mostly accurate assessments.The water sports (all of it) uses old, poor condition items; some of the equip looks like sharks got at it. They only have 2 Hobies to sail. They have three windsurfers. Aprox 10 Boogie boards; 4 are in good condition. They have several kayaks; 3 or 4 are singles, they have what looks like 3 worn out doubles. The singles are in reasonable shape.The Hobies have worn standing rigging, and running rigging, complete with broken strands, open braid, missing bolts, and the rudder hardware is completely worn out; you must wrestle with the tiller to keep the rudders down on the posts. (I sailed both boats that day, they are nearly identical in condition.) the sail on the white boat is in rough condition; the multi-coloured sail is a better piece; try to take that boat.You can only book one hour with a piece of equipment per day. My first Recommendation: DO NOT COME HERE IF YOU WANT TO USE WATER SPORTS. This condition is a year round condition (big surf, good breeze) and is excellent sailing ground; but this resort will not allow you to sail in good sailing conditions. They want very calm water, with little wind.By comparison, the Bahibe Principale next door, sailed every day we were there, and had enough equipment that there was always something left on the beach to use. I also inspected their equipment; it all looked new or nearly new. Very good condition.Water sports are only permitted on average 1 day out of 7. Over a three week stay (another guest) we learned that sailing was permitted only 1 day (the day we sailed). The staff at the watersport booth, will not listen to you, they say 'weather not good' and do not let you have anything. In summary (water sports) this resort lists and has equipment solely to obtain an increased star rating from the tour operators; this is a very bad part of the resort, and it will suck severely if you went there to sail (like I did). I can't stress enough; after investigating I learned this is normal; the resort does not have water sports to actually make your stay more enjoyable, they have it solely for the rating; not to be mistaken as being there for your use. They DO NOT like to let their equipment out. (To be as fair as I can, the surf and wind, are for experienced sailors; but this should be handled by the resort by advertising that the water sport equipment is for experienced sailors only; no beginners; that would warn guests who are researching a potential resort. - But then they should allow experienced sailors and kayak enthusiasts to use the equipment.)Snorkling; I recommend you bring your own gear; their trips are expensive; some of the snorkeling is good, but the area is extremely dangerous once you are away from the roped off swimming area. Do not snorkel away from the beach on your own; the resorts boat staff are extremely dangerous; this is a deadly area, they drive motor boats like mad-men. They do not use a lookout for powerboat towing (para-sailing, banana boating, tubing, etc.) and all this costs money. I saw them lose tubers and banana-ers several times, and travel down half the beach length before they would even figure out they had empty tubes or bananas behind them. They WILL kill someone down there someday; just don't get out there where they can hit you, and the victim won't be you.The rooms: Reasonably clean. Towels are scarce; you may have to ask for enough for your guests. The water is hard to get sometimes, you might have to hunt down a Maid's cart and steal it. In your fridge you may get two coke, two sprite. Not always replaced you may have to hunt this down too. The light bulbs look like 5 watts. They don't tell you on arrival that the room power only works with the room key in the time-lock. You need to get two key cards. Our kids had a key card fail every single day. We only had one fail, on one day (get replacements at the front counter).We learned our new favourite expression 'not today, maybe tomorrow' spoken with a Spanish accent. Staff do not speak English, except for key members, who speak only very limited English. Don't be too fancy, for example, don't say 'just put a little rum in my drink'. Use hand symbols and basic English 'little bit alcohol'. I heard a lot of drinkers struggling with this concept.No towel service; you HAVE to get there early, and never turn it in untill you have another in your hand. (that's beach towels) You won't get face cloths. You will have to pester the maid in order to get two hand towels. You will probably get two bath towels in the bathroom. This service is not consistent; we had friends who had better service (enough towels everyday, extra toilet paper, swans, etc.) Some of the maids smile and say Ola; some don't even blink at you. We all tipped a couple dollars, every day, plus gifts on the pillow. Tips did not seem to affect the service quality one way or another. for example, our kids couldn't even get their glasses changed consistently from day to day.The basic cleaning is fairly competent; beds are cleaned, floor etc. Don't expect the ceiling to be clean, or your lampshades, the A/C vents etc. They will have stains, cobwebs and dust. Door fitments are poor, carpentry skills are apparently absent etc. They fill gaps with caulking.The (lack of) service basically, is the largest drawback to this hotel. Our stay was not horrible, we had decent time, but we will never return. A last comment about the ala carte restaurants. You must book at 9 am on a given morning, they recommend you book your restaurants for the whole week; you do this at the reservation desk in the Bar and Grill. I strongly recommend that you do not go to these. they only allow about 40% bookings; they won't accept walk ins, and only a couple tables are allowed to book per sitting (based on every half hour). The menus at each of these, are limited to the extreme. (one page per restaurant - one appetizer, a couple entree's, and very limited deserts.) If you go, do not expect to get what you want. At the Chinese one, we asked for an extra eggroll, (1 inch around, by 2 inch long; very small). Each guest is only allowed one as an appetizer. The head waiter got very mad at our waiter when he tried to apologize, and bring the kids a couple chicken-on-a-stick appetizers, in place of the egg roll request. You are only supposed to get one -chicken on a stick ka-bob- per guest. The main dishes were not good.Don't order hamburger at the grill. Don't order fish anywhere unless you brought strong anti-biotics (we did, and at the first urgent visit to the throne room, we took it; this handled the sickness quite well).Another bad example; with a hamburger (our first day) we tried to get some ketchup. It was 5 minutes before closing; we were told 'sorry; maybe tomorrow'. For eating, we strongly recommend you stick to the Buffet; good variety, not great but good. You should find something to eat every day. This might get old though, if you stay more than a week. The deserts are very good. There isn't a tender steak to be had on the property; their best is still tough (but tasty). The veggies were very good.The grounds are nicely kept; we thought the pool (cool on first immersion) was very clean; but there is no shade; do not go there until the sun starts to go down or you will burn badly (we went around 4 pm each day).Get to the beach early; get your seats reserved under a hut, or you will burn badly.Do not go out in the sun if you have to take any sun-sensitive medication (for the craps etc.); this might hurt you; the sun is wonderfully powerful; but very dangerous. Pay heed to the medications' warnings. Wear lots of sun block; you will still tan.We travel extensively; some places we recommend; this one we do not. If you go, be prepared for poor service, even by Caribean standards; the service is the worst part; but if the price is right for you, and you are looking for a nice spot to sit for a week and watch the surf; this might be your spot; just don't go with expectations of a 4 star resort.The site itself is beautiful; the beaches, sand, sun, great surf for body surfing etc., ocean water is wonderful. It is however, a bit cooler than places like Huatulco, Mexico. The hotel says that the water is 27 degrees C.I hope you find this helpful.Our recommendations for a better vacation resort on this scale: the Gala, in Huatulco Mexico; similar size, great service, awesome food, fantastic staff, amazing ocean, great sailing; it just has hard beds, take a foam topper with you (you can leave it after you unpack). (Also, Huatulco has Pacific Blue water; not the georgeous aqua of the Caribbean.)An alternative for superlative service (5Star++) vacation, if you want to try something else, would be a Royal Caribbean Cruise; take only their largest boat (Voyager of the Seas or a sister ship); and choose an 8 or 9 day trip. Don't pick one with lots of stops, stay on the ship and experience the cruise itself; those multi-stop cruises can be a little rushed.Our recommendation for a Punta Cana vacation resort that IS a 5 star: The Bahibe Principale, next door to this resort. We don't recommend experiencing the locale; it is oppressively poor. If you want to go on a humanitarian adventure here (the Dominican Republic), don't stay at a resort, join the Peace Corps.prh

<Content>Beautiful Resort, would definitely return! So I would like to start by saying I was kind of scared when I read everyones reviews. After staying at Grand Paradise Bavaro from March 6th-13th 2005 I discovered that there was nothing to worry about! Personally I think many people go in to their vacations expecting a 5 plus star hotel  service that they would find at home and this is just not the case in other countries. If you start out with a good attitude and relax a little bit you will find that the little things really aren't that big of a deal! Lobby/Rooms  grounds-Very nice lobby area.Grounds are kept clean, well lit at night.Rooms are cleaned very well daily. Mini bar is also restocked daily.The rooms are in good condition.Balcony or terrace in each room, view is great even if it is not beach view.StaffI found that a smile and even a small attempt at spanish gets you a long way! They really appreciate a smiling face and they will try to get over the language barrier just as long as you make an attempt as well (Although many of them speak up to 5 languages). Tips are not expected but they are appreciated. Very friendly!BeachBEAUTIFUL! The water can get a little wavy at times but the tourquois waters, white sand  palm trees are absolutely amazing! Also even the rooms farthest from the beach are just steps away. If you have a large party you may want to get to the beach early to get a spot....otherwise you will have no problems finding a seat...although one with shade is hard to come by.Food  DrinksThere is a large selection of foods at the buffet(Again as long as you aren't expecting out of this world food you will do fine, you have to keep in mind the food is just different in other countries). There is also 4 a la carte restaurants. I recomend the italian and the grill. The favourite drink seemed to be the bananna-mama...a frozen bananna strawberrry like rum drink....very good!EntertainmentThe shows in the theatre every night were entertaining. One night there was even a flame throwing type dance show...by far the best of the week! There is also a piano bar as well as a disco or you can sit down on the patio by the beach with a drink. During the day there are tonnes of tours to suit everyones needs as well as water sports offered at the hotel. If you are interested in seeing historical sites, shopping  seeing how dominicans live I suggest the all day tour to Santo Domingo, D.R's capitol. Its a long day (aprox. 6am to 10 pm) but well worth it!OtherQuick and easy check in  check out (our room was ready when we arrived at 1pm)Market held outside on friday nights (Make sure you barter, never pay more than half the asking price)Access to internetNever had any problems with getting clean towels for the room or beach.Athough the halls did echo in the hotel I did not hear the disco music late at night once and I was the closest building to it! (This was a common complaint I read about)Overall I was very impressed with this resort. It is mostly a family resort and great for anyone who just wants to relax! The price is very fair for what you get...if you are expecting perfection I suggest you pay double the price and book a 5 plus star resort. I would give GPB 4 out of 5. There are little glitches in every vacation but if you go in to it with a positive attitude then the little things are far less likely to ruin your trip. It is not the end of the world if you have to ask for a t.v. converter at the front desk, and if you ask nicely and put a smile on your face you will have no problems getting a second room key! You have to keep in mind that the way you treat the staff will definitely affect how they treat you in return.Feel free to e mail me with any questions

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beach...Definately! Service...No Way! We returned yesterday from our 7 day vacation at the Grand Paradise. Here is an overview...CHECK IN: Check in was very smooth. At first, they could not find our reservation, but within a matter of just a couple of minutes, they had us on our way. They will NOT give you a second key for your room. We got around that by talking to our representative, and he got us one. The safe is $20 US for the week. Yes, I was an idiot and lost the key on the beach and we did have to pay an additional $50 for another one.ROOM: Our room was pool side, building 6 second level. There are no elevators for those of you who may need one. Our room was very large, but only had 3 drawers to put our clothes and whatnot. They do not tell you at the front desk that when you come into your room, that you need to put your key into a little slot to turn the electricity on. (Probably the reason you are not allowed two keys). This has to be done every time you come into your room. I agree with the other people, bring at least a 75 watt light bulb, as the ones in the rooms are very dim! We had hot water with a ton of water pressure...no issues there. The housekeeping staff speak very little English, but were very polite. (they were about the only employees who were polite!) Yes, sometimes it took a while to get your room cleaned and new towels, but that was ok with us.BEACH: Very beautiful. The staff was always cleaning the beach...garbage washed up, seaweed, empty cups, etc. Although it says you cannot reserve chairs, everyone does, so if you go down between 8 and 10, you will have no problem getting a chair. It was extremely windy every day (it is on the Atlantic side don't forget), but we made the most of it by boogie boarding and just bobbing in the waves. RESTURANTS: Ok, here is why I gave this place only 2 stars. First, you MUST get reservations for the Chinese, Italian, and LaCana grill between 9 and 11 each morning. You can make reservations for all three for as many nights as you would like. Don't accept we are full for an answer. Not once!!!! were any of the three full. Not even close. If they do say they are full, get a manager from the lobby area. If you do not have a reservation, they will NOT let you in, even if they are almost completely empty. We had serious issues with the manager in the LaCana grill. Our friends came in to late to get reservations. Since it was empty, I politely asked him to allow our friends to eat with us. He explained that they were full, and it could not be done. By the time we were done eating, there were only 3 tables being used. I asked him why he lied, and an arguement broke out. I started to walk away, and the man actually grabbed my arm and told me to look at him. A report was filed. Point of this: MAKE SURE YOU HAVE RESERVATIONS!FOOD: The food is only ok at any of the places. There is nothing but fish, chicken and pork chops every night. Do not eat the hot dogs, they are raw and cold! The ice cream down there tastes like turpintine! Bring snacks!STAFF: For the most part...rude. It is almost like they figure they have you there, and your money, so oh well. The resort had only 10% American guests and I spoke with a number of them who complained that they felt that the staff was very rude.Will I go to this resort again? No. Will I go to the Dominican again? Probably not. If you have any questions, feel free to e-mail me.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Lowdown A few quick notes to make sure you have a great time:  - Remember what you paid for your trip (i.e. don't think it will be 5-star) - buy sunscreen before you get there - beach is GREAT, good waves, white sand, paradise day  night - the flea market has some interesting stuff, but bargain hard - take a few excursions, the guides are always great, and drinks are always free. We swam with sharks/rays, definitely well worth it. - if you like cigars, go to the cigar museum, it is very small but the staff are very knowledgeable, and they will give you a better deal if you're friendly. Try the mamajuana. ; ) - get a towel and beach chair early - we found the food better in the buffets than in the restaurants (although the restaurants are a little more private) - participate in the events, the staff work really hard to get people away from the bar and their chairs, and they're always fun - check-out the evening entertainment, surprisingly good - DO NOT make long distance calls from the hotel (about CAD 50/call, we found out after we got the visa bill) - DO NOT let the airline charge you for overweight luggage when leaving Punta Cana, this appears to be a common scam. We were very surprised that our luggage was overweight b/c we were way under the limits coming down and hadn't purchased many things while there. We started to unpack our luggage to lighten the load and then decided to weigh our bags on another scale that was empty. We were shocked to see that we were still a couple kilos under the limit. We showed the airline and they let us go ahead, once in the terminal we found that many people had fallen for the scam. It's too bad b/c it is one of the last things people will remember about this otherwise beautiful place.  Overall, I had a great time and would go back again. Although next time I will probably spend more money and upgrade to a 5-star resort, but it has nothing to do with this one. For the price I couldn't have asked for more.   P.S. please tip the staff for me b/c I should have done it more

<Content>Great beach, good service, decent food December 27th to Jan 3rdI would like to start off by saying that I am an experienced traveler, I almost always go all-inclusive and have been all over the Caribbean (St. Thomas, St. Maarten, Port Lucaya-Bahama, Grand Cayman, Riviera Maya, Cozumel and Jamaica). I do not go for the cheapest fares nor do I automatically choose the most expensive option. I browse sites like this and learn a great deal. But after just getting back from the Grand Bavaro from Dec 27th to Dec 31st, there are some misconceptions about this resort that need to be addressed. This is going to be long and detailed but I think that it will be of great use.Check-In(A)The front desk was more than courteous and the manager was friendly and helpful even though I asked for a room change and needed special assistance. When I did have a problem later on in the week with the Chinese restaurant (my only real complaint) he took care of it immediately and to my complete satisfaction. His name was Ruben, the entire front desk staff was efficient and courteous, I have had a much more difficult time in many US hotels of supposedly higher stars.Room/Housekeeping (A)I was originally assigned Room 41 something but asked at the front desk to moved to building six based on recomnedations from people on this site, they did so and I was assigned Room 6130, steps from the beach and pool. The room was big enough although the bathrooms were a little cramped. The room was clean, the fridge stocked and we always had clean towels. I donéˆ¥æª› know if those who complained were just mistaken or were just badmouthing just to complain about something. We needed two beds (one for our daughter) but the room we were changed to only had a king size bed, which is not the hoteléˆ¥æªš fault, the original room had two beds, but one call to housekeeping and they arrived promptly with a rollaway crib. This again was my fault, my Spansih being a little rusty, I referred to our 5 year old as éˆ¥æ¸˜inaéˆ¥? or baby, so they ran and got a normal rollaway, this was brought in and made up quickly, we asked for and received extra pillows. My wife accidentally left out her purse one day but when we returned nothing was missing. The maid was tipped a few dollars each day.Food (C+)To those of you who complained about the food, you do have some good points. The food is of buffet quality, slightly substandard of a cruiseship variety but not bad. One lady said that you eat the same food for breakfast lunch and dinner, not exactly true. Yes you may have potatoes at every meal that day but they are prepared differently and NO they are not the same actual potatoes, the food goes much too quickly, nothing sits out too long. And having worked as a server in the US I can tell you that this is standard. 90% of the food you eat in your typical Franchise Casual Dining is made two to three days ahead of time and microwaved to order. I did have a problem with the Chinese restaurant, we were told to be there at 6:20, we were second in line at 6:10, but the manager told us that everything was booked until 8. How could that be we asked? He said that he opened the doors a little early, but there is no way 40 people lined up and signed in before we arrived at 6:10, frustrated I went to the front desk where Ruben took care of everything. We eventually ate at La Cana that night where the service was friendly and the food good. Overall I would rate the food fair to good compared to other all inclusives. By the way I never got sick, which is odd considering I almost always (despite my best precautions it usually happens on an excursion) get Montezumaéˆ¥æªš revenge. I have a weak stomach but never got ill.Beach (A+)Beautiful!! To those who complained about the lack of chairs, you were exaggerating a bit werenéˆ¥æª› you? There are 30 to 40 thatched roof umbrellas, you could not fit anymore because of the tide coming up and not everyone wants to hide from the sun on vacation.The waves were big, but not overpowering, about the same size as the Jersey shore, maybe slightly bigger and times, great sand, soft and never hot, great view and nice blue water. Best feature of the resort.Pools (B)Clean, cool and nicely landscaped, not the best but certainly not the worst. The animacion staff was eager to get you involved but never rude, they have seen so many tourists say no at first but then after a little coaxing really let loose and have agreat time, everyone who participated seemed to have a great time. More pool chairs are needed and the staff should police the éˆ¥æ¸Ÿaving chairéˆ¥?rule. You know no one is using the chair when there is nothing on it but a towel, there are 10 people in the pool but 50 empty saved chairs.Kids Club (B)The staff was friendly and sought out kids to come and play instead of waiting for them to come, lots of fun games outside, but I was unimpressed by the actual club, seemed dreary and a little out of date. My little girl chose to spend most of her time with us.Manati Park (B-)They try for the most part but after being to Xcaret park in Mexico, there was no comparison. The dolphin swim is 70 dollars for only eight minutes you decide if its worth it. We went to the park the one day it rained, so it was not a day completely ruined, the iguana pit was the best feature. This was our only excursion.Spa (B+)My wife got a great massage for a great price. The atmosphere was not great but good. Overall (A-)This is a four star resort by any island standard, small enough to avoid crowds and long waits, but big enough to provide all the amenties you need. I loved the beach and pools, the service was good if not spectular, your average restaurant service in the US, grounds were nice with everything within easy walking distance. All in all it is a VACATION people, relax, unwind and stop nitpicking. There are no major flaws and the little ones you are likely to find at any resort. I wouldnéˆ¥æª› hesitate to recommend this resort if you plan on traveling to DR, if your destination is undetermined you may want to spend the same amount and go to Riviera Maya, but if you love the beach you should give this place a try.

<Content>Great time, but what about the malaria??? <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>family christmas vacation December 19th to 26th, 2004We stayed at the Grand Paradise Hotel in Punta Cana. We are a family of 4 and our children are 20 and 22. We had 2 rooms beside each other and that was what we were hoping for on our trip. Our view was partially of the 2nd pool and the pond close to the main foyer, and if we poked our heads out from our balcony we could see the ocean. The rooms were spacious and clean. We were on the third floor, so our balcony enclosure had open grillwork so that we could see out when we sat down. Only one of the rooms was ready when we arrived around 1:00 pm. We all changed into our bathing suits, shorts, tops and sandels which we were smart enough to pack with our carry-on luggage. The hotel staff said that they would bring our luggage up to the rooms, however, that took them 45 minutes to deliver. Nevertheless, we have learned to pack what we would need for the first day in our carry-on, so that there would be no disappointments if lugguage were lost or if we had to wait for luggage delivery to our room. We were nicely greeted at the lobby and received our bracelet which indicated that we were part of the all-inclusive package. We could not get our key to the safe in our room until the room was ready ( 3:00 pm).The main cafeteria had a wide variety of food and although there was a lot of repetition over the week, there was plenty to choose from. There were at least 2 stations in the buffet where you could get your food freshly cooked if you preferred. This was also available at breakfast and lunch. The staff was friendly and accommodating. In the evening we tended to eat at the other 3 restaurants on the premises. They never disappointed us. Our only complaint was that the wine was not very good. Their beer is excellent! The service was excellent and our favourite spot was the Asian restaurant.We spent most of our time on the beach which was absolutely the best. You could walk for miles and there were beautiful palm trees abounding. My husband took his own snorkeling gear and was suprised by how many fish you could see just inside the swimming boundaries. They appear to be invisible to most swimmers, but to the snorkelers they were definitely there. He sometimes would bring some bread from the cafeteria when he went snorkeling and he said that many were attracted to the food and this made for better viewing. The water was clear, blue and just the right temperature for swimming.At times it was difficult in the afternoon to get a drink at the bar, but if you were patient and learned how to carry 4 drinks at once, you had it made. At other times there was no line-up at all. The glasses are small, but the mixed drinks are really strong. Watch yourself on the first day!The entertainment was lively and the dancers were good. The costumes were colourful and we enjoyed each performance. There were 2 live bands that played in the evening during the week. One was on the beach and the other played by the poolside bar.My son's only complaint was about what he called The Fun Police. He would regularly hide from them under a book or pretend to be sleeping while on the beach. He learned how to say no in many polite ways when they came to get him to play games. Just be as persistent as them and they will back off. Lots of people did partake in the beach volley ball which was actually very entertaining.This was our first time away for Christmas and thoroughly enjoyed ourseleves. We would go back again. Be sure to bring lots of US one dollar bills which are great for tipping. We made a point of tipping between $10US to $15US in the specialty restaurants because of the the great service. We also left a couple of dollars every other day on our pillow for the maids. This ensured that we always had our container of water and few pops in our fridge.

<Content>Great holiday I just returned from the Grand Paradise Bavaro. We stayed from Nov 4-11, 2004. I travelled with my husband (we're both 35), 3 kids (ages 9,7,and 6), and my in-laws (both in their 60's). My in-laws had been to Punta Cana before (different resort) and have been to Cuba, but we had never been to the Caribbean or to an all-inclusive before. We have been to Puerto Vallarta and to various places in Hawaii.We found the resort itself, outstanding. The food was great....we enjoyed the buffet the most, with everyone's different tastes. The desserts are the best! The service wasn't great, but we were okay with that as we just served ourselves coffee, juice, etc. It didn't seem to matter if we tipped, either, so sometimes we did, sometimes we didn't. We did try both a la carte restaurants (Italian and Chinese) but preferred the buffet. We also went to the beach restaurant La Cana for lunch quite often because we could go in swimsuits, and it was okay. We didn't ever have to deal with the front desk, aside from check-in, which was quick and easy, so I can't comment on that.The maids came early some days, later others. It didn't really matter to us, since we only went to our rooms to shower and change. We left them $1 US each day and a dollar store gift (pencil, lip gloss). The rooms were fine, although the beds were a little small and hard.The beach was the biggest disappointment to me. My husband, kids and I all love to snorkel, so we had packed our snorkel gear along. The beach is beautiful to look at and I don't know if it was just the time of year (tail end of hurricane season) but the water was very rough. The kids loved to play in the waves, but couldn't swim and snorkel. My husband went out a couple of times and I went once....there really wasn't a whole lot to see, compared to Maui. The pools were great and fairly clean. For the most part, they were pretty empty (not sure where everyone was!) and the kids had the run of them. We had brought our own floaties which was good because it's 5 feet deep everywhere so the kids couldn't touch. We didn't usually have a problem getting a chair, although some days they were all 'saved'. We did have a problem getting towels some days, if we didn't get them first thing in the morning. They kept saying 20 minutes all day. The service at the pool bar was incredibly slow (even with tipping) and if the kids went up themselves to get some juice, they were always served last. The weather the first two days was hot, hot, hot, but then the rest of the days were rainy and overcast. It would clear up for a bit and we'd head to the beach or pool til the next downpour. We also used the rainy days to go into plaza bavaro, the cigar museum, and walk to the flea market down the beach. The cigar museum was a waste of time....one small little building with one guy rolling cigars. The cab ride there was free so we thought it'd be worthwhile. They drove us back on their own after about 5 minutes because they didn't like having the kids in the store.On the 2nd rainy day, the kids discovered the kids club. They LOVED it. We couldn't get them to stay with us after that. Luz was fantastic with the kids and they did lots of different activities including tennis, swimming, shuffleboard and bocce. Each of my kids won a necklace at different activies either there or the minidisco (also managed by Luz) in the evening on stage.We also spent some rainy time in the sports bar playing fooz-ball.All in all, we had a great time, despite the rainy weather. We got a last minute deal and I think for the price we paid ($799 CDN each including airfare!) we more than got our money's worth. I'm still missing all those fabulous desserts!Hope that helps anyone who is headed there in the near future....Have fun!

All staff except, front desk, very nice but limited english (bring a spanish dictionary - you try and then they will, a couple of singles here and there didn't hurt either). You're better off sticking with the buffet then going with the specialty restaurants. Reservations for the restaurants are made the same day @ 6:30pm for that night, pants required. Get your tv remote  lock box key(extra charge) when you check in, they don't tell you til you get to the room. Large pools, no swim up bar, pool/beach bar, cold jacuzzi. Get beach towels early in the am and pick a spot on beach (people reserve even though you're not supposed to). Not many kids. No 4 or 5 star expectations no disappointments. If you want to lay around a pool, beach, drink and eat for a week. You can't beat it for the price. We always stay at all inclusives and this was an extremely good value.

<Author>beenthere
<Content>An Experience To Remember I just got back from a week at the Grand Paradise. Me and my 2 friends went down, we are in our early twenties. I was there from September 12-19, YES I was there when Hurricane Jeanne hit!!! First off, let me start off by saying that I read ALL the reviews before booking this hotel, and my experience was very different from alot of the things written. The grounds are beautiful, and the staff is extremely friendly and helpful. Robbinson (Robi), Reuben and Ceasar were wonderful at the front desk. The entertainment staff (the animators) are very nice and always try to get you involved with the activities. The pool was not dirty, and there were always enough towels. The only tiny complaint I could have was that there were some ants in our room, but it wasn't a nucensce. There is a sports bar on the grounds with a tiny disco and thats where we spent our nights, especially after the hurricane hit. The disco does repeat the same songs, but you can bring your own cd's. Unfortuanatly, I cannot comment on any of the restaurants because we did not experience them because they were closed down after hurricane Jeanne hit. We ate at the main buffet room the whole week, and it was good. Let me tell you that this resort was one of the ONLY resorts still standing after Hurricane Jeanne hit. After hearing the horror stories from the passengers on our plane, I felt extremely lucky to have stayed at the Grand Paradise. The other hotels had no running water, there kitchens were not functioning at all, and the guests even had to bath in the pool! When the hurricane passed, our hotel was flooded and phone lines were down, no running water ... and the staff was still catering to our every command. Alot of the employees did not show up for work because there homes were demolished by the hurricane and roads and bridges were flooded. We were one of the only resorts that had running water and A/C up and running after a day. After the hurricane hit, they were constantly cleaning up the debris around the hotel ... the hotels adjacent to ours had the debris and fallen palm trees left out in the open, and did not do a thing to clean it up. We were also one of the only hotels that still had hot food served! This was an experience that I would not wish apon anyone (especially since I live in Canada and have never experienced a hurricane, nor do I ever want to again). All in all, eventhough the hurricane hit, we still had a good time, mainly because of our resort. THANK GOD we stayed at the Grand Paradise. We were in a life threatening situation, and this hotel tried to make our stay as comfortable as possible. I would only like to say that I would never travel again during hurricane season, nor do I reccomend it ... you don't want to even risk the chance of experiencing this kind of catastrophy. I would like to thank all the staff that helped make our stay better, and in conclusion I would like to leave off by saying that if this hotel could withstand a hurricane, I would highly reccomend it to anyone. Me and my two friends will be going back in February and we will be staying at this resort again!!!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Trip! We were at Grand Paradise from Sept.5-Sept.12/04. Overall, we had a wonderful trip and the weather was great - even despite Huricaine Ivan in the Carribean. Front Desk Service: We found the staff to be a bit on the slow side, but everything is done there in Dominican time. However, from the other reviews, we expected this to be the case. Room: We had a great view of the ocean and the pool. The staff kept our room tidy although we didn't always get small wash cloths. The staff did ensure that we got them once we asked though. Keep in mind that you can ask at the front desk for a TV remote.Beach: The beach was awesome, but you do have to make sure that you reserve a spot in the shade before 7AM or you will luck out. Sand was nice and white and not very hot. We found that the beach was kept nice and clean. Water was pretty clear although towards the end of the week, it got a little cloudy and seaweedy - but to be expected with the huricaines going around on the ocean.Pool: Generally kept clean. They are very big which is nice if you want to use an air mattress. The pools are always in the sun though so you have to watch out you don't burn. There are only 2 or 3 umbrellas by the pool - again the first spots to be picked.Nightly entertainment: We found the entertainment pretty good, although more geared towards adults. The content was not always suitable for kids. Parents be cautious. Food: We found the food to be overall pretty good - although not like home. The buffets have a lot of variety. The pasta bar was great, and we took advantage of this quite often. The dinner buffet did not always enforce the dress code, but the a la carte restaurants did. The beach grill had good food but everyday the same. It was nice to be able to eat in your beachwear though. Tours: We did the Country Adventure tour which was a very good tour. We were picked up at 9AM and did not return until 6PM - a pretty long day. We saw a school, typical house, cigar museum, sugar cane field, and had lunch at a ranch were able to do a bit of horseback riding and relax/swim in a nearby river. They also showed us how they grind coffee beans and cocoa beans. From there we drove to a nice beach in time to have a 45 minute swim. They showed us some beautiful scenery while driving around the country too. Bring a camara. Overall, we had a great trip and couldn't have asked for better weather. It was well worth the money spent on it - roughly $710 plus all taxes. We would recommend it to anyone looking to have a relaxing vacation. Just remember it is not like home and you will have a good time.
