<Author>hokoonchi
<Content>Grand Paradise Not So "Grand" First of all, I would recommend this resort to anybody who has never been to a 5 star resort before. This way, you will not know the huge differences between those hotels and this one, and you will most likely enjoy your stay much more. As for those who have been to a 5 star resort before, I do not recommend this place, as upon arrival, you will immediately begin to make mental notes of all of the vast differences.My husband and I just came back from the Grand Paradise a week ago. We had gone there to celebrate our first year wedding anniversary. Prior to going there, I had read all of the reviews on this hotel, so I was aware that this place was only about a 3 star. Since we had found a really cheap deal, $750 each, for one week inc. tax, air and hotel, we decided to try it out. Although a bit long-winded, here's what we thought:Check in - Is 3 pm, we arrived around 3:30, and although there was only one family checking in ahead of us, we waited about a half hour for the room. Don't bother trying to tip the front desk people to try to get an oceanview room - it doesn't work here. I read reviews on other hotels in the D.R. and it seems that it is a common practice - not here though, so save your 20 bucks. We even emailed the resort, the week prior, but our room request was not fulfilled, except for the fact that we were given a king-size bed, which was nice.Room - They told us it was a nice gardenview room, but upon peering over our balcony, we had a full view of the Kid's Club, and the builiding across from us. I don't know where the garden was supposed to be, but whatever... At least the room was well air conditioned and pretty clean, except for some (not enough to complain to mgmt. about) very small picnic ants that I would find crawling on the floor and sometimes on the desk. Word of advice, shake out all of your clothes before leaving the hotel, and do not keep any kind of food available for these ants, as I think they are just waiting to come busting out from somewhere if they have the chance. Even if you have a sweet drink opened, I'd be careful. Another thing about the room, is that it is very dark in there. Even though there are two bedside lamps, I think there is only a 10 or 20 watt bulb in them, so don't plan on reading in bed at night unless you want to strain your eyes. A booklight is highly recommended. And, the lighting in the bathroom is even darker. There is just one very dim light bulb, just enough so that you can see what you're doing in there. I heard that this is the case with the other rooms as well, so apparently it wasn't just our room. They must not have enough electricity over there, because even the restaurants and the outdoor lighting is very dim in the evenings. Also, there is no clock in the room, so if you don't have a watch with you, you will not know what time it is most of the time. I guess this is fine, since on vacation that is something you shouldn't have to worry about, but when it comes to waking up at 6:30 in the morning to reserve a palapa, and once again at 6:30 pm to reserve your spot at dinner, time becomes very important. Luckily, we brought along a travel alarm clock.Housekeeping - Although we left a couple bucks and a small gift on our pillow everyday, most days we did not get any small towels. After placing one or two calls to housekeeping, they would arrive, but usually after we had taken our shower. I read this in other reviews, so I brought along a few extra washcloths, which I am happy that I did. I also brought along a pair of disposable slippers, which were very useful.Beach - The beach was nice, probably the highlight of the trip. However, it is necessary to get a spot in the shade, as the sun is very, very strong there, and sitting out in the sun all day would be dangerous, even if you're slathered in spf 45. However, since the towel desk doesn't open until 9 or 10 in the morning, we brought along a couple beach towels from home, so that we could reserve our spot under the palapa at 6:30 am. This was helpful since the hotel beach towels are blue, and we could easily spot our chairs when going back to the beach after breakfast. The sand and the water was nice, but not anything comparable to that of Cancun. The sand had lots of twigs, and dried bits of sharp seaweed. So, if you have sensitive feet, a good pair of beach sandals are recommended. Also, bring along a pair of tweezers, as you may find a few splinters in your toes at the end of the day. The water was a clear greenish blue color, nice, but once again, don't expect the beautiful turquoise color of Cancun. There were some nice waves, and alot of people had rafts which they floated on in the ocean. They can be purchased in the gift shop for $12. Day Trips - We met with our tour rep. the day after we arrived, and he went over all of the outings. We didn't go on any, as none of them seemed worth the money, and it appeared that he made up the price of the outing according to what he thought you were interested in (skimming some bucks for himself? Probably!). I heard that the sunset horseback riding on Macao beach was nice however. One thing I don't recommend to contact lense wearers though, is the four-wheeler tour. I was looking at pictures in the tour book and noticed that everyone was wearing a scarf over their face. When I asked why, the guy said that since everybody is following behind each other, there was a lot of sand being kicked up in people's faces. As any contact lense wearer would know, getting sand in your eyes is not fun! A pair of goggles would be recommended if you really want to do this.Restaurants - Where should I begin... If you are someone that is coming from a big city and are spoiled with good food all of the time, you will not enjoy the food here. Let me just say, you will not be gaining any weight on this trip. We found the food to be completely tasteless. Breakfast - The breakfast buffet was huge but serves the exact same food everyday, and unfortunately, there was nothing very appetizing to be had. Most of the food was very, very greasy, and the large variety of breads were very dry. They serve goat milk in your coffee, and I imagine with your cereal, if you choose to have any. They have an omlette station, but you may want to ask the guy not to drop a ladle full of oil on the grill before making yours. I had one on the first day, and it was so oily, I coudn't eat it. They also have a sandwich press, which most people were using to make their own mystery meat and cheese sandwiches in, for breakfast. We had this a couple of times, but by day three, that became tiresome. We found the only edible foods at breakfast were the fresh fruit, especially the pineapple, and the fresh juices, which were pretty good. We also usually had some goat milk coffee and a dry, flavorless sweet bread, so that we wouldn't be hungry all morning. Another word of advice: be careful when taking fruit from the bottom of the serving tray. There is usually some water in there, which we orginally thought was juice from the fruit, but thirty minutes later found out otherwise, as we were running for the bathroom. So, be sure to grab fruit from the top of the pile, as they clearly do not dry out their containers. Lunch - Best meal of the day, so fill up!! We never went to the buffet lunch, as we assumed it would be a repeat of the breakfast buffet, but the grill restaurant serves up some slightly more edible fare, and you can wear your swimsuit. The rotisserie chicken, was pretty good. If you grab a roll, you can take your chicken apart and make a nice sandwich. They also serve hamburgers and fries, so kids will be happy. And, there are some other things there, but nothing good enough to write about. After a week of this though, I don't think I will be eating chicken or pineapple for a very long time.Dinner - Out of the three a la carte restaurants - Chinese, Italian, and the Grill, we thought the Italian restaurant was the best, until I found a large unidentifiable black bug crawling through the food on the appetizer table. Since it was so dark in there, I couldn't tell what kind of bug it was, but disgusting no less. This was hopefully just a rare occurence. Also, don't expect any of these ethnic foods to taste anything like they would back home. It is obvious that the chefs have absolutely no idea what these types of food should taste like, and they must be well aware of this, as they kept refusing a Chinese family reservations, at the Chinese restaurant. We really would've liked to have heard their opinions on this food! Although this made it a kind of an interesting and comical experience, the food was terrible. The desserts are the same in all of the restaurants, everyday. There is also the buffet restaurant for dinner, which we ended up at a couple of times because we left the other restaurants part way through the dinner, in hopes to find something better to eat. Luckily, you don't need a reservation for the buffet. Out of the whole week, the French buffet was the best (each day they post which ethnic food will served the following day). They had a fondue station set up, where they cooked beef and chicken on skewers, and had about 15 different kinds of sauce to dip them in. I think everybody realized that this was the best food they were going to have all week, so the line became very long for this item. Service - what service? We found that unless you are a Spanish speaker, forget about getting any good service. Even though we threw out a few phrases here and there, and also left a tip, this did not net us any better service. It is not that the employees are laid back, as described in other reviews, it is that they are completely unorganized, and have no idea how a real restaurant should be operated. Every evening, we had about 5 different people waiting on our table. The host who seated us, took our order, another brought us water (only once I might add, unless we flagged them over), another brought us wine, another served our appetizer etc etc.. Since they were all doing a little bit of everything, every evening turned out to be some kind of circus, with all of the staff sporadically walking about doing a little of this and a little of that. The service in the buffet restaurant is practically nonexistent. The tables were always missing something, either napkins, forks, or glasses. Guests were walking around swiping items off of other tables, so that they could eat. And, although they are supposed to serve you beverages, most people were walking over to the bar to get themselves a drink, as it's a lot quicker. To top things off, I did not find the employees to be overly friendly either. Most of them looked like they were bothered to be working around all of us, service with a smile? Not! Out of the whole week, I seen maybe 3 friendly employees. And, tips are definitely not appreciated, except for the guys at the beach bar. We gave them a couple dollars each day and they always remembered us when we came back for a refill. Speaking of refills, as in other reviews, definitely bring insulated mugs with you. This way you don't have to keep going back to the bar, as the cups are very small.Nightlife - Typical cheesy shows that you would see at any other resort, which takes place every evening at 9:30. With nothing else to do, pretty much everybody goes there to see them. The dance club, which is primarily for the young crowd over 18, opens at 11:30, and is mildly entertaining, for about 20 minutes. Then, there is a game room, where all of the kids under 18 hang out. They have fusball (sp?) and a pool table, as well as a snack bar. A small slot machine room, with about 20 machines, is next to the game room. My husband won a little over $60 on the 5 cent machines, but that must have been a really rare occurence, since the employee working there had trouble filling out the paperwork for the pay off. Oh, and he didn't even get the whole amount of his winnings, since they don't have any small bills. As it was only a couple of dollars it was no big deal, but still... One night, we ventured over to the Breezes hotel next door to check out the grounds, and to go to their casino. Their casino was small, but they had some table games, which was fun for a while. Souevenirs - complete junk. A good 15 minute walk down the beach, you will find some tents set up where the local people sell their wares. Each stand sells the exact, I mean exact, same items. As soon as you approach their area, they will all start coming after you to try and drag you into their tent. Don't plan on getting out of there quickly. The only thing of interest in those stands were the oil paintings, which they were trying to sell at exorbitant prices. Bargaining is definitely a must, and don't let up when they refuse your offer. As soon as you say you're going to look at the other stands and come back, they will give you your price, since they know that you will probably not come back. We walked away with a couple of nice paintings, but not without a lot of bargaining, which can be kind of stressful if you're not used to that type of thing. If you don't feel like going to their stands, don't worry, they will come to you. Every friday evening, the hotel brings these same vendors on-site. They are conveniently set up outside of the restaurants, so you will definitely be heckled on your way to dinner. The items in the gift shop are uninteresting and overpriced. And, if you want to buy a candybar or something, they are $3 each. Personally, I would have been embarassed to bring back anything from there and give it to somebody as a souvenir. And, don't expect to find anything better in the airport gift shop on your way home, it's the same stuff. The duty-free shop is an absolute joke as well, there's hardly anything in there. For your flight back - I highly recommend bringing some extra snacks with you. They are selling little cans of peanuts for $6 in the airport, as well as other snacks that are ridiculously overpriced. And ladies, be careful, the airport employees will look through your purse as you pass through security. Two guys will take everything out of your purse, so watch your money if you have anything loose bills in there. It's almost like they try to distract you by having two guys looking through your bag at once. And not surprisingly, they only seem to want to look inside of purses, not the carry-on bags....Anyway, there it is. It's not bad if you just want to go lay on the beach everyday, and you take along the extra things mentioned in the reviews.  Would we go there again? Noway. Our advice, go to Mexico, they know how it's done over there! Feel free to email me if you want anymore details, or have any questions. If it's too late to turn back on the resort, don't be put off by our review. We're just one opinion of thousands, so you may just have a great time!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>You get what you pay for We stayed at this hotel Aug.23 - Aug.30. We paid $2289 for 2 adults and a child which was the best deal we could find. Right away, I'll say we got our money's worth. However, I would only recommend this hotel to people that are strictly looking for some relaxing beach time, as there is not much there otherwise. It's perfect for families with kids, but don't expect much entertainment. The beach is beautiful, clean, clear water. There seems to be plenty of shade, BUT all chairs in the shade are gone before 7 am. My husband and I actually took turns to put our towels out at night, as we didn't want to get up too early in the morning. I found it helpful to have our own towels, as the hotel never had enough.The rooms are very basic, but well air-conditioned, with great shower. Always plenty of hot water. However, be careful in the bathtub as our bathroom was very poorly lit and you could't see anything. Also, they never gave us enough towels despite the fact that we tipped our cleaning lady $3 a day. Although she always stocked up our fridge with bottled water and soft drinks, which are free (a nice touch that you don't usually get in the all-inclusive resorts). I only wish they'd use vacuum for the floors. They clean tile floors with a wet mop, which doesn't get rid of the sand. We didn't care that our room had no view, but we liked it's llocation. It was on the 1st floor, very close to the beach exit and away form the pool, restaurants and other activities. I highly recommend to ask for a quiet room (ours was 5122) because you woulds't be able to rest otherwise. People tend to party into the wee hours and it gets very noisy at night. Also, they have roll-away beds. We got one for our son, but you really have to ask for it in advance as they don't have enough.Food: plentiful and nicely presented, BUT if you watch your carbs and prefer high protein diet, you'll be very dissapointed. I could not eat their meat and poultry. Even cheese and lancheon meats tasted funny. We had to stick with mostly starches: pasta, rice and potatoes, as well as fruits. Also, their sweet breads at breakfast and desserts were absolutely delicious. So, forget your Atkins diet for a week and you'll be OK. If you go to the Asia or Italian restaurants, expect the food quality of a take-out or a mall food court. The service was always great, though. A bit slow, but no other complaints. We tipped $2 at the buffet at lunch and dinner and $5 at the restaurants. Also, $1 tip goes a long way at the bar, as far as speedy service as well as the amount of alcohol.One more suggestion: stay away from the front desk. Try not to deal with them unless you absolutely have to. They couldn't be more clueless about good customer service, especially if they have to provide it in English. The majority of the hotel guests are European, so prepare to do a lot of second hand smoking. There is no non-smoking anything and you'll inhale smoke anywhere you go.Overall, a good value for your money.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Grand Paradise, know before you go. Before we left home we did some research and learned about some of the problems with reservations and check-in and then called the Grand Paradise two weeks before the trip. The reservation office told me we had no reservations even though I had the confirmation numbers so I just called the travel company and they straightened it out with the hotel. I also telephoned the hotel again the day before we left and again confirmed our reservations, room view and bed requests. Note: The guest rooms are located in several different buildings with three floors each and no elevators. Consider this when requesting your room location if someone in your group has a problem with the stairs. We also learned the preferred currency is US Dollars and brought more cash than I usually like to travel with, especially one-dollar bills for tips. Upon arrival at the Punta Cana Airport we were given the opportunity to be photographed (you will see the pictures when you leave a week later) and then purchased Visitor Cards for $10 cash each. The price is posted in USD like most of the prices we saw during our stay. After completing the Customs and Immigrations formalities we entered the arrivals area and told someone from one of the taxi desks we were going to the Grand Paradise and they told us which of the busses was going there next. The price is set at $26 for your group. We had four people in our group and lots of luggage so I tipped the driver for helping me with it. The ride is about 30 minutes. At the hotel, some of the staff was involved in an argument with some very angry guests who said they had reservations but the hotel had no rooms for them. My previous telephone calls turned out to be a good investment because the desk manager on duty was the person I called the previous day and he remembered me so we had no problems with check-in. They issued us magnetic keycards, towel cards (more about them later) and plastic color-coded bracelets you have to wear during your stay so they know you are a guest at that hotel and whether or not you are over 18 (the age required to be served alcohol and get into the disco.) I also got a lock for the room safe, which costs $20 to rent for your stay.The swimming pool is nice. There is a desk adjacent to the pool bar that exchanges the towel cards for blue towels to use at the pool and the beach but beware; they do not have enough for all the guests. If you do not get your towels by about 9 AM, you arenéˆ¥æª› going to get one. Some people brought their own but we requested extra towels from the maid and used them. (I tipped the maid $2 a day so I didnéˆ¥æª› have any problems getting the towels.) Both the swimming pool and the beach are closed to guests after 7 PM. The beach is really beautiful and the water is clear. There is a marked swimming area for snorkeling or use of the other non-motorized equipment you can check out from the Aquatics Desk on the beach. There are not enough recliners on the beach for the guests so again, get yours early. Most people put their towels or other items on a recliner for the day and then came and went as they pleased. Be aware the pool area is not topless but the beach is. There are four restaurants at the hotel. Two are specialty restaurants, one Chinese and one Italian. They are only open after 6:30 PM and have dress codes. Beach attire, shorts, tank tops, etc. are not permitted. The Chinese restaurant was not too popular and seating was readily available. The Italian restaurant was very popular and you have to know the system to get a seat. Hereéˆ¥æªš how it works: you stand in line until the doors open at 6:30 PM on the night you want to eat there. At this time you can either eat or make a reservation for later that evening. No, you cannot make a reservation for another night. The food at these restaurants was okay but nothing to write home about. Adjacent to the two restaurants mentioned above is the La Laguna Buffet. It serves breakfast, lunch and dinner buffets. The dress code applies at dinner. The peak dinner period seemed to be about 8:00 PM but the wait was minimal. There was no problem getting seating at other times of the day. We thought the food was pretty good. There was always a large selection to choose from and we always found something we liked. The fourth restaurant is the La Cana restaurant on the beach. It serves lunch and dinner buffets but it is smaller with fewer selections however the dress code does not apply there.Tour operators are located on the second floor of the lobby with many to choose from. We wanted to go snorkeling and the Coco Tours representative, Abis, recommended a half-day tour of the Marinarium, an enclosure in the ocean where they have several Nurse Sharks and Stingrays penned in. If you really want to snorkel and look at marine life DO NOT TAKE THIS TOUR!!! It is billed as éˆ¥æ¸n incredible once-in-a-lifetime experience where you can snorkel with sharks and stingrays.éˆ¥?Abis told us repeatedly this is primarily a snorkeling trip and that the operators provided masks, snorkels and fins but if we had our own equipment we were welcome to use it. The facts are we paid $70 per person to ride on a bus for an hour picking up guests from several other hotels. We then boarded the boat and motored out to the Marinarium enclosures a few hundred meters off shore where we learned not only did they not provide fins to the guests, they refused to allow those of us that brought fins to use them. They anchored the boat about 100 meters from the enclosures and expected everyone to swim against the ocean current to the pens with no fins. Needless to say, a lot of people didnéˆ¥æª› make it. Several of the older guests and none of the young children could make it. Families had to separate so one adult could stay on the boat with their children. I made it to the pens and saw the sharks and rays but it was a real workout and there was no opportunity to enjoy the view. They planned for us to snorkel for 45 minutes and then opened the bar. The crew served unlimited beer and rum drinks for the rest of the afternoon while we slowly motored down the coast to a shallow area about a meter deep. There, the guests had the opportunity to wade in the shallow water while a crewmember waded in with a tray of drinks. The crew then motored back to the shore serving drinks along the way. Just when we thought it was finally over, we discovered our bus had to wait for the rest of the boats to return, this was about 40 minutes and then another hour for the ride back to the Grand Paradise. We left the hotel at 12:20 PM and returned at about 7:30 PM. This tour is little more than a very expensive booze-cruise, which is fine if thatéˆ¥æªš what you want to do but we paid the $280 to spend the afternoon snorkeling, not riding up and down the coast drinking. I arranged a couple of SCUBA dives through the Aquatics Desk at the hotel and discovered they also take people snorkeling. I donéˆ¥æª› know the price but it has to be cheaper than the booze-cruise and, of course, you can use your fins. The diving was not the best Iéˆ¥æªe ever seen but good and worth the $45 per dive I spent. There are several nearby dives sites in the area you can choose from as well as a full day trip to an area called éˆ¥æ·atalinaéˆ¥? This is supposed to be the best diving in the area but the trip only leaves on Tuesday and Friday. The dive shop is well equipped in case you need gear.The shopping area is called the Plaza Bavaro and is about 15 minutes away by taxi which the front desk can call; the fare is set at $12. The market is a large area on each side of the street catering primarily to tourists. Bargaining is expected and some of the merchants start the bargaining at ridiculous amounts. The currency of choice is still the US Dollar but I was told they also accept Canadian Dollars, Euros and British Pounds. I saw ATM machines advertising access to most of the usual ATM networks but was told they are not reliable and dispense Dominican Republic Pesos when they do work. Most of the merchants advertise that they accept credit cards but when we tried to use one their machine indicated our credit card was not valid (our account is in good order.) I think either the merchantéˆ¥æªš equipment cannot communicate with the network reliably or they really donéˆ¥æª› want to accept the cards. Taxi drivers wait just outside the market so getting a ride back to the hotel is no problem but you must stick with the tan-colored éˆ¥æ·ªiutraturaléˆ¥?taxis. The return home was fairly uneventful. The front desk will send a porter for your baggage if you like and will call a taxi. In our case, we requested a van and got one. Allow extra time at the airport for very slow check-in because they do not have X-ray equipment for the baggage and the security personnel must manually inspect your bags before you can check them. You will then proceed through Immigration and turn in the remaining half of your Tourist Card and proceed through the X-ray equipment for your self and carry-on bags. When you enter the departure area, you will see the photographs that were taken a week earlier when you arrived and have the chance to purchase them for $6 each. This part of the terminal did not seem to be air-conditioned but the gates are located on a slightly lower level and was cooler.

<Content>We had a great holiday Me and my boyfriend stayed at Grand Paradise Bavaro from the 22nd of July - 5th of August, this was our first time to the Carribean.We arrived at the hotel at 2.30pm and waited about half an hour to check-in and were then given our key to our room. At first we were a bit dissappointed as our room had no sea or pool view as it faced the front grounds of the hotel (room 1101) however it was a very quiet place to be. The rooms were big and comfortable and we had no problems at all regarding them.The complex itself was lovely the grounds were beautiful and well kept.Restaurants:The food was quite good however although I am a fussy eater there was food to cater for everyone especially in the main buffet restaurant where they had speciality nights; French, Mexican, English etc.Our favourite was the Chinese restaurant as the food and service was brilliant. We went to the Italian a couple of times which was quite nice also however the service was not as good.We only visited the grill restaurant the once and were not very impressed as the food wasnt anything special and the service was poor. Beach  pool:The beach is absolutely gorgeous however it does get extremely busy and if you want a shade you have to be up really early to put your towels out I was up at 7am one morning and they were all gone, I think people must put them out at night!!We spent most of our time by the pool which was a bit cooler and more bearable than the beach, there were always plenty of beds around the pool however very litlle shade.Entertainment:During the day there was the Kiko team by the pool who organised a variety of activities like beach volleyball, beach games, aqua aerobics, the team could be quite pushy to get you to join in with these activities however they did look good fun!In the evenings there are shows on in the Theatre we went to a few and they were amazing it was mainly dancing and music but the dancers were brilliant definately worth seing.Drinking:There are a few bars to go to in the evening we mainly went to the balcony bar above the reception they played nice music and sometimes had singers in the atmosphere was very relaxed here, Maria behind the bar was very funny as she used to break out into a song as she was serving you or just leave the bar to go and dance.Be aware of the drinks as they can be lethal as the cocktails contained about 4 units of alcohol each even though they were nice you'd regret drinking them in the morning!!!Towels:They provide beach towels for you by the pool however I would advise you to take your own as they never had any when we went they always said come back in five minutes and this could carry on for most of the day, in the end we gave up trying.Overall our holiday was great the weather was quite good with a few showers here and there, we made friends with a lovely family and thoroughly enjoyed our stay there - just a shame we had to come home!!We would definately go back to the Dom Rep again!!!

<Content>The vacation I wanted and needed We returned from Grand Paradise Bavero on May 23, 2004. Like many others I was concerned with the resort given the reveiws, but our travel agent indicated that for the price we wanted this was the best place to go. That it was....When we arrived it was before the check in time of 3:00 p.m., we got our braclets and checked in. We were told that the room would be ready at 2:00 and that we should go have something to eat and our bags would be kept in the lobby until our room was ready. So we went to the buffet for something to eat. This was when I started to get nervous as I am a very picky eater and my kids (7 and 4) are fussy as well. My concerns were soon put to rest as I was able to find lots for the kids and I. The food was not overly flavourful, but that is expected since it is easier to add more flavour than it is to take it away.We ate most of our meals in the buffet as it is easier for the kids as the other a la carte restraunts are too slow and fancy (at dinner time) for kids who want to be out doing things. Lunch at the grill (by the beach) was great as they had the grilled cheese and hamburgers. Yes, at lunch we ate at places other than the buffet. Why you ask...that is easy. Kids Club (thanks to Luz and Mary)The Kids Club made the difference in the vacation for me. The staff took our two kids for breakfast (9 a.m.) and kept them until (1:30 p.m.) after taking them for lunch. We would then pick them up and go swimming until 3:00 p.m. when it was time for them to go back to the Kids Club. They would stay there until 5:00 p.m. and then we would go swimming again until it was time to get ready for dinner. After dinner at 8:30 p.m. there was a mini disco put on by the Kids Club staff, this involved dancing, fashion show ect..then it was time for the adult show (which our kids stayed for as it was good and tasteful entertainment). After the show it was bedtime and they were tired. So putting them down was easy. Adult entertainment during the day is very dependant on who is around. If you have a lazy group then the activities flop but if you have an active group the activities are great. I played beach volleyball and water volleyball and tried to learn the club dance with my kids. When you have kids with you the attention by the wait staff is great they like kids. We met 7 other families and all the kids became friends as we did and we all hung out together. After the kids were asleep my husband would get himself a couple of drinks to bring back to the room and I would head off to the disco. The disco was OK, I don't dance alot but enjoyed watching those that could and I did dance with some of the staff at times. The music is out of date but still good music, if you were born in my era (1974).The weather was great, it was not hard to get a chair around the pool. It was slow at getting service by the pool bar (it was really busy as it was the only bar by the pool and it was small) but a tip or two solves that, as does manners. We were so happy with the trip that when we did get asked to listen to the vacation speal we did (if you say no they will not hassel you and if you say that you have already been to the office they will not hassel you either) And we bought the package as we were having such a great time (and it is not just for this resort).The first room we had was big and OK. The room we upgraded to (when we bought the package) was even bigger with two patios over looking the pools and the ocean. It was amazing. But as a warning don't bring in food. Our kids managed to get some in when we were not looking and we had ants the next night. We called the front desk and they were killed and never came back. Oh one last thing English is like the 3rd or 4th language for the staff and is poor at the best of times, but keep in mind that this is not the US or Canada. No matter what you are eventually able to make them understand and when they don't they direct you to someone who can speak better English.Have fun....make the best of it and enjoy

<Content>what we expected We read a lot of the reviews on this hotel, so we were prepared for some of what we witnessed at this hotel. Overall I thought everything was ok, except for the other guests at the hotel. There were hardly any English-speaking people at this resort, something that I was not expecting at all. It was truly one of the most miserable days of our life! They told us it was a 35 minute drive to board a catamaran. By the time we got to the island it was after 1:00 pm and the food was not ready. We did not get soemthing to eat until 1:30. We boarded the bus at 4:00 for a 4 hour bus ride back to our hotel. What a disaster!! Overall, I was disappointed with Punta Cana. We have traveled to many islands in the Caribbean but, there is nothing to see on this island. Just the beach and trees. If you are content to lay on the beach locked up in a resort, then this is the place for you.

The theme nites at the buffet always offered something good and the pasta bar was nice too. Italian was the best. Asian was terrible. Grill was xcellent the 3 times we ate dinner there with atmosphere and romantic too. The grill had great chicken, pork chops and even German sausage for lunch. The grill is the best place for lunch if you want to walk a few steps from the beach to lunch in your bathing suit only. Generally the service was slow and we did have to ask for drinks a few too many times, xtra napkins, whatever. The staff were always smiling and polite. We said por favor, gracias, buenos dios and smiled a lot-they loved us and we were only exercising a little courtesy-BIG DEAL.I VALUE THE FOOD AT $80US/DAY.BEACH: Unbelievablely beautiful. The sand is fine and clean. I found no rocks or shells in the water or on the beach. We did see some seaweed a few days but the staff were even picking that up from the beach. Sunblock 30-45 are needed but make sure you bring xtra unless you want to pay $20-30US a bottle. The water was very clean and not too cold. The waves were just enough to keep you busy. Yes the shade was limited but do you expect the resort to provide enough shade for every guest. Yes we competed for a shade hut and got up at 630-700A to reserve a lounge. Bring at least 2 blue towels with you because you cant get beach towels before 900A. Behind the Grill there are some very nice palm trees that provide shade most of the day. Its a little crowed and a few steps further to the beach but you'll need some xtra exercise to shed the weight you will gain from eating too much.I VALUE THE BEACH AT $10US/DAY. Free beaches are rare on LI.POOLS: There are 2 very large pools. I found them very clean and cool. After 3pm the water gets too warm (what do you expect??). The cholorine was OK. No shade around the pools. The whirlpool near the beach is relaxing but can get crowded.GROUNDS: Very clean and well laid out. The palm trees, grass and plants are well maintained. The 2 pools and restaurants are an easy walk from most buildings. I think Bldg 3/6 (even # rooms) are the niceest because you have a nice view of the pools. I didnt see other buildings with any nice views and forget about ocean views because the palm trees block the view and they dont have too many ocean view rooms anyway.SHOPPING: Do not shop at the gift shop. The flea market is a 15 minute walk down the beach. If you dont like to haggle either pay 3x the value or don't shop. I found the local vendors very nice but pushy. They are trying to make a living-be nice and use yuor broken spanish. Many of them speak other languages too! A little patience, cortesy and a smile go a long way. We spent at least 1 hr shopping on 3 occasions-what's the hurry.I usually offered a little less than 1/2 and started walking away-I usually got my price. Be sure to clarify US, Canadian, Euros before you offer a price. We ran out of $$ and used the ATM in the Sports Bar-Dominican Pesos only. The exchange rate was @ 43 pesos to the US$. At the flea market I bargained for 40 pesos to the US$ and got it-they wanted as much as 55 pesos!!!WEATHER: I kept track every day.2 days overcast but partial sun-@85 degrees1 day overcast w/very little sun-@80 gegrees8 days sunny/hot-@ 85 degreesRAINED 10 minutes on 2 days only.ENTERTAINMENT: Every night they had a show which was good but not great. We were very tired every night and skipped the show 3-4 nites.I VALUE THE ENTERTAINMENT AT $20US/DAY. DRINKS: We are not drinkers but did have 1 tropical drink, 1/2 beer (very good) and 1 cordial evry nite. The people drinkin didnt seem to mind the HOUSE BOOZE!! There were plenty of bars to go around.I VALUE THE DRINKS AT $20US/DAY. TOURS/BOATING/ETC: Plenty to do but we didnt try anything. Can be expensive.TIPS: I never tipped more than $2 and only for xtra service.SUGGESTIONS:#Bring insulated cups#Bring small insulated bag for bottled water (2 liter)#Bring or buy a beach bag#Bring at least 75 $1 for tips/flea market#Buy post cards at end of Flea market#Bring a supply of notes in spanish if you want your eggs cooked right.#Bring 2 pairs of glasses/sun glasses# Stay away from golf shirt guys selling vacations unless you go away 2-3 times a year#Buy the photo at the airport#RELAX RELAX RELAX!!!!!!!MY ESTIMATE OF DAILY VALUE OF RESORT:ROOM $80US/DAY.FOOD AT $80US/DAY.BEACH AT $10US/DAYDRINKS $20US/DAY. ENTERTAINMENT $20US/DAY. TOTAL $210/DAY/COUPLE COST: $135/DAY/COUPLECONCLUSION: We got a lot more than we paid for. If you want better food, beach, pool, room, drinks, service then pay $300/ day at another resort. We were very satisfied with Grand Paradise. We couldnt afford more money and would prefer to come again for the $2500 it cost us including air fare rather than the typical $5000 I saw for other resorts/locations. My wife and I enjoyed 10 days without any interruptions, phone calls or family crisis-PRICELESS!!!!!!! We have fond memories and some very nice photos to remind us of our 10 days in PARADISE We always found something good to eat and walked up and down the beach every day. Every nite we sat on a lounge at the beach and listened to the surf. We actually had time to talk to each other and thorougly enjoyed each other's company. We are still in love after 38yrs and 4 kids.

<Content>Had a great time My husband and I traveled to this resort April 23-30, 2004 and had a wonderful time. We are early 30's at 6 months pregnant, and were looking for RR. The resort was full of couples and families of all ages. Our building was #5 and was handy to everything. We had no issues checking in or out as we arrived and left in the evening. The people bent over backwards to accomodate us, very friendly. The food was plentiful and the beach was paradise. We enjoyed ourselves but did hear some stories from some other guests who were dwelling on an issue and letting it ruin their trip. For example:1. Check in - if you arrive in the morning be prepared not to have a room available. Just wear your swimsuit under your clothes, strip, grab your towel and hit the beach. The hotel was full and checkout is 1pm. Check in is 3pm. The hotel cleaning staff works from 9am-6pm. So there was a family who were vocal about waiting 5 hours to get a room and it wasn't ready when they got into it. This set the tone for their holidays and didn't seem too happy even mid way into their vacation. We arrived after 6pm and were processed quickly. Our bus departed at 5pm, so we checked out at 1pm and enjoyed ourselves until 4pm and got cleaned up and hopped onto the bus. The luggage was left behind for this 4 hours and was safe.2. Not enough ocean view rooms to go around. We didn't pay extra for an ocean view room as we figured why bother? We met 2 couples who did pay extra and ended up with pool view rooms. My opinion is don't bother paying the extra, all the rooms look the same. I only had to walk out my door and faced the beach everyday down the hall.3. Bring lots of $1 US Bills. Come prepared with the small bills and you will have no hassles. People who know this tip and still travel with large bills are asking for the trouble of converting it. 4. Beach chairs under the umbrella huts. People get crazy over the beach chairs when there is no need to get so aggrevated. There is 24 hour beach security. Make friends with these men and you will have no problems. Some people do take others towels, especially from people who mark their chairs and never come back. Some marked chairs are empty all day which wasn't fair. I woke up early everyday and spoke with security. With a small tip they held 2 chairs for us everyday. I didn't feel guilty as we used those chairs all day everyday so I got to see the people who never came back and the frustrated folks looking for some shade. I always told people to speak with the secuirty guys and those that did approach these guys were always given a chair. Even from the resort next door, Breezes. Most people seemed to ignore these kind men who couldn't speak much English but were always trying their hardest sitting in that heat with full uniform on.5. Bring strong sunblock. Some people only brought sunblock 10 and cooked their skin. Sunblock costs $30 US at the stores, so bring at least 30 SPF as well as the 10. The hotel sprays for bugs so don't bother bringing bugspray. We did meet 2 people with a bug bite but they didn't see it happen.The waves are very strong and we saw a man who required help very near the beach. Breezes have the lifeguards.The big thing is to remember that you are on holidays so relax and enjoy yourself. If you have to wait for something, it won't be for food or sun, which is what you are there for anyway. Don't let some little issue ruin your trip and don't keep complaining about it to other guests!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Expectations!!! I have been to a bunch of different resorts in DR, Mexico, St. Maarten, St. Thomas, etc. I have to comment to anyone who is thinking of going to a Caribbean Resort...YOUR VACATION IS AS GOOD OR BAD AS YOUR EXPECTATION. If you think you are going to a American/Canadian 4-5 star resort you would be fooling yourself. As many people have commented poorly about this resort and others, you need to remember you are not at home, most of the people who live in these countries do not have large homes with 2 cars, a pool etc. Their entire family lives with them in a 500 sq ft house. So the hard work, quality food, and other amenities they are providing are 10X higher than what they are used to receiving in their day to day lives. Just thought I should mention this as I have stayed at 3 star, 4 star and 5 star hotels in the Dominican and the difference between them is minimal as far as the quality of food. If you want Wolfgang Puck, you should stay home to get it. But if you open your mind and realize you are experiencing how others live, you will love it.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Grand Paradise Grand Time Well kept and clean. Food had good variety; enjoyed Oriental a la carte restaurant. Buffet had good selection and was air conditioned. Beach restaurant for lunches had excellent burgers and chicken. Plenty to do, beautiful beach. Lots of water sports and recreation. Disco starts late, ends late. My 17 year old and his buds closed it down almost every night we were there livin' la vida loca! Bring lots of small denomination US currency. You'll be surprised what a little tip gets you. Don't think that because it's no tipping, there isn't any. The ones you'll hear complaining most times are the non-tippers. Wake up and smell the coffee; this is the real world! Bring large insulated travel mugs too; the cups at the bar are really small so you'll wind up making far too many trips and waiting in line too often. An small insulated cooler bag is also wise to pack as it's handy for keeping agua (water), cerveza (beer), and (cola) pop icy cold on excursions or at the beach and the boys on the bar are only to happy to fill it with hielo (ice) for you. Realized that this is one of the newer resorts and as a result near the extreme end of the beach. Quite the walk to get where the action was. If you're looking for adventure, Saona catamaran is a great time and a great value. Don't buy anything in resort shops. Take a tour or arrange a car. Merchandise, cigars, coffee are all less expensive in the countryside however be prepared for the harrassment from the locals. They are so poor and see tourists as all being wealthy. They know no different so don't be offended. Females should not travel alone off the resorts and should always be accompanied by males. There's not much to buy there anyway. Roads are brutal and so are the drivers so don't bother renting cars or scooters. This resort was rated four stars. I've stayed on 4 1/2 star in Punta Cana as well. Trust me. You don't want less than four star in Punta Cana.

Buying souveniers - if you go right on the beach you'll come to a bunch of huts with various things to sell. Knock the price down to a third from what they give you (sometimes even more). Some vendors came and setup in the resort one night. Their really expensive, I would wait and go down the beach to purchase same item. Tours - went on the blazing trails horseback tour. Excellent! Lots of running along beach....guide was attentive and helpful. Also, souveniers they sell after are reasonably priced. Also went on 1/2 day snorkeling excursion Tikki something on a paddle boat. They did a great job of entertaining people, Michael Jackson impersonations etc.....lots of fun. Food - Buffet is safest for picky eaters- enough variety that you can find something you like. Italian was good but not a lot of variety. Didn't like the asian but maybe that's just me. Beach Huts - beginning of the week had to get up to put something on lounge chairs under huts by 6:00 am or forget it. Later in week there were some still available around 8:00. Guess it depends on how busy the resort is. We would just put a shirt or towel to hold it and go back to bed..... Disco-lots of people but the music was mostly latin...would of liked to hear a little more variety. Entertainment-Shows were well done with great dancers. There are different themes every night. Only one night with an American music theme though. Didn't catch much of the humour but it was probably 'lost in translation'.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Beaches are beautiful ! I have just returned from a 1-week stay in Punta Cana. It was my first time in the Dominican. Not sure that I would rate this hotel as a 4-star. I have stayed at many all-inclusive 4-stars before and this was average. The good and the bad: The beaches are beautiful ! The weather was gorgeous ! The Dominicans are quite friendly, and those at the front desk (as well as some working on the grounds) actually speak fluent english or french or even Italian or German. The men do leer at women though and say things to each other in Spanish, which makes you wonder what the heck they`re saying about you. The food at the buffet was very good, with alot of variety. The rooms were so-so. We are a couple and had asked for a King, but got 2 double beds (I think most rooms have 2 doubles). The maid comes daily, but sometimes as early as 8:30 a.m. ! So make sure to put your do not disturb card out if you want to sleep in ! As well, the halls are very echoey and the doors slam rather easily, so bring earplugs ! There are alot of activities during the day that are free and the staff are very good at trying to get everyone to participate in beach activities (volleyball, aerobics, etc.). There are spanish lessons, as well as dance lessons, there`s a ping-pong table too. There are 2 pools, which is where most of the activities take place. My biggest complaint was the amount of children in this place. If you are going to relax and get away from kids, I would strongly suggest you book a couples resort. This place was just crawling with crying, whining kids under the age of 6 ! As well, I found that the nights were the dullest, as there`s not that much to do. Oh, and the reservation system for the a la carte restaurants was very poor. They only took the first 20 people per half hour block, so the restaurants were literally half empty at all times, but if you came late, you could very well be eating at 9 p.m. (which is what happened to us the first night!). The shows at night were good (gotta applaud the dancers -- I mean they`re not professionals, just locals, but they work very hard and do a good job). The disco was OK. Oh, if you like Air Supply and Journey, then you will love the repetitious music they play at night in the restaurants. Snore....they could have something a little more recent...And the last biggest complaint was having to get up at 6 a.m. every morning to go lay out my towel on a beach chair under a hut (trust me, you need the shade -- that sun is hot, hot, hot). All choice spots are taken by 6:15 (which makes me wonder what people do on vacation....why are they up so darn early???). Overall, would go back to Punta Cana, but not to this hotel.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The straight truth about this place Where I am coming from: This is my seceond stay in an all-inclusive, so I am not a total expert, but do have a pretty good opinion. My first stay was at Barcelo Maya just south of Cancun.On this trip, we were with a group of about 30 people who went down for a wedding. The wedding was on the beach and went without a hitch (a hah). The resort caters to weddings and ensures that you get everything you would reasonably need to have a wedding.The resort: The facility is decent. Lawns are well kept, the massive pool is always clean, the main check-in building is attractive, and very Latin, the disco is well lit with lasers etc, the lodgings are OK, and the beach is beatiful. You may notice that most of my descriptions are just OK - aside from the beach, nothing here is exotic or extravagant - just OK. The place is well laid out and everything is within reasonable distance.The food: Breakfast: A big dining hall just like at camp. If this were a 4/5 star resort, there would be someone there to make you a sandwich - here it is build your own. In some instances it is quite nice, where someone makes you an omelette, but in most cases its help yourself buffet. We always looked twice at the breakfast food because the dairy is all goat milk. You also see things uncommon to Canadians - perhaps common to Europeans who are a little more diverse, but we North Americans kind of look twice if it doesn't say Kelloggs if you know what I mean. Lunch: Under a large grass thatched open concept hall. The buffet has chicken (you wonder about it a little but it tastes good) a typical North American spread, and some pizza types, with some fruits - again you won't go hungry, but you won't eagerly reach for everything they lay-out. Dinner: Nice: go to the a la cartes - the Italian is great. The Chinese is north Americanized. The food at the Grill is OK - steak was brutal though. (Jeeves pass me my floss) Service at the a la cartes is great. Nice post dinner apertifs too.The bars: great - and everywhere. Their beer is good too - Presidente. Banana mama -mmm. Cuba Libre -mmm por favorActivities: Great - they do a good job getting you involved and they know how to leave you alone too. Volleyball is great. Lots of step classes and dance classes. Waterpolo was great. They are good with kids if you have them. You can sign out windsurfers, boogie boards, snorkel gear, sea kayaks - all the equipment is in great shape. The shows: kind of weak. These people try really hard, and you have to admire the staff - you see the waterfront guys at 8:00 AM and doing activities all day long, and then they are dancing in the shows at night - work work work. While they are great on the beach, I would say they do not pull off the dancing - the resort needs to import more professional talent for the shows. The market: Interesting to learn how these people live and just how poor they are. If you go to the market you will clearly see how desperate they are for $1.00. We bought Ladimar stones, and rum. The cigars are fakes, but probably as good a smoke as you would get at home anyways - watch out for banana leaves though.Do's and don'ts: DO: go to the market down the beach don't: look at the market stuff forever - - its all the same trinkets, art, paintings etc. DO: go to the resort next store - you will see what a 4 star looks like in case you are wondering DO: get your money before you go - take American 1's. If yoiu take bigger money, they all pull the I got no change sr after you barter for price on something: Don't: ever pay full price for something:typically pay 1/3 of what they ask, remembering that, while its fun to barter, these people are sometimes starving - just pay them if you feel you are getting a better deal on stuff you could otherwise buy at home Don't: get change at the front desk: We got 8000 pesos out of the bank machine on site and went up to change it to American at the front desk - she tried to get a $30 service fee to which I immediately raised my middle finger in her general direction. Just pay in pesos. We ended up going to the bank at the casino next door, and traded 500 peso bills to 50 peso bills. Each 50 peso bill is equal to approximately $1.20 US, or $1.50 Canadian. Those bills make for great tipping. Do: tip early in the week - they will like you more for the rest of the week. DO: bring a big mug: the drink glasses are so friggen small you have to refill all the time, which is laboursome should you decide to hang down by the beach. DO: bring tons of lotion - the sun is sooo hot - I got caked my first day - maybe do a pretan in a bed DO: bring some long pants for dinner wear DO: pace yourself - if you like to party, there is plenty of time - the shock of the sun, booze, and heat can wipe you out after a winter of hibernating .Final DO: relax. You are in a third world country where stuff gets done when it gets done. If you are irritated about how long it takes Armondo to stop sweeping the floor to come over and pour you a Presidente, you are in the wrong spot. These people move at 5 miles per hour and have no sense of urgency - never have so why would they when you are standing there. That took me a few days to realize. Once you understand that, you are on holiday.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great place to stay, beautiful country! We stayed at the Grand Paradise February 15th-22nd, 2004 and had a great time. The country is beautiful and the people are very nice and friendly. If you are looking for the hustle and bustle of Cancun, you aren't going to find it here. This is more of a relaxing place to visit as opposed to the party atmosphere of Cancun. There were a few little things that if you are a picky person and these things would ruin your vacation don't come here. Our closet door was off-track, someone came the next day to fix it. We had to wait until the afternoon to get a safe key. We never did end up getting a tv remote, but we were in a beautiful country, so we didn't watch much tv anyway. Avoid the timeshare people (white polo type shirts) and if they approach you just tell them you are not interested, they will leave you alone. We weren't able to get into the a la carte restaurants, so go early if you want to eat at them. Service is a little slow but you are in a foreign country and on vacation so RELAX!!! I speak Spanish fluently and the staff loved it once they found out, so they do appreciate it if you try to speak Spanish. The food was decent, there is always a big selection so you can find something to eat if you are picky (except a decent salad - everything is iceberg lettuce!?). I was a fan of the Dominican Corner which they have every night in the back of the buffet restaurant. They did have a Dominican night one night, which was my favorite night (least favorite was mexican night, not that great). Some pointers: if you want a beach spot in the shade, go out early! Wake up early and catch the sunrise, there is a great vista right around the corner, it is worth it! Bring lots of singles for tips. It is hard to get change in US dollars. The waiters and bartenders do appreciate tips. Eventhough this is an all-inclusive, these people make less than $100US a month. You can tell by giving them a buck or two each night it is appreciated. We gave our maid $2/day and we had great service. She gave us fresh flowers and a newspaper everyday along with diet coke since I asked her for it and they normally only put sprite/coke/water in the fridge. We went on the Saona Island excursion and it was a long day, but very nice, bring water shoes because the island water is rocky! We also went to Santo Domingo which was an even longer day, but if you are intereted in history, it is worth it. There are a lot of stairs, so be prepared to walk. The shopping in Santo Domingo was pretty good, too. We were able to get lots of souvenirs, cigars, rum and mama juana for cheap. The hotel stores and markets down the beach are very overpriced. Finally, we enjoyed the shows at night. They are a little cheesy, if you have been to other all-inclusives you know what I mean, but they are definitely better than other resorts we have stayed at in the Caribbean. Overall, we had a great time here and would definitely go back!

<Content>Great vacation!!! Mind a few details.... We just returned from one week at Grand Paradise Bavaro. The vacation was excellent and we had a great rest. The beach was stunning, the food superb in the main buffet restaurant and the cocktails were available morning noon and night! A lovely touch was afternoon tea on the little lake in the middle of the resort where there were ducks and a heron! Everyone was friendly and helpful and the entertainment team worked extremely hard to keep everyone happy. There was even a disco if you felt energetic enough! We spent a fantastic day going to the Island of Saona which was just like our Bounty Advert at home! and a day at Santa Domingo the Capital of the island. Apart from the speciality restaurants which were mostly half full - we couldnt quite grasp the booking system - and it wasnt worth the effort of going, the hotel was 1st class. We will be returning again next year and hopefully taking some more friends with us.

<Content>Just 'OK" My fiance and I were at this hotel from Jan. 24-31 2004 and judging from the reviews I wasn't sure if this was the best decision that I had made or not. Upon arriving at the hotel our jaws dropped as to how gorgeous the grounds were, palms trees swaying and everything was immaculate. Weather for the whole week was beautiful, there was one night of rain, but it was in the late evening so you could hardly notice it.The BAD POINTS:As we checked in to the hotel, the rumours are TRUE, the hotel staff are rude and non-customer oriented. I work in customer service so i was appalled by the service i received. Our room was 'okay', a bit musty, the closet doors were falling off the tracks but otherwise it was decent. The food overall in the resort was okay, the a la carte ones were great (if you can get in there) and their reservation system is so complicated at times that people were waiting in line to complain. The service in general is so/so, not what you would expect from a four star. Food was okay, however, my fiance and I both came down with symptoms of stomach flu (his came in the middle of the week, mine came the day after our trip). Not Fun. As for tipping, one day we tipped the maid 2 dollars, and received fabulous service. The next day, we tipped 5 dollars, and received nothing, not even towels. It was a real hit or miss, which was a common theme throughout our stay.One more word of advice, if you are single and young, DO NOT go to this hotel. The crowd seemed to be around late 30's to seniors. If you're young and looking for fun, go to the Breezes next store.To sum it up, my fiance and I both agreed that this hotel can be compared to a beautiful woman with no brain. It's beautiful to look at, but no substance/no character to it. If you have any questions, please e-mail me to discuss this further.

<Content>Punta Cana, yes; Grand Paradise NO! It's hard to write a bad review when I'm now surrounded by snow but I must. The service was horrible. Many of the staff were friendly, many were not, there is very little english to be had and the front desk staff seems annoyed at the thought of clients. The beach was the nicest I've seen, we swam everyday and snorkled with the fish feeding them bannanas and bread. No need to go on a snorkle adventure there are free masks and flippers for guest use just sign them out. However you would never know this as there is no information. Thankfully I read reviews from Trip Advisor before I went so we knew to take a $15 US cab ride to a restaurant called Captain Cooks. It is cheap and delicious seafood right on the beach, surrounded by a market and little town. It makes for a good afternoon trip. The Captain Cooks boat will return you to your hotel for free before 5pm. There is also a small grocery store across from the restaurant to buy any forgotten essentials for a resonable price. Stay out of the hotel shop, robbery. We bought coffee to bring home for approx. $1.50 CAN and it's the best. Lots of good in Punta Cana but the service at the hotel put us off, we'll return to Punta Cana, to Captain Cooks but not to the Grand Paradise.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent Vacation!! First of all, I was a little nervous to go to Grand Paradise after reading some of the shady reviews. What a pleasant surprise to find a wonderful resort. Here's some hints about what you might find when you arrive: CHECK-IN - not bad at all, just be sure to ask for a spare key (to turn on the electricity) and for a TV remote (which probably won't work but give it a try anyway). Very quick process, and they ply you with rum punch while you wait. ROOMS - very clean. I was pleasantly surprised to find no bugs and modern bathroom facilities (except for the fact that they request that you don't flush toilet paper - does anyone actually follow that sick rule?). We tipped the maid $2US everyday and always had a clean room and a stocked mini-fridge (Coke, Sprite, bottled water). This is the only area that I have big complaint...any person who works on the resort has access to get into your room at all times. We had the same women (not a maid by the way) come into our room twice while we were in it. When she realized that we were in there she looked very shocked and then asked us if everything was OK (we had made no complaints that would call for someone to check on us). In my opinion that is unacceptable and think that something should be done to stop that. BEACH - so beautiful! The beach is straight from a postcard with soft sand, aquamarine water and palm trees everywhere. Just make sure that you are out by 8:00ish in the morning to claim your chairs for the day. A little tip...don't pay to go snorkeling, it is a big waste of money. Go to the activities stand and sign out a snorkel (you get an hour free every day) and go off the beach at the resort. Bring a banana and you will be a hit with the fish. FOOD  DRINK - better than expected. For the first few nights we ate at the buffet for every meal and that was alright, you get to try many things that you never would at home. On the third night we discovered La Cana (by the beach) which is where I would recommend eating dinner every night. The choices from the menu are excellent (fillet mignon, jerk chicken, cosa nuestra, shrimp, fahitjas, and so much more) but just make sure to be there at around 6:30pm to get a decent dining time. As for the drinks, very strong!! When you ask for an alcoholic drink (and always be sure to specify if you want alcohol in it, cause if you don't say, they won't put it in), they are not shy with the booze. Sometimes a little strong for my liking but hey you're on vacation!!! So overall, I thought that the resort was great. I would recommend Grand Paradise to anyone and hope to return soon.

There is no drink serving on the beach but you can bring your own from the bar. The water is warm and very blue/green very nice.Pool: very nice, big and clean but go get your chair early in the morning or you wan`t have a nice spot for sunbathing. There is NO swim-up bar in the pool.Food: there are 3 restaurants of which 2 require reservations, which can be made only the same day at a specific time so plan ahead and the food is only avearge. The 3rd restaurant/cafeteria style is a self service/buffet with a huge variety of food but the quality is below average. You`ll need to learn what to choose/avoid. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Would have been greate EXCEPT!!! We just got back from our 7 day vacation at Grand Paradise Bavaro on Nov. 24, 2003. I have been reading all of the reviews and NOT ONE of them mentions the problems my husband and I encountered! We definitely enjoyed the food, although the variety was a bit more limited than we had enjoyed at other resorts (a previous trip to Dominican Republic at the Riu Bambu, Barcello Beach Resort on the Mayan Riviera in Mexico, Sol Melia in Cayo Largo, Cuba). The resort itself is very beautiful and the pictures we found on the net did not do it justice. The staff were very accommodating when we asked for a change of rooms, as the Gardenview room they had assigned us initially looked out onto the road, after which we got a splendid room overlooking the pool! The variety of people from all different countries only served to spice it up and we were definitely NOT offended by the nudity in the form of toplessness or thongs. Frankly, North Americans have a long way to go to get over their childish hang-ups about their own bodies.  However, I DID find the time-share salesmen EXTREMELY ANNOYING! The hard-sell tactics got downright ridiculous when the same people not only accosted us just outside of the lobby and buffet dining room (which made it difficult to avoid them), but even when we were minding our own business tanning around the swimming pool. The final straw for me came when one of these desperados accosted us just as we were finishing our beach walk and accused us of NOT REMEMBERING HIM when in point of fact, he had forgotten that he had personally accosted us at least two or three times PER DAY in the first three days of our arrival. This proves that the management at this hotel was more concerned about ensuring future reservations than the immediate comfort of their guests. It obviously does not occur to them that the two are intertwined.  It would have been nice if they could have done something or at least lodged a complaint about the constant helicopters buzzing their guests overhead! Between them and the persistent salesman, it was impossible to get the rest and recreation this resort promised.  Although the rooms were equipped with individual thermostats to control the air conditioning, I think that was a mere courtesy as they did not work. The more we adjusted one way or the other, the colder we got! This made it difficult to have a shower without freezing, as the showerheads were NOT adjustable and no matter where we pointed them, they got the floor wet. We had to drop it in the tub, soap up while freezing and then quickly pick the showerhead up to rinse off!!! Someone must have had a good laugh at the guests' expense when they designed these gems!  I would have loved to take my four children there, as they resort is truly beautiful and the staff does try to please, but the drawbacks are a little too much to have to put up with. Too bad........

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Just got back...wished for a few more beautiful days! Just returned home tonight from a six night trip to the Grand Paradise Bavara. I went with my sister and my best friend from college. For a trio of girls in their twenties we had a wonderful time. There is so much to do and see that I wised we had a few more days. The people of the Dominican Republic could not be any nicer. Both at the hotel, with our excursions, and around the area. Our room was a little musty at first but with the air turned on and my sister bought a candle, we soon felt right at home. The queen beds were a little small and so I asked for a roll a way bed just in case we needed it and they had it in the room within the hour at no extra charge. The housekeeping surface was top rate...I had brought some soap and shower gifts that we gave to the housekeeper the first day and then on the final day..I left a collection of school supplies and wrote her a note to give to her children or children who could use them. She was always great at making sure we had as much bottled water as we asked for and whatever kind of bottled caffinated drinks we requested. We took the opportunity to take Domingo up on his offer and paid $35.00 (U.S) to go horseback riding. You can do a free hour ride in the morning or the two hour ride in the afternoon you pay for but you also get to explore a beautiful cave and take a small hike. We did this and one thing Domingo the guide should have told us was to wear tennis shoes and not riding boots...riding boots are fine for horseback riding but not for the hiking over rocks. If you like riding fast...at about a canter on the beach the two hour ride is a must!! The other ecursion we did was one that came with our travel package..the trip to Soanoma. This was a LONG day..and we had not realized it was going to be so long. We took two buses to get to the town that we then boarded a speed boat to the island. We ate lunch provided for us on the island and sun bathed. We then were taken from a speed boat to a catermoran boat. On the boat there was dancing and drinking...oh and lots of rain (which was freezing)...the rain was the only part that was not fun..the rest was a good time but cold after being rained on. We did not realize that rainy season had started and so we were not completely prepared for the rain. The locals said that the rainy season started earlier this year and that the last couple of years had been harder to predict. The rest of the week we stayed around the hotel laying out by the pool, playing pool games, water areobics, and talking with all kinds of people from differnet countries. We explored the diso one night with some guys from Italy. They spoke a little french and my sister understands french and so it was fun to try and communicate. With the more we drank and danced the less of an effort we had to make and it all turned into a fun time. The only downside in our opinion was the food. We were not completely impressed but also we did not go there to eat..we went to get sun and relax. The safe food for us was the chicken at the grill. I enjoyed the asian food the most of any speciality restaurant. I was dissapointed that each night the desserts were about the same, I was hoping for a little more variety...but it also saved me some calories because I didn't always eat the dessert. Also the other aspect that was different for me was the shopping and hard selling. My sister and I went to Plaza Bavara to shop and we were not prepared for a few Domincans to be outside every store begging you to come in and look around and when you go in the store they follow you around. Also bargening was not something we were use to but my sister did very well with her purchases. We found that if you don't give any eye contact that they don't approach you as aggressively, but again that is not something we were use to so it was hard to change in just a week. The other aspect of confusion for several travelors was how much you had to pay to come and leave the country. It is never really discussed so I will let you all know this is how it is as of the date that we went. You have to pay $10.00 (u.s. dollars) to enter the country. When you pay $10.00 you recieve a tourist card which you need to keep for your return flight. I put mine with my passport and ticket. When you return home you have to turn it in at the airport. If you lose it that is when you have to pay $20.00 to get out of the country. If you have the card you pay nothing to get out..you just turn the card in!! So many people on our bus were really stressed about this point so I wanted to make it very clear. But overall my sister and I agreed we would go back and would have loved a few more days to relax and enjoy the beautiful country and its people.

<Author>Zina9
<Content>I liked it (but wouldn't recommend it for everyone) I stayed at the Grand Paradise Bavaro around the end of August with a friend. I had a great time. The resort was beautiful. The food was average (good variety but bad quality). The staff were very friendly. The service was a little slow at times. The nightly entertainment was great (every other night the staff would put on a show and the other nights were for audience participation). I recommend this resort to families, couples and singles who just wanna kick back and relax. Here are a few pointers to make your trip more enjoyable- 1. Have your bathing suit and sunscreen in your carry-on luggage just in case your room isn't ready. 2. Ask for the remote control and an extra room key at check-in. 3. If you're gonna get a safety deposit box make sure you bring a safety pin so that you can pin the key to your bathing suit (do not lose the key-they will charge you $100 to break into the safe) 4. Bring a little pouch so that when you go to the beach you have some thing to put your room key, sunscreen and camera in. 5. If you go to the vendors be prepared to bargain. Whatever price they tell you, cut it in half. 6. I don't think tipping is necessary. Nobody was really tipping the bartenders and waiters. It's included in your package so that you don't have to worry about carrying money around. We did tip the room maids for the first two days just to be on the safe side. 7. The disco was small and they played the same music every night. If you have a CD you can ask the DJ to play it. If you can get a group of about 10 people, take a shuttle to Mangu at Occidental Grand Flamenco on a Wed or Fri night. (the cab ride shouldn't be more than $5 both ways) It's pretty hype. Overall it's a good resort. My only complaint would have to be the food. Don't be too picky and you will enjoy yourself. Feel free to email me with any questions.
