<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A Piece of Heaven I just returned from an unbelievable vacation two weeks ago at the D.R., staying at the Paradise. My mother, who is 72, and I went to get away for 7 days. I had researched this site as well as others to be well prepared. I read with much horror of what to expect and not to expect that I was nearly ready to choose another destination. GLAD I didn't!!!! We had the time of our lives. The beach is absolutely beautiful. The hotel check in was smooth, the manager there was awesome as well as the staff. We had a wonderful view of the gardens and the pool. English is not readily spoken, unless you run into someone from the USA or Canada, but that didn't seem to put a damper on anything. Sign language does wonders! Point and say gracias and you shall receive. We had wonderful service wherever we went to eat, which the La Cana Grill was by far the most outstanding place with the best service...but then again, we cut up with the waiters and staff so much they knew who we were the second night and went out of their way to please us. TIpping is rec. as they work for peanuts and they work long hours from sunrise to sunset. My mother was not able to sit on their bamboo dining chairs due to her back and some medical conditions, and a quick smile and a few mucho gracias got her a resin chair from the outside. From the first night there, the manager and the waiters would automatically bring her one in before we sat down. AND they allowed her to take one to the beach for her comfort. TIP the housekeeping!!!! Remember these people are very poor and a little gratitude goes a long way. I left a skirt, shorts, a toe ring, pair of sand shoes, sunglasses, and money and I thought they were going to cry. Does the heart good. The drive from the airport is not the smoothest so be prepared to hold on tight! They drive as they want to drive which is without caution! The roads are bumpy, but I wouldn't have had it any other way because you do get to see the real Dominican that way. How these people llive and work, the conditions they live in, and the way their homes look, will surely surprise you! Meat is hung out on racks in the blazing sun all day. No refrigeration! Take in as much as you can because it adds to the experience. We asked for wake-up call every morning and received it on time without fail. Everything else is on their time, but who cared. We were on vacation. Take a walk off the beaten track and you will see squatters alongside the road, frying up bananas and fish. We smiled alot and they waved for us to come over to try some! They love their pictures taken, too. Take some excursions! We took the Monster Truck and what a blast we had. It was exhausting because it is a long day. 7:30 in the morning to about 6:30. My mom hung in though and so did I. That is a must do and see! It takes you to through the plantations, to a dominican's home for fresh brewed coffee, to a voodoo priest, which on the day we went was a holiday do we didn't get to speak with him, to a children's school, a market and toa fresh water river. Much more but it was unforgettable. The sand is the best I've ever been on, the water was perfect in temperature. My mother was diagnosed with inoperable lung cancer a week before we went and she will never forget this beautiful experience. The heat is extreme so make sure you bring alot of sunscreen and stay under the cabana's if you are sensitive to the rays. Even in the shade, one can tan or burn! Bring candy for the children because they are everywhere on excursions and will run alongside the trucks to get a little goody! Throw them a handful and watch the glee! I had candy and cookies and whenever we stopped, there were sure to be a load of children waiting for some goodies. Their little eyes light up and again, it does the heart good. There wouldn't be anything I would change for this vacation and I will surely return one day. Hopefully, with my mother! No need for peso's as the American dollar is more to them than their own so bring cash. $1 is worh 30 pesos to them. Make sure you watch the vendors and take advantage of their bartering. If you don't like the price, name your own and you will eventually get it for your price! It's a hoot! So, have fun, relax and let the Dominican world take you away! It did us and they will forever be in ou hearts! Remember that a smile goes a long way and they actually do like the tourists. Those who had such a bad time maybe expected a bit of America and it's nothing like it so smile, have fun and e-mail me if you want any more information!

<Content>Amazing service/Clean beach Had a great time Delivered above average service than what was expected. This was my first time travelling to the Caribbean. I was very satisfied with the service I received. All areas of the resort were cleaned regularly, including the beach. Food was good, served a lot of the same foods from day to day but nothing to complain about. We lost our safe-key the first night we were there. The master copy was located in Santo Domingo, a 2 hour drive away. I was notified that if they had to bring the master from Santo Domingo to Punta Cana, it would cost $28US. We decided to wait it out a day or two to see if someone would return it. On the day we went to the front desk to tell them to order the key from Santo Domingo they said that someone had returned a safe-key. They got the head of security to take us up to our room and try it out and it worked. They did not charge us anything and the security would not accept a tip. The desk man that had helped us from the start about this issue was tipped generously. We were very satisfied with their honesty and service. Rooms were very clean and well maintained. Only have 2 things to complain about. The first being that we did not receive the room we requested the first night we were there. Second being that our plane did not depart from Punta Cana till 9:00 p.m. and they wanted to charge us $10US to hold our bags from check-out till departure. Overall, I would recommend and definitely return as a repeat visitor. Any questions or inquiries send an e-mail.

<Rating>2	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>chucky2
<Content>Beach vacation with the family Returned from Grand Paradise resort on August 31st after 1 week stay with family. I would rate the vacation overall as very good in all aspects. I am pleased to respond to particular questions by email.Punta Cana Airport: Passing through the airport was a breeze. They will take a picture which you will have the option to purchase for $6 on departure. The bus trip to Grand Paradise is about 30 minutes, and will be an eye opener in terms of the local driving situation, local living conditions, etc. Departure was a little more complicated as a few buses arrived simultaneously. You will pay your $20 per person departure at the airport. Dont be fooled - prices at the airport are outrageous - best to take a taxi to town ($12 one way to Plaza Bavaro) where better deals are negotiated. The taxi ride is another eye opener as above.Hotel Check In and Layout: Check in was fine for us, as I had emailed ahead as suggested by another reviewer. Showed the desk the copy of my email, and sure enough they complied with my request. We were in building #3 , ground floor, facing one of the pools (2nd pool from the beach). At check-in we received 2 room keys, 4 beach towel cards, the TV remote, and I returned later for the key for the safe and an internet card (to access one of the two computers at the sports bar). The room was large and well maintained - ample room to acquire a cot for our son. I would say the buildings are layed out very well, spacious, and you would only walk a few minutes from any part of the resort to get to the pools or beach. Nevertheless, if you are fussy about location, building 6 and 3 would be the best, with rooms ending in even numbers facing the pools in the resorts interior area. Odd numbered rooms face the other way. Building #2 towards the beach (even numbered rooms), would also be very good. It is unrealistic to request ocean view as there are none (or very few). The buildings meet the beach area on a 90 degree angle, and do not face the beach. Those that do, the view would be obstructed by palm trees, etc. There are three pools and a Jacuzzi suitable for all ages. But no infants wading pool that I could see.Beach: Very long and stunning, with good surf for beach fun. Good for long walks (Breezes Resort is next door to the left, the only resort neighbour - you have to see their lobby!), and the small flea market is about 10 minutes walk to the right. We snorkelled and fed fish bread from our hands (some people said bananas were just as good) and took pictures. The beach is enclosed with buoys to keep the boats out of the swim area - or people out of the boat area. A rocky area to the far left inside the buoys will offer the best view of fish. The beach will have the cabanas/huts and since I am an early riser, I would place our towels out there at about 6:45-7am to reserve a spot.Activities: There will be many options, however, I found them to be pricey. We did try most of the inclusive activities like scuba lessons in pool, ping pong, beach volley ball, horse back riding, but paid for extras such as parasailing. The theatre shows were excellent (3-4 large shows, magician, and 3-4 audience participation shows) usually intermingled with dance sessions, etc.Food: We found the food to be excellent. The three al la cartes (Cana Grill steak house, The Chinese Food, and Italian) were superb in quality and service. We had breakfast always at the buffet and that was excellent , and we had lunch always at the Cana grill (BBQ chicken, pizza, hot dogs, fries, fish, burgers, salads, etc) - all very good. We dont trust dairy products though. Stick with bottled water provided in your room fridge, or at the bars when they have a supply). I would say that there is very good ambience in all the restaurants but our favourite was the Cana Grill at night eating by the ocean.Economy: US Dollars are universally accepted anywhere. We tipped $2 for the maid each day and got very good service - and a few waiters whom we got to know by name were given $1 occasionally (for blender drinks with real fruit added - bananas for the Bahama Mamas). We also tipped at the a la cartes $4. Dont get pesos at the Hotel- they will only give you 29 per dollar, at the bank at Plaza Bavaro they give you about 35. So the Hotel takes 20% off the top. Its a moot point again since most will take $US. The whole economy is based on negotiation. I got a CD for $10 not $20. Hair braiding for our daughter for $25 at Plaza Bavaro, not $55 asked for at the Hotel. Trinkets are always $3-4 dollars and jewellery about $10 . Paintings $10-20. And so on...Tips: We brought two cheap inflatable rafts for the beach; insulated travel mugs for the drinks; fooz ball and pool are available in the sports bar, and internet access; plenty of strong sun screen, and for light skinned persons, limit your sun exposure to avoid sunburn; take immodium, Tylenol, antacid, and emergency kit for any scraps; might consider water shoes for kids as there is the odd rock at the surfs edge that could be sharp but no problem really; we brought our own snorkel equipment even though it is provided; usually enough shade at the beach; we decanted water from the large bottles into smaller ones to take with us; there were no mosquitoes, just the odd sand flea at dusk - we would brush them off;Negatives: Occasional language barriers; occasional indifference among bar tenders; a few delays but as other reviewers have stated , Chill out this is a different country.; somewhat pushy vendors at the Flea Market or Plaza Bavaro; you dont need pesos even if told you need them, if you do get them, go to a bank; poor road conditions and risky driving behaviour; some rudeness among foreign guests; hi prevalence of smoking among foreign guests; noise levels in ground level hallways may permeate ground level rooms; ensure locks on ground level patio doors are functional; occasional bad TV reception - (satellite); avoid hi prices in resort gift shop; finally I found this destination is slightly pale in character and is less carribbeanized than other locations such as Barbados, St. Lucia, Cuba. It is basically a beach vacation with the family at this all inclusive resort with all the bells and whistles. You rarely travel on your own outside to explore the culture. Some destinations like Cuba, Hawaii, Jamaica, etc, have an allure. But if it is beach you want, you have found it here!Pleased to respond to any questions at ejodoin2@cogeco.caErnie

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Vacation Aug 16 - 22, 2003 Folks, here again we find a vacation that is good value for the money. The food was well above average and by the sheer number of choices available, I saw no one starving while I was there. It is not the Ritz Carlton so don't expect to be pampered as if you paid those kind of prices. The hotel was clean, especially the restaurant areas. In spite of what I read about the staff, I found them to be very accomodating and while it is true you must exhibit a bit of patience, not a great amount is required. I found a lot of tips helpful, e.g., placing the towel early in the morning assured getting a hut for the day. The tip about 2 keys was well stated so we could keep the air and power on the entire day. Reservations are no longer required for dining in the varous restaurants. One note: I read some guy's review from New York in which he states the Italian restaurant was like nothing he has eaten in Brooklyn. Well, having lived in Europe for 29 years and having traveled to Italy on numerous occasions, it was refreshing to eat fairly credible Italian food--a la Italy as opposed to a la American - Italian. With such a large number of Italians, French, and Germans, it was only fair to assume the Italian restaurant was catering to the European taste. In short, the food was good. I would recommend this resort to anyone who genuinely wants to get away and spend time lying around on the beach. Finally, the 9:00 a.m. horseback riding session (free to all guests) was a great surprise since we rode for about 75 minutes and were able to go to the beach on horseback. Give it a try--you'll love it. Jeff Tobin

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A Beautiful Resort My friend and I visited this resort April past and had an amazing time! I've noticed some of the bad reviews given about this resort and I honestly don't understand why. The beach was picture perfect, the pools were spotless and the landscape in general was beautiful. Overall the food was pretty good in both the buffet restaurants and at the a la carte restaurants. Sure, you are bound to run into some things that are not as appealing, but given the many choices and varieties, it is almost impossible not to find something tasty! The bars were pretty good, except for the long line up at some. Usually the pool bar is the busiest and can get quite congested at times. We usually just wandered over to another bar and most of the time got served right away.  The staff are for the most part very friendly. The animation staff have the most energy and are constantly trying to get you involved in games, and various activities. I have to warn you that they are quite persistant at times (even when you insist that you don't wish to take part), especially with females, so if you want to avoid this just hang out around the beach and not the pool when you hear or see them getting ready to start an activity. Because guaranteed, once they see you and decide they want you to take part, before long you will find yourself up in front of everybody trying to learn the dance to their theme song!!  The only slight annoyance I had with this resort was the reception staff. Most of them aren't as willing to make your stay as comfortable as the rest of the staff. You will have to wait to get your room untill at least three, maybe even later. We knew this before we got there, so upon arriving early, we didn't get upset to find our rooms unavailable. We made the best of it and took a tour of the place, had a few drinks and some food. By this time, our room was ready! For some strange reason, the reception staff speak the least amount of English and for this reason give an attitude of indifference to your problems. Don't get too upset, Dominican people are a very relaxed sort of people who don't rush for anything. They don't seem to mind if things don't go right, they take everything as it comes without getting too worked up about it! haha Most of us aren't like that! The thing to do when you have a problem is remain calm and remember to smile and be friendly. This will get you so much further with them than if you get frustrated and angry. You might feel like screaming, but in the long run, you will get your problem solved much faster by adapting to their ways a little and being pleasant!  All in all, this was a great resort and I would definately recommend it to people who like to take it easy and have fun! This was my second time in Punta Cana (stayed at the Sunscape Hotel the first time) and it was no worse or no better! Punta Cana is always a blast!

Keep in mind that the temperatures in Punta Cana are extremely warm, and the sun is constantly shining through the windows of your room.. so the air conditioning is only on when you are in your room, with the key in the slot.... don't expect relief from the heat instantly. I was on the first floor at this resort, so i had sliding doors w/ a small patio that any one could easily walk onto, the only bad part was that my doors wouldnt lock, so i would adivise that you check that out first thing. There is no remote in the room, so you have to go to the main desk to request your remote, if for any reason you are to steal the remote and bring it home w/ you ( yeah ok like any one would really do that) they charge you $20... there is no coffee maker in the room, and you have to go an put down a $35 deposit for an Iron. The hair dryer is useless since its power was very weak. The Food. Once you see how disgusting the food is on your first day, you will not want to try the Italian or Chinese resturaunts there. So if Italian is one of you favorite types of foods, trust me don't scar yourself by trying their specialty foods here, you'll NEVER want to eat Italian again....stick to fruit...and don't drink the water they serve you at your meals, its 'purified' but tastes like crap and made my family quite ill.The majority of the people who visit this resort are Europeans, some women had no problem taking off their shirts and flashing their disgusting bodies and boobs. A lot of child nudism as well, prepare to see 11 year old girls walking around topless. Don't their parents worry about the perverts on staff?Some of you who are reading this who went to this resort and had the times of your life have not travled enough. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great place - Highly recommended (July 21, 2003) Just got back from the Gran Paradise and I would definitely recommend this resort to other travellers. My husband and I have travelled to numerous caribbean destinations and this resort was a great value for the money. Here's why:Beach - The beach was beautiful and long. Fine white sand and cool, clean turquoise water with fun waves. There is also a reef that you can swin to from the shore to do some snorkeling. It was great! The beach is lined with lots of tall, picturesque palm trees and plenty of straw huts and beach chairs. But, the resort was full when we were there and you must get up early (7:00 to 7:30 a.m.) in order to secure yourself a hut and a much recommended place in the shade. Warning: we did get our shady spot snatched from us on one occasion when we went for lunch eventhough we left our towels on the chairs!!! FYI this beach sits on the Atlantic ocean and not the caribbean.Food - The food here was very good, better than some higher rated resorts we've been to in the past. Lots of variety and theme nights at the buffet. Also, unlike other resorts, the lunchtime buffet was quite different and non-repetative from day to day. ++ Everything was also kept quite clean. The 3 a la carte restaurants were good too. With regards to the restaurants, the resort claims that you do not need reservations but, you must go to the restaurant in advance and put your name on a list with the time which you would like to eat at (What we call in Canada, a reservation) But, you cannot do this buy phone from your room!!!!Pool - Didn't spend much time at the pools (there are two side by side) because the beach was too good and the pool water was too hot. But, the pools are big and picturesque with lots of surrounding vegetation, good music, good atmosphere and action. Note: there is no swin up bar at the pool, but there is a bar right next to the big pool.Bars - They were good, open early and closed late (pool bar 'til 11:00 p.m.  grill bar 'til the wee hours.) Selection of drinks was good, no complaints except for the slow service.Gym - Good for cardio but poor for weight-training (improper benches and not enough free weights). And, you must train with your running shoes, no sandals allowed. (They won't let you in the gym with sandals). The hotel also has a Spa service, but this is at extra cost.Rooms - The rooms are nice but there are very, very few ocean view rooms. We suggest you request a pool view instead! Although, you might never even come close to getting what you ask for. We had quite a fiasco with our rooms - yes I mean roomS, we had three in one week!!! The first had two beds and no A/C. We complained and only got our new room on night three. The second still had two beds and the bathtub did not drain water. We complained and had to stay there for one night. We finally caught the manager and complained to him. He apologized to us extensively and promised us that we would get a proper room and a complimentary gift for our troubles. So finally we got a room with one large bed, A/C, and a properly draining tub - but, no ocean view, no pool view, and oh ya, water dripped from the ceiling in the bathroom. And that complimentary gift must have been sent to one of our previous rooms, because we never got it!Check-in  service - Definitely, this is the hotel's weak point. FYI check-in only begins at 3:00 p.m. no matter what time you get there! This does not mean that you will get your room at three, in fact most people get there room way past 3 o'clock. We only got ours at around 5:30 p.m. Many people complained about this issue but they didn't get anywhere. The hotel's response was that's just the Dominican way. FYI un momento = min. 20 canadian minutes and magnana means... never. The service there is very, very slow so you can count your arrival day as a total write-off no matter how much you complain. It's just the Dominican way!!!Overall - we did enjoy ourselves here and would return and recommend this hotel to our friends with some key points of advice... be patient, relax and have fun... you're on vacation!!!!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Honeymoon at Grnad Paradise My husband and I just returned from our honeymoon at the Grand Paradise Bavaro in Punta Cana. We had a fabulous time. The beach and resort were very clean and well maintained. The staff were very friendly although English is not the main language. Check in was a little confusing since our room was not ready until after 5:00. Our room was nice, nothing extravagant though. We thought the food was pretty good. Our favorite place was the La Can Grill for dinner. The seating procedure is a little confusing and I know many people get upset. What we did was go at 7 when they open for dinner and put our name in for the next available seating time. They only seat every half hour. Basically, we tried to be patient and understanding. Sometimes the service was slow but we preferred it to going to the buffet restaurant. Our highlight of the trip was the two tours we took. We did the Bavaro Splash where you get to drive the speed boat out into the ocean and go snorkeling and we also did the Punta Cana Runners Tour where you go into the fields and plantations and meet the rural people and tour one of their houses. You also get to go to a ranch, ride horses, and have lunch. It was spectacular. I highly recommend taking a day to do that. Beware of the locals market when you walk down the beach. They will really try to get as much money out of you as they can. Barter with them and walk away if they won't come down in price. All in all it was a great time.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>A vacation club in paradise We just returned from a 2 week vacation that consisted entirely of fun in the sun... except for the occasional one-minute rain showers. I decided to do a write-up while everything was still fresh in my mind. We arrived at Grand Paradise Bavaro before noon on June 29th, 2003 and were informed that our rooms were not yet ready... we were prepared for this from reading reviews before departure. It is wise to have your bathing suit and a change of clothes with you so that no time is wasted upon arrival. The all-inclusive braclets are given to you so you are free to take advantage of everything available. It is helpful to know other languages other that english...such as spanish, italian or french as the reception staff have a limited understanding of english. The complex is constructed with all buildings and facilities very close together. The animation team puts on shows that are second to none and the club dance is easy to learn and fun to dance along to. The huts on the beach are occupied quickly so if you want a spot, wake up before 7 and lay your towels out on the lawn chairs. The resort store is extremely overpriced but there is a market 10 minutes down the beach where you could truly find a good bargain... spruce up on your haggling skills... but every few nights vendors arrive and you can purchase dominican paintings and jewelry at good prices... remember that they want to sell to you so YOU THE BOSS. The departure tax has increased to 20 US$ so be prepared for that. There are also many photo oppurtunities during the week with parrots, monkeys and snakes but each photo is priced at 5 US$...the photos are very good quality but a tad pricey. The mini fridge is restocked daily with water, sprite, and coke. The maids are all very polite and willing to help out. The Las Arenas bar is usually understaffed and the drinks are water-downed... it takes a while to get service but the bartenders are super friendly at all times. The disco has the smallest dance floor ever and smokers puff away while dancing. We met many people from all over Europe and Canada and were devasted to have to leave. Make sure to get involved in the pool games... winners usually get a certificate but the last night each winner on stage was awarded a bottle of dominican rum. The buffet has a theme dinner everynight that was delicious but if you want to eat a la carte that get there early... before 7pm to ensure a meal earlier than 9:30 since that is when the show starts... don't miss out! If you choose this as your destination of choice you will not be disappointed! Happy holidays!

<Content>What a great week We just returned from this wonderful resort (May 25-June1, 2003) and had an amazing time. We had read all the reviews about this resort and for the most part the good reviews are very accurate. Those who wrote bad reviews about this resort perhaps were expecting something else. We saw a number of guests who were rude and abrupt with some of the staff, and in doing so got that back. We had a couple of small problems (double beds when we asked for a King) but with smiling faces and a very non agressive threatening manner we were dealt with very well. Some of the comments were about the lack of english being spoken, well really you are in their country, it does not take too much effort to try and learn a few key words. The locals seem to appreciate the effort. As in life, if you smile the world smiles with you. The week we were there the hotel was only around 70% full so were were fortunate to walk up to any restaurant without booking. The same for the beach, we were always able to find somewhere to sit. The resort is well laid out and is well kept. The rooms were large and very functional. As with anything, there were one or two niggly things that needed some attention but nothing that was going to ruin our week. We took someone else's advice from this review board and tipped our room cleaner on the second night, it does make a difference. We took advantage of the free horseback riding and thoroughly enjoyed it. Word of caution, wear long pants. I still have the saddle sores!! We also did the 007 speed boat tour with snorkelling. That was a lot of fun and we got some great underwater pictures.....we hope. We must compliment the food and beverages at this resort. The food was amazing, very tasty and good quality. The house red and white wine was suprisingly good. The coffee was excellent and the fruit drinks and punches were very good. Due to 9/11 this hotel began maravelling dwindled significantly. We found there were a lot of French, English and Italians at the resort. Very cosmopolitan. We did take a walk to the Breezes next door and it looked like a very nice resort, however they are next door to dense forestation which is a breeding ground for the mosquitos. We were not at the Breezes for more then 10 minutes before we both encountered a number of mosquito bites. This was not a problem at all at the Grand Paradise. All in all we would dfintely go there again and would not hesitate to recommend this resort to other people. Go with an open mind and a relaxed attitude and you will enjoy yourselves. <Content>3/24-3/28/03 Great place to vacation if....... Grand Paradise is an absolutely beautiful resort. No one will ever be able to dispute that fact. Our vacation was a charter based out of Atlanta, Georgia and everyone on our flight was heading somewhere in the Dominican. A number of other couples were staying at the Grand Paradise as well. Throughout our stay, we compared experiences with our new friends and the only complaint that anyone had was the language barrier. It almost seemed as if the resort staff went out of their way to ignore English speaking guests. If you speak Spanish, French, or German, you will not have any problems. If you only speak English, be prepared to figure everything out on your own.This sort of indifference to English speaking guests seemed to be a common thread with everyone on our return flight from the Dominican, no matter what resort had been visited. Overall our vacation was a success. My wife and I traveled with our children ages 10 and 7. The resort offered many activities that kept their attention as well as ours.For those traveling from the States with children or teenagers, keep in mind that the Dominican is a haven for a great number of French and German. The only reason that I mention that is because you may want to talk with your children about the large amount of topless sun bathing that takes place on the beach as well as pool side. We were aware of this before traveling but thought it was worth mentioning for someone traveling to the area for the first time. If the resort could fix the language barrier for English speaking guests, I'd return in a heartbeat. That was truely the only hiccup in our trip.

A couple of days into our stay there was a 1 year anniversary offer from the resort for a free 1 day trip to Santo Domingo with 1 night in an all-inclusive resort there. We enquired at the front desk but due to the constant delay in getting service there, we were approached by another guest of the resort. She warned us about taking the resort up on their offer as other people had taken the offer and when they came back to the resort they didn't have a room. We will go back to the Dominican Republic but I don't think I would want to go through the hassle at this resort again.

<Author>MississaugaRed
<Content>Awful travel, Greatest vacation We visited the Grand Paradise Bavaro the last week of February - a group of 10 people ages mid-30's to mid-50's. In no time we were all feeling and acting like teenagers. How could you not when the staff there went out of their way to make your stay as relaxed or fun-filled as you desired.The awful part of the trip was the travel - Redseal/Jetsgo supplied. We have renamed the air line JetsSTOP. While the staff manning the aircraft were very pleasant and as accomodating as they were able to be, the fact that we were using a fledgling travel  air carrier meant we had all the problems associated with using the low man on the totem pole. From departure time, to gate access, to over booked hotel rooms, we were the people getting bumped. Our flight was delayed longer than any others the day we left Pearson. In spite of a storm the day we left all other air lines got away within an hour or two of their scheduled departure time. We had an eleven hour delay! An hour of that sitting on the plane because they couldn't get the luggage loaded properly. Say no more. Our solution - Pack as much fun as we could into the time we had did have. We kept a positive attitude, generally entertaining ourselves (and others) in the process. Once we got to the resort, the spacious  clean rooms were a welcome sight. We were kept supplied with bottled water  soft drinks. Maid service was propmpt. Maybe too much so, as housekeeping would sometimes try to enter our room before it was vacated in the morning. It took us several days to realize there was a way to lock the door. So, FYI - moving the handle into an upward position means the staff may knock, but they can't come in! I also begged a do not disturb sign from one of the housekeeping staff I encountered, which solved that little issue. Our rooms were in building 2, close to the pool and beach which was perfect for our needs, just far enough away to cut down some of the noise if you were an early to bed kind of person. The resort has a very compact  efficient layout which meant everything was easily accessed. You didn't have to give up an hour of your time to pop back to your room if you forgot something, or if you needed to go up to the front desk. We close a daily nesting spot between the pool and the beach. The pool bar was right there and a lot of the activities during the day took place pool side next to the bar. It made it very easy to join in the various games, dance lessons  aerobic sessions that went on at various times all through the day. The same staff that supervised these activities were also part of the nightly show times and were often seen assisting with special events at the disco late into the night. The animation team put in a very long day and should be commended for generally keeping an easy going and friendly manner no matter what the circumstances. The disco was hit and miss. Some nights were packed and a little smokey for our taste, other times the music was great and the mix of people just right for a good time.The beach was beautiful. It seemed to go on forever. The water was very surfy, which make it great for playing, maybe a little rough for very small children to go into without a parent. The surf action did change during the day so it might seem fairly calm during the morning but pick up a bit in the afternoon. Nothing that an adult with even a reasonable amount of swimming talent couldn't handle. The food was great. Not one of our party had a problem of any kind related to the food or drink. At the buffet the menu was always varied. A differnent theme was used each night during the week. There was always a good assortment of vegetables, fruit, meats, pasta and deserts. They usually had a couple of specialty stations set up with the nightly theme food. The grilled steak  pork they made a couple of nights was excellent. My only disappointment with the buffet - it was totally enclosed, with a limited number of windows and none that opened. The same for the Asian and Italian restaurants, which were all part of the same building. Now, I'm sure they have a reason for designing the layout like this, but part of the joy of travelling during Canadian winters to the carribean is being able to do so much outside in the warmth! It would have been nice if the buffet, where you had to take breakfast and where you dined any night that you didn't have a reservation at a specialty restaurant, could have had at least some outside seating. The beach restaurant was lovely. It served a nicely varied lunch (the pizza was always fresh, thin crusted with a variety of topping; great hamburgers - ask for them well-done!), during the dinner hour it was The Grill restaurant requiring reservations, and between mid-night and 1:00 a.m. served a late night snack. They staff there were wonderfully flexible with the timing for the mid-night snacks. If they had enough takers, they would stay open late and throw on fresh food for you. I know we ate there after 2:00 a.m. at least a couple of nights. They would accomodate by keeping that bar open a little later as well. We did get into The Grill restaurant 2 nights, and it was the best atmosphere you could want for a tropical evening dining out. The staff were great. The pre-dinner drink service was a little slow at first, but once we started joking with the wait staff they quickly picked up on our vacation-fun spirit and joked and teased us in return - while sending over ample drinkage all the while! In general we found the Dominican people to be generous and good-natured. Most of the staff spoke some language other than their native Spanish, although that language was not always limited. I admit to feeling a little inadequate when having to tell them I spoke only English. Luckily one of our party spoke french and another Italian, so we were always able to be understood. The locals were also very pleased anytime we made the least effort to address them with the limited Spanish we knew from our phrase books. Please make the effort if you go there - it's worth it to show them that you respect their culture and appreciate the opportunity to enjoy their country. Yes, the tourist industry is very important to the Island, but that doesn't mean we should be dismissive of these people's pride and worth. If you treat those who are working there like people and not like servants your vacation will be the better for it. You'll come away with new friends and happy memories, and maybe leave some of the same behind you with them. Other things we learned:There is a market about a 10-15 minute walk down the beach. They offer a little bit of everything. The prices they were willing to take for their wares changed from day to day. Bottom line: If you're not comfortable with the price, say No, Thank-you, and walk away. Tomorrow the price could be higher or lower, for no reason we could see other than the mood of the vendor at the time.Take American dollars: Last year we visited the La Romana area of the DR and were advised to use pecos whenever possible since that was their currency. This year, no one seemed happy unless they were getting American money. They would jack the price up so much if you wanted to pay in pecos that even with the exchange it was cheaper to pay in American Dollars than in Canadian converted to Pecos. Do not take damaged bills: We couldn't give away an American $50 bill we had because it had a slight tear on one side. We tried at the market, at the resort and even at the Punta Cana airport - no takers. Something about their banks not accepting it.Travel mugs: Take them! Not only do they make for fewer trips to the bar or restaurant but it keeps your beverage colder/hotter longer. Also - great for trading. The locals don't have access to these kind of things. Several vendors offered to trade a t-shirt for my mug - which I might have done if it had been the last day instead of one of the first!Salty Snacks: If you can't go an entire week without chips or chocolate, take your own. What they have available there in the gift shop or at the airport is hugely expensive. These treats can also be used as a thank you to particularly helpful staff. Air mattresses: we took a couple to inflate when we got there, using a small bicycle pump we had. It made for a more comfortable lounge chair as well as a great water toy. The cheap ones from Canadian Tire work well and can be left behind as a gift for one of the staff with children.If you enjoy Volleyball - take your own: We did and didn't have to wait for anyone else to get a game started. The sports hut shut down at about 6:00 p.m. and they would always take the equipment back. With your own, you can play indefinitely, or at least as long as your teams last. Medical supplies: As well as the usual medications you'll think you might need, take bug spray and bandaids. If you are usually a feast to bugs here in Ontario it's going to be open season on you in the DR. Not everyone got bitten, but those of us were normally do here, got it there too. Bandaids are a must because if you're wearing sandals after being in winter shoes for several months, you're bound to end up with blisters  sore spots.Sunscreen: The cost of a 30SPF bottle there translated to about $46 Canadian. You will need it -take it from home and save yourself a bundle.A La Carte Restaurants - they changed their set-up during the week we were there. Instead of making reservations it became first come, first served. We were able to go up to a restaurant around 6:00 p.m. and get in the schedule for the first available seating, which might not be until 8:00 or 9:00 pm. which suited us fine.Hope this is helpful in some way. The best advise anyone can give no matter where you're vacationing is to keep an up-beat attitude - the fun will find you if you do! Go with the intention to enjoy and you can't miss! I will happlily answer whatever questions anyone might have.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>We loved it ! We just returned from a 1 week vacation at the Grand Paradise PuntaCana. We arrived there on February 1st, 2003.The check in was fast and the luggage was delivered quickly to our roomon the 2nd floor in building #1. The room was large and bright with a nice size balcony. The fridge was stocked with soft drinks and bottled water. The bathroom was also fairly big. Everything was very clean, and there were no insects tobe seen all week long. The air conditioner was running quiet, which is important for a good night sleep. The food in the La Laguana Buffet Restaurant was excellent, a large variety to choose from, never boring. We also ate at all three a la carte restaurants. The food was good, but it seemed they wanted you out of there as soon as possible. They did not give you enough time between courses to relax and enjoy your drink. You hardly finished the main course and the desert tray was on the way. We constantly had to remind the waiter to come back a little later. The pool and the pool area were beautiful and kept clean all the time. The washrooms, no matter which ones we used, were always clean. There were a variety of activities during the day to keep anyone busy. We never felt pressured to participate in any activities, which we found very nice. The beach was also beautiful. The first few days the waves were too big for us to go in, but then the ocean calmed down and we loved it. The drinks at the bars were good, although they were inconsistent from bartender to bartender. A drink would be made with orange juice and another bartender would use pineapple juice for the same drink, but after a few of those, they all tasted just about the same. We have been to Cuba and Mexico a few times before but the GrandParadise was the best so far. The size of the resortis perfect. Everything is close by. We really loved it. Our motto always was, never go to the same resort twice, but the Grand Paradise changed our mind. We will be there again next winter if we can book a room on the upper floor.
